column1: This is a good product - sounds great
column2: gets good battery life
column3: everything you'd hope for in an iPod dock.  But it has one major flaw.  The iPod docking port is really flimsy
column4: and has no structural support aside from the actual electronics themselves.  After a little bit of use
column5: the connection between the iPod and the dock deteriorated to the point that the volume fluctuated up and down
column6: and sometimes the sound cuts out all together.  If they added some kind of simple support so that bumping the iPod wouldn't stress the electronics
column7: I'd give this thing 5 stars.  But without that
column8: it simply breaks quickly
column9: and no longer performs its only job - to sound good.

column1: I bought this as a replacement for my stowaway when I replaced my Palm m105 with an HP IPAQ. The palm-stowaway combination was an excellent portable alternative to my laptop and I used in nearly every day.  After my positive experience I expected my new IR keyboard to function the same way.  What a dissapointment! I can forgive the large size of the keyboard but there are several aspects of this keyboard that have made it intolerable to me. I found the keys did not always respond leaving me with multiple errors to fix in every paragraph and the split space bar has been a constant source of irritation
column2: I usually hit the solid piece of plastic in the middle instead of one of the keys.  The little plastic arms on the stand do not hold the PDA at all securely
column3: even bumping the table can knock it off
column4: and I have taken to using an elastic band to keep my IPAQ in place. The "mouse" arrowpad is a nice idea but does not justify the loss of the arrow keys. Finally the backlight does not stay on while using the keyboard and there is no backlight control on the keyboard (unlike the stowaway). I will be replacing this keyboard with another after a much more careful search

column1: Right from the start I have had problems with this coffee marker.  The timer/clock loses about 5 minutes a day so I'm always resetting the time to the correct time so that the automatic start feature will work.  The lid on the thermos leaks during brewing. Which means coffee spills everywhere including on the maker which also shuts the coffee marker off. So I end up with coffee everywhere and have to wait hours before I can even think of using the marker again.   I have owned the coffee maker for less than 30 days and I think I will be looking for a replacement tomorrow

column1: Sir Leycester Coltman was Head of the Foreign Office's Latin America Department
column2: then Ambassador to Cuba (1991-94)
column3: then to Colombia (1994-98). But as this mean-minded book shows
column4: this hardly qualified him to write `the real' biography of Fidel Castro.   This book gives the Foreign Office view
column5: brimming with anti-trade union
column6: anti-national and anti-communist sneers. For example
column7: he casts doubts on Fidel's brother's parentage
column8: citing as evidence Raul's `slanted oriental eyes'
column9: but even the book's photos disprove this.   Coltman patronisingly assumes that Britain can give lessons in democracy to Cuba
column10: but how many of us voted Mandelson an EU Commissioner? Coltman smugly assumes that capitalism means progress
column11: but capitalism
column12: a mode of production
column13: does not make technological innovations or scientific advances: the working class makes them all. He cannot describe US imperialism and the illegal US blockade without putting the offending words in inverted commas.  He claims that the Macmillan government's decision to sell the Cuban dictator Batista warplanes and tanks was `commercial rather than political'
column14: because Britain's economic situation was `desperate'.  When Macmillan refused to sell Hawker Hunter fighters to Castro to defend Cuba against imminent US aggression
column15: the situation was presumably not so desperate. Kennedy's illegal assault on Cuba showed that Bush's practice of unilateral
column16: aggressive war is nothing new.  Cuba's eight million people have sustained independence and sovereignty
column17: repelling all efforts to interfere in their internal affairs. So Fidel rightly opposed the Sandinistas' 1989 decision to bow to US-EU demands to hold multi-party elections in Nicaragua: the Sandinistas even let the US government fund the opposition.   He warned
column18: "Some people think they can save socialism by making concessions. They fail to take account of the voracious mentality of imperialism and of the reactionary forces. If you give them part of a fingernail
column19: they will want part of your finger; if you give them a piece
column20: they will want the whole finger; if you give them the finger
column21: they will ask for the forearm; if you give them the forearm
column22: they will ask for the arm; and when you give them the arm
column23: they will chop off your head."

Pillows making contact

column1: this hippy master of CHEESE made my middle years a living HELL with his horrid M.O.R. sap toons! How can ANYONE actually praise these corntastic AM gold leftovers from an era that had some REAL music  going on? This is like putting AIR SUPPLY over the BEATLES as a GREAT ROCK BAND---wake up America!
GWTW certainly was one-sided in its portrayal of the Old South
column2: and I can see how that could be a deal killer for a lot of readers.  Although I consider GWTW to be one of the greatest pieces of American literature ever written
column3: I was VERY excited by the idea of TWDG.  The idea of building a "back story" around the black characters in Mitchell's novel is BRILLIANT!  So much could be done with this idea to address issues of race and slavery
column4: as well as to broadside a popular piece of American literature through counterpoint.  Unfortunately
column5: this great idea is wasted because Randall is utterly lacking in talent.  The thing that immediately bothered me about TWDG is the extraordinarily poor use of dialect.  One sentence has the main character narrating in perfect grammar with strong vocabulary and then in the next sentence she's all "he do dat" and "me go sleep."  Randall should have picked one voice for her main character and stuck with it.  This alone represents terrible hack writing
column6: but I must go on and say something about the (snicker) "plot."  The plot
column7: which should be subversive and controversial
column8: fails to rise above the trashy romance novel level
column9: and the (I think they're supposed to be shocking) sex scenes wouldn't shock anyone except my Amish Aunt Minnie.  I actually laughed out loud several times as I read them because I pictured Clark Gable/Rhett Butler saying some of this ridiculous dialogue.    The plot here is so flaccid that Randall inadvertently undermines her own book.  The white characters remain more interesting than any of the black characters.  This despite the fact Randall gives them tons of dirty linen to air in an obvious (and pathetic) attempt to make them interesting.  Her black characters are non-entities
column10: which I believe was her beef with Mitchell in the first place....right?!   As a result
column11: by writing TWDG
column12: Randall is only spray painting a nasty word on the castle walls of GWTW when what she needed to do was bulldoze the original
column13: dance gleefully on its grave
column14: and create something very powerful in its place.  But that would take a skilled writer
column15: and Randall just doesn't have the goods.  "Taking on" GWTW is a great idea
column16: especially to stir up discussion around issues of racism and slavery in our country and our history.  However
column17: to do an idea like that justice requires a talented author (i.e.
column18: not Alice Randall).  Maybe Toni Morrison should take this on?  I'd read that

column1: I read this short novel because I greatly admired Shaara's Pulitzer Prize winning "Killer Angels
column2: and because I'm a baseball fan.  The novel feels more like an outline or first draft than a completed work about an aging pitcher.  It's a bit shallow and predictable in its plot.  The characters are what one expects in all too many sports novels and short stories.  The feel or atmosphere just isn't quite there.  Any baseball fan will see flaws in the book right away, flaws that distract and damage the work.  Shaara sets most of the novel in Yankee Stadium with the Hawks playing the Yankees.  Why the author chose to have one real team against a fictional team is unclear.  The Hawks apparently are from Atlanta, but an Atlanta team, Braves or Hawks, whichever, would not be playing the Yankees interleague on the next to last day of the season.  Finally, when a visiting pitcher goes out to warm up before the game, he does so in the semi-hidden bull pen down the left field line in Yankee Stadium--not on the mound on the field.  This book was published posthumously and Mr. Shaara perhaps never had a chance to polish his prose--prose that was excellent in Killer Angels."  It's unfortunate.  There are glimmers of interest in the book
column3: but not enough to recommend it to baseball fans or fans of the author's other book

column1: This book is a review of research concerning heart disease
column2: cholesterol
column3: and diet.  The author makes little attempt to be objective
column4: and pushes continually for his opinion that research to date has not been able to prove conclusively that a diet high in cholesterol leads to heart disease.  In the beginning of the book
column5: he carefully lays out the logic for the reader
column6: separating the main hypotheses concerning cholesterol so that he can then bring each into question in turn.  For Ravnskov
column7: the main hypotheses are: "a high-fat diet leads to high cholesterol levels in the blood" and "high cholesterol levels in the blood lead to arteriosclerosis and heart attacks."  He also examines related hypotheses of perhaps lesser importance
column8: such as "lowering your cholesterol level with lengthen your life" or "polyunsaturated oils are good for you".  Each chapter begins with a description of what Ravnskov terms a "myth" concerning cholesterol or heart disease
column9: which Ravnskov then counters with a critical analysis of the research purported to prove the claim contained in the "myth".    Ravnskov points out a fair number of problems with the classic studies concerning heart disease and cholesterol.  These problems range from the way in which the studies were conducted
column10: to who was studied
column11: to how the results were interpreted.  One odd point that he mentions repeatedly is that in some studies
column12: researchers "chose" to use a "less-rigorous" one-tailed t-test when seeking statistical significance when they should have been held to the "more rigorous" two-tailed t-test.  Now I'm no statistician
column13: but from what I remember of t-tests
column14: it's not that one type is more rigorous than the other
column15: but that one is appropriate for certain purposes and the other is appropriate for others
column16: and you never really have a choice about which one to use-you just have to choose the one that fits the type of question you are trying to quantify.  So do any of Ravnskov's criticisms of statistical methods hold water?  I'm not sure.  When criticizing the work of others
column17: Ravnskov pays quite a bit of attention to questions of statistical significance
column18: but unfortunately
column19: when making his own claims
column20: Ravnskov often omits little things like p-values.  A friend of mine read this book and was quite taken with Ravnskov's contention that the body makes its own cholesterol
column21: so if you eat foods high in cholesterol it doesn't have to make as much than if you avoid cholesterol-laden foods.  This friend has been a vegetarian for twenty years and is very physically active
column22: but she still has a moderately high cholesterol level.  She figured that if Ravnskov were right
column23: the reason why her cholesterol level is high might be because she doesn't eat meat
column24: so if she were to switch to eating a lot of meat
column25: her cholesterol would stay the same or perhaps even go down. A month-long trip to Mongolia
column26: where she would have to subsist on a mostly mutton diet
column27: gave her the chance to test these ideas.  Before she left for Mongolia
column28: she had her cholesterol tested-240 mg.  In Mongolia
column29: she kept her active lifestyle
column30: but ate mostly mutton
column31: which contains the most cholesterol of all red meats.  As soon as she got back from Mongolia
column32: she had her cholesterol tested again.  Instead of staying the same or going down
column33: it was up to 280 mg.  Hmmm...perhaps there's something to the preponderance of scientific research after all.  Ravnskov would probably explain away the result by saying that cholesterol measurements can vary widely
column34: or perhaps that this woman has a genetic predisposition for high cholesterol.  But the experiment was enough to convince my friend that at least for her own body
column35: a high-cholesterol diet will raise her blood cholesterol.  However
column36: she's not brave enough to test the second part of Ravnskov's claim: that there's no link between high blood cholesterol and heart disease.  She's back to her vegetarian diet with a vengeance
column37: and her cholesterol is back to 240 mg again.  Ravsnkov seems to have potentially valid criticisms of all of the major studies concerning cholesterol and heart disease.  But still
column38: it's hard to see how ALL the research could be wrong
column39: when there is such a large body of it
column40: and it all points in the same direction.  Ravnskov hasn't been able to come up with a single piece of research that argues strongly for a non-connection or shows no linkages.  (He notes of course
column41: that logically speaking
column42: he doesn't need to do so; he need only show that the other arguments were invalid.)  He concedes that people with a genetic propensity for high cholesterol do indeed have higher rates of heart disease
column43: so I'm thinking that perhaps that might be true for the rest of us as well.  Meanwhile
column44: perhaps the greatest value of this book is in its identification of and citations to the major studies in the field.  Study the references section carefully
column45: then go read the original papers yourself before you make up your mind.  (Unfortunately
column46: the references aren't listed in standard bibliographic form
column47: but Ravnskov usually provides enough information in his extensive endnotes to allow readers to scout out the original papers.

column1: The story begins with two College guys who just came back from Mexico with Spanish Fly which they plan to sale to their college friends. column9: and I was just about to put it down when I came across those drawings that had enthralled me all those years ago.  They were done by a man named Cor Blok
column10: a Dutch artist who had conceived of his work as something like The Bayeaux Tapestry.  Never have I seen such an accurate portrayal of Tolkien's vision.  Tolkien was trying to create a mythology for our time
column11: and Blok's art is the visual representation of this mythology.  LOTR is not a comic book
column12: it's a saga for the ages.  Blok has given a face to these writings with a timeless allure like no other

column1: This is a book in the genre of Mein Kampf and The Protocols of the Elders of Zion.  An unapologetic smashmouth racist tome that revels and celebrates hatred and fear and is sure to provide supremacist groups with a wonderful volume to treasure and keep on the shelf.  I feel sad when I see that this book will clearly be used to indoctrinate and "teach" people how to hate and fear other people.  Raspail's central thesis is that white people should be nervous because there are a lot of non-white less "desirable" people out there who are coming to peacefully take over their fat
column2: rich lands.  He uses every negative
column3: racist term to describe nonwhites calling them: "turd eaters" and emitting foul stenches etc. etc.  In short
column4: everyone other than whites is a subhuman animal that could be tolerated as long as it doesn't come too near.   The book is a mean spirited
column5: paranoiac Malthusian nightmare of being over-run by "the other" (where the other is a bunch of starving Indians on a convoy).  Fear pervades every page of this book and one finds one actually pitying the revoltingly racist Mr. Raspail simply because of the fever pitched fear that must course through him.    Having read Raspail's odious and despicable work
column6: I find myself wonder what would happen if an ice age descended on Europe and obliterated "Western Civilization" there. How would the North Africans react to flotillas of poor
column7: emaciated Europeans showing up on their relatively warmer shores ?  Would they adopt the attitude that Raspail longs for and attack them or....?  It's clear that Raspail is an imaginative writer. What worries me is the extent to which his work will be used to excuse

column9: justify and defend pure murderous evil.

column1: It is remarkable see the appearance of such a retrograde biography. Nothng new except the cover.  "How many times do we have to hear....?"  Tomaline's work is not really the fruit of research. It rehashes all that Millgrate had covered and leaves out (!!!!) all that has been found of interest since Millgate's biography.  We hear nothing of Hardy's first wife's hatred of him...didn't she leave a multi-volume diary entitled "Why I Hate My Husband"? No
column2: instead Tomaline gives us the wife that made the man a poet. We get nothing of the control freak whose alter ego was "Will Strong
column3: the prinipal character from an unpublished first novel.  Hardy was such a control freak that he wrote his autobiography in the third person (imagine spaking about yourself as he" and suggesting motives to yourself as though to another!) and then had his second wife publish it in her name after his death to make it seems a biography? There is so much that is newly interesting about the author that it is indeed surprising that Tomalin's rewriting Millgate (by the way
column4: a quite Hardean strategy of overwriting which made his novels palimpsests of notable quotation)
column5: made its way to the press.  Same ol' same ol.  Ho hum.

column1: I read this short novel because I greatly admired Shaara's Pulitzer Prize winning "Killer Angels
column2: and because I'm a baseball fan.  The novel feels more like an outline or first draft than a completed work about an aging pitcher.  It's a bit shallow and predictable in its plot.  The characters are what one expects in all too many sports novels and short stories.  The feel or atmosphere just isn't quite there.  Any baseball fan will see flaws in the book right away, flaws that distract and damage the work.  Shaara sets most of the novel in Yankee Stadium with the Hawks playing the Yankees.  Why the author chose to have one real team against a fictional team is unclear.  The Hawks apparently are from Atlanta, but an Atlanta team, Braves or Hawks, whichever, would not be playing the Yankees interleague on the next to last day of the season.  Finally, when a visiting pitcher goes out to warm up before the game, he does so in the semi-hidden bull pen down the left field line in Yankee Stadium--not on the mound on the field.  This book was published posthumously and Mr. Shaara perhaps never had a chance to polish his prose--prose that was excellent in Killer Angels."  It's unfortunate.  There are glimmers of interest in the book
column3: but not enough to recommend it to baseball fans or fans of the author's other book

column1: Vasari's classic text is well written (translated
column2: I guess I should say) but extremely tiresome.  For nearly every artist he simply lists their works
column3: and rarely with more analysis than by describing them as "life-like" or "beautiful."  For example
column4: here is what he says about Titian's Assumption of the Virgin in Santa Maria Gloriosa dei Frari
column5: Venice
column6: one of his most famous and celebrated paintings: "He did a panel for the main altar containing Our Lady ascending into heaven
column7: with the twelve apostles standing below her and watching her ascent
column8: but since this work was painted on canvas and perhaps poorly cared for
column9: little of it can be seen."  That's it.  The only exception to his utter factual tediousness is Michelangelo's Life
column10: where
column11: although he goes into almost no description of the works themselves besides his characteristic fulsomeness
column12: he does provide some interesting anecdotes.  If you are looking to understand and analyze Renaissance art than this book will not help you.  If you are looking to engage in scholarly debate over the origins and documentations of the discussed works then you should probably read the original
column13: unedited version in Italian anyway.

column1: It is true that the Jews have lived outside of Israel for over three- thousand years. It is also true that many Jews who live outside of Israel feel at home where they live
column2: and have no intention or dream of living in Israel. But it is also true that the central religious vision of Israel centers on a people living in the land of Israel. For those who live by Mitzvot living in Israel is mandated by the fact that only here can one do a maximum of Mitzvot. For those who connect deeply to the Promise and Covenant which are at the heart of the Biblical vision of the world it is clear that living in Israel and helping build a special society is the commandment of God.  There are other reasons for living in Israel including the fact that it is the only place in the world where one can live in a society that follows and breathes to the rhythm of the Hebrew Calendar.  While this book speaks about the variety of Diaspora communities and their pulsing life it minimizes the fact that assimilation
column3: and intermarriage are constantly depleting the Jewish people in the Diaspora. The Jewish community in Israel is the most rapidly growing large Jewish community in the world and it is expected that in less than two decades it will contain the majority of Jews in the world. In Israel intermarriage
column4: and total assimilation are minimal. In fact Jews who come here from all over the world with minimal Jewish knowledge
column5: deepen in Jewish knowledge and connection here.  It is however only fair to point out that Israel is today threatened by many forces
column6: including those of radical Islam. There is no 'guarantee' that it is the safest place for a Jew to be. There is I believe only a guarantee that it is the place where one can take one's communal responsiblity as a Jew in the deepest and most serious way.

column1: This book shows the dichotomy that exists in modern-day America between the cutthroat environment that supposedly exists in the private sector
column2: and the easy-does-it culture fostered within the public sphere of schools
column3: government agencies
column4: etc...  The book makes the case that America's youth are basically coddled K-12
column5: and end up playing catch-up during and after college when working in the free-market culture of the private sector.    These conclusions have been elaborated on before in other publications
column6: and are only true to a certain degree.  For example
column7: the author gives examples of how Americans working in the private sector excel and achieve like citizens of no other country.  The author forgets to mention that nearly all the successful industries in this country
column8: especially those that have gone to spawn copycats in other countries
column9: were and are all supported and protected by government largess.  For example
column10: automobiles would only be rich men's toys today if it were not for all those roads and parking lots built by taxpayers.  Another example
column11: US agriculture would not have survived the Great Depression and become the world's leader in food produce if not for the introduction of farm subsidies
column12: government-funded agricultural research
column13: government-operated satellites and weather stations to monitor the weather
column14: and other government programs that directly or indirectly help farmers.  These and other established
column15: successful private industries would be nowhere without some "coddling" from US taxpayers.  Even if we dismiss the previous points
column16: I believe the author has only shown half the picture; specifically
column17: the author does not fully examine the question of why "coddling" occurs in schools and students are not prepared for the competition of the "real world".  The answer to this question connects the dichotomy so well illustrated by the author.  Specifically
column18: American adults are so busy surviving in the private sector that they have less time and effort to raise their kids to be good competitors themselves.  For example
column19: the character traits that makes for successful businesses: willingness of employees to relocate
column20: works long hours
column21: toeing the company line
column22: etc...
column23: are exactly the worse traits to follow when trying to raise kids well.   Raising kids well means living in stable communities with low turnover - this means minimal relocation of employees by businesses.   Raising kids well means spending time with them
column24: and not spending long hours at work.   Raising kids well means teaching them to stand up for what they believe in
column25: not what their peers (boss
column26: coworkers
column27: etc...) want them to do.    This then is what the author has totally missed out on in this book; an explanation of how the dichotomy between private sphere hard-nosed competetion
column28: and public sphere cushion jobs came about.  Because of this omission
column29: this book is merely commentary and observation
column30: and lacks insightful thought

column1: Dashiel Hammett
column2: author of such classics as THE MALTESE FALCON and THE THIN MAN
column3: certainly deserves credit as one of the originators of the noir genre. Unfortunately RED HARVEST doesn't live up to this reputation.  	RED HARVEST starts with the Continental Op arriving in the mining town of Personville (sometimes called Poisonville). He has been hired by the editor of the local paper
column4: who turns up dead. This editor is also the son of mining magnate Elihu Willsson
column5: who had called in a collection of hooligans to break a strike. What he had not foreseen was the inevitability the criminals would take over the town.   	Originally I had the idea the "red" in the title had something to do with the socialist workers movement or the Wobblies
column6: a logical assumption since Hammett was a communist
column7: but Hammett settles for the obvious
column8: the red meaning murder after murder as  the Continental Op turns the criminals against each other.  	A blurb on the back of the book lauds Hammett for "sharply and economically defined" characters. They're sharply defined all right
column9: so sharply defined that they all run together. Pete the Finn
column10: Lew Yard
column11: Max Thaler and Noonan
column12: the chief of police
column13: could be the same character. At the beginning of the novel
column14: the Continental Op learns the history of conflict from Bill Quint
column15: an I.W.W. organizer from Chicago
column16: but that's pretty much the last we hear from him.   	About the only interesting character in the whole book is the femme fatale
column17: Dinah Brand
column18: but her sole motivation seems to be money.  	Hammett also has problems with resolution of conflict. When painted into a corner
column19: he simply kills off another character.  	Even the Continental Op is pretty much a cipher. He doesn't seem to have much of a background
column20: other than that he's somewhat afraid of the Old Man
column21: who runs the Continental Detective Agency. We know he smokes and drinks too much and even takes cocaine
column22: but other than that he doesn't live up to his cool name. Unfortunately all of this reads like a bad comic book. Even Hammett would have a good laugh at what the New York Times said about RED HARVEST
column23: I would assume in 1929 when it was published: "RED HARVEST is more than a superb crime novel: it is a classic exploration of corruption and violence in the American grain." I'll give him two stars for noir dialogue
column24: but the rest of it is pretty much dreck.

 I never bought a copy of this book but was provided an unsolicited copy by the author thirty years ago. I regarded it then, as I do now, as a serious challenge against, not a part of, historical bible-based Christianity. Since spiritism and necromancy are among the pagan occult practices specifically identified and forbidden in the bible (Deuteronomy 18:10-13, Leviticus 20:6), it can be expected that a christ portrayed from such sources would also be in contradiction with the bible (fell in the garden of Eden(i.e. sinned), reincarnated numerous times, sat under eastern masters, etc.). These assertions may be intriguing to someone who is under the enticement of the occult, but to the orthodox Christian they are utter blasphemy against the Son of God. The book convinced me that Cayce functioned as a spiritist medium as defined in Deuteronomy 18 and that the Cayce readings were demonically inspired.   Nowhere in the bible does the Spirit of God endeavor to fascinate anyone with the prospect of spiritual knowledge, rather he deals with the deeper issues of the conscience; the imperative of repentance and new birth, and the seriousness of death and judgment to come. And as it is appointed unto man once to die
column5: but after this the judgment" - Hebrews 9:27. Denying these biblical tenets in favor of reincarnation is serious business as reincarnation glosses over personal accountability and the right of a holy God to reveal every secret and to settle all accounts at the final judgment.   Being a born-again Christian since 1967 and having advised the now-deceased author of my convictions in these matters
column6: I would not recommend this book to anyone seeking Christ
column7: but rather the gospel of John
column8: then the rest of the bible. The true
column9: living Lord Jesus is there. Repent of your sins
column10: receive him as Lord of your life
column11: keep his words and you will find him
column12: for he then will flood your inner being with himself (John 14:23).    "For God so loved the world
column13: that he gave his only begotten Son
column14: that whosoever believeth in him should not perish
column15: but have everlasting life" - John 3:16

column1: I bought this headset for my daughter at Christmas.  They sounded great and she loved them
column2: but after about 8 weeks of use she quit using them.  She showed me that the speaker part pulled out of the band. After examining them I see that it is all plastic and the wire rides in a little grove on the inner side of the band.  When the speaker part pops out the wire become the support and the whole thing just dangles around your neck. I was very disappointed with the workmanship of this product and would not recommend them

I was looking forward to the arrival of this bike so much
column2: I thought it was going to be a great way to burn calories while doing just about anything. But when I tried it I discovered 2 things. First off your legs have to be at a 90 degree angle in order to pedal without it moving all over the place (which means you have to have an adjustable office chair or put phone books on a normal one). And when I finally get settled on it no matter how hard of a setting it's on it only burns about a calorie a minute.   This bike might be great for arm workouts because it doesn't move as much on the table and it can offer a lot of resistance (though I only tried it for a few minutes) but definitely not for your legs

column1: The Last Samurai is a re-do of the 1990 borefest Dances With Wolves.  Once again
column2: a formerly evil American U.S. Army officer comes to the aid of an indigenous people who are threatened by evil predatory U.S. imperialism.  At least that is what the filmmakers would like you to believe.    Actually
column3: the Japanese samurai were an oppressor class in their own right.  The samurai preyed on the peasants.  Eventually
column4: as reformers took hold in 19th Century Japan
column5: a new national army based on the peasantry was formed.  When the samurai rose in revolt against the reform government and attempted to restore their traditional privileges. the national army defeated them.    The Last Samurai fails as both movie and history.  Avoid it like the plague.

column1: **1/2  In "Hitch
column2: Will Smith plays a modern-day Henry Higgins, who, for a tidy fee, will teach lessons of love to a bunch of lovelorn Eliza Doolittles - only, in this case, the Elizas are grown men who desperately need instruction on how to win the hearts and affections of the women of their dreams. Of course, the irony is that Hitch doesn't adhere to his own formula, being a confirmed bachelor with no interest in entering into a serious relationship with anyone himself. Until, that is, he meets the woman of his own dreams, Sara, a New York City gossip columnist who has no idea what it is Hitch does for a living.  It occurs to me that, when it comes to certain movie genres - action movies and romantic comedies in particular - it would be helpful if we could inflict some kind of temporary amnesia on ourselves so that we could at least think we were watching something new and fresh and not something we've already seen a hundred times before. Even the best romantic comedies can't entirely avoid paying homage to the formula
column3: and Hitch" is clearly no exception. As such
column4: the film has some mildly amusing moments
column5: some endearingly sweet scenes
column6: and some cute little plot complications amidst all the sentimental clichï¿½s
column7: lowbrow slapstick and tired stereotypes we generally find in these films. (I mean
column8: do we really need yet another romantic comedy in which one of the heroine's co-worker sidekicks is a light-in-the-loafers
column9: preposterously effeminate gay man?). It seems like every time "Hitch" is about to win us over
column10: it short circuits itself and loses us by going for the obvious.  Smith makes for a smooth romantic lead
column11: but Eva Mendes doesn't always seem up to the challenge of her role
column12: particularly when she is called upon to convey dramatic intensity. Actually
column13: of the performers
column14: it is Kevin James ("King of Queens")
column15: as an overweight klutz who has hired Hitch's services to help him woo a beautiful blond heiress
column16: who walks off with the film. Even though he's only a supporting player
column17: it doesn't take him long to assume center stage in the film
column18: essentially relegating the leads to second banana status.

column1: I loved Dr. Pert's previous book
column2: The Molecules of Emotion.  I was thrilled to hear this new book was being released and couldn't wait to get a copy.  The title of this book made bold promises
column3: but I was disappointed to find that it failed miserably to deliver.  I expected a book that would outline activities or exercises to practice the art and science of feeling good and finding one's self in the presence of God in a present-moment way.   The book offered neither
column4: but rather
column5: rambled on and on
column6: outlining Ms. Pert's own life's journey in an in-your-face sales-pitch "I got it
column7: you should too" presentation that only flaunted
column8: and failed to ever really teach.    Ms. Pert's discussions on dietary health and wholeness were limited and contradictory at best.  If you want real data backed by science in this area
column9: I suggest the writings of Dr. John McDougall (especially the McDougall Plan and The McDougall Program)
column10: John Robbins
column11: and particularly T. Colin Campbell's China Study.  Little concrete information was really offered in the practice of "feeling good."  If you want practical information and a firm plan that promises results in this area
column12: Dr. Laurel Mellin's The Pathway does more than deliver on such promises.  Recovery from trauma was mentioned

column1: I made the mistake of picking up this book to read over a long weekend.  The title caught my eye and the concept seemed promising
column2: but once I actually got into the story I was very disappointed.  Too many of the major plot points are entirely unbelievable.  For instance
column3: a child who the protagonist encounters abandoned in a village becomes a singular focus and driving element--even though the protagonist barely spends any time with her and hithertofore has not been the motherly type.  Over and over again the CIA frontman gives into her unreasonable and irrational demands
column4: to the point that one starts to root for the bad guys.  To anyone with a high school biology class under the belt
column5: the science is preposterous and completely unbelievable.  Much effort is put forth to develop an "antidote" (actually an antibody) to anthrax.  Cipro
column6: anyone?  The writing is also very stilted
column7: often awful
column8: and at times laughable.  Too many times to count a character "smiles sardonically" or "speaks jerkily".  At times the plot turns are so poorly described it is difficult to judge just what the heck is going on.  And
column9: ultimately
column10: the characters behave so irrationally one does not really care.  I would only recommend reading this if you need perspective on how bad books can really be.  Otherwise
column11: look elsewhere

This volume is disappointingly lightweight. Notwithstanding the comment of another reviewer who allegedly spent several evenings reading it
column2: one can easily read it in 2 hours or even much less. The pages have relatively few lines of text
column3: and those lines are widely-spaced. Almost 30% of the book (55.5 pages out of 190
column4: other than intro and index) is filler
column5: comprising biographies repelete with photos of the chapter authors in their Formula 1 racecars
column6: running in a triathlon
column7: rubbing their dog's belly
column8: etc.
column9: and lots of information about their hobbies
column10: or else pages that are completely blank but for brief epigrams by the likes of Benjamin Franklin
column11: Mark Twain and Herman Melville.  The substantive focus is almost exclusively on patents
column12: with a dash of trade secrets thrown in. On the plus side
column13: writers from IBM
column14: HP and Intel have good stuff to say about licensing strategies. But the book doesn't say much about the strategic side of building a portfolio -- e.g.
column15: you won't find any mention of designing around
column16: the doctrine of equivalents
column17: walls
column18: fences or flooding. Many of the articles exalt the delights of suing people. The authors voice opposing views about patent trolls
column19: but the discussion is surprisingly black and white
column20: with little nuance (e.g.
column21: no discussion about whether there should be different remedies for different sorts of patent owners).   A frequent refrain throughout the book is that up to 80% of many companies' value is in IP and intangible rights. But actually
column22: good luck trying to get 80% of your market cap by selling off your IP portfolio. In the context of this book
column23: the statistic is misleading in several respects. First
column24: the percentage is based on the gap between the market capitalization of a company and the book value of its tangible assets.  Much of the value in this gap is in goodwill and brand
column25: i.e. trademarks and related rights
column26: which aren't discussed in this book at all. Second
column27: the debate over whether market cap accurately reflects fundamental value would fill many books the length of this one. Lastly
column28: the valuation of patents is especially context-dependent. A patent's value can only be determined by  licensing or selling it to someone else
column29: or by using it in litigation. For most companies (trolls aside)
column30: only a small percentage of their patents will ever be litigated. It's hard to predict which ones those will be
column31: and even harder to predict the financial outcome of the case. And the percentage that are licensed is usually well under a majority (and in many cases is zero). All these issues complicate the attribution of value to patents. But aside from some brief discussions of patent quality in one or two chapters
column32: you won't find such issues grappled with in this book.  The three or four best articles
column33: such as the one by M. Phelps about IBM's licensing program
column34: are way too short and general to give you much guidance on how to implement a strategy at your company. They're like tantalizing hors d'oeuvres -- whereas the book is priced like a full meal (or a very fancy entree
column35: at least). As for the balance
column36: there are plenty of websites and blogs where you can get articles of comparable depth and insight for free. So buy this book used
column37: or read it in a store. A meatier book about patents generally
column38: including portfolio strategy
column39: is Knight's "Patent Strategy for Researchers and Research Managers"; and about licensing programs
column40: a pretty good choice is Parr and Sullivan's "Technology Licensing: Corporate Strategies for Maximizing Value." You may spend more on those
column41: but they're much better value for the price.

column1: Suzanne Somers apparently has no use for modern medical science. Especially as a survivor of breast cancer (although of a very early stage) she is putting her life in grave danger by taking hormones. Recent studies have shown that women who were taking HRT for protection from heart problems actually had MORE problems than normal menopausal women. This is an unbelievably destructive
column2: horribly dangerous book for people to take seriously. Being skinny is NOT more important than being alive. If you want to get the real scoop on hormones
column3: talk to a doctor at an academic medical center (in other words
column4: one that isn't going to mislead the public for personal financial gain) and see what she or he has to say. Chances are excellent that you'll be told to avoid them at all cost. Look at it this way: are you going to put your very life in the hands of Suzanne Somers? I'm sure she's a very nice person; it's just that she has no medical training whatsoever. *** writing from an NCI-designated Comprehensive Cancer Center**

column7: the character designs were interesting and the marketing gimmicks of seeing NEW characters were enticing... So what's the problem with Pokemon?   Look at the industry when the previous fads hit the airwaves. Children's entertainment was all about milking toys and movies so much that each fad could survive only until the next hit movie or new toy was released. Pokemon wasn't like these previous crazes made to sell a bunch of toys until interest moves onto the next big thing. Pokemon was an institution. They created an entire world of escapism that ended up to be so powerful

column14: Card Captors

I bought this book wondering if it would show me any tips to improve my running technique. The book does serve as a good introduction to running technique and I would suggest the book to a person who knows nothing on the topic.  However
column2: the book left me more convinced than ever before that one cannot improve technique from lessons in a book.  Coaches exist for a reason and this is one of them.  Runners who have great body and muscle awareness are not going to have major problems and thus are not going to need this book.  On the other hand
column3: runners who have poor body awareness are going to need a knowledgable person (a coach) to watch them run and identify the problem. So they don't need the book either and are better of spending their money on a coaching session.  This book might be useful for a student taking a college course in coaching running but that is about it.  Beside this general complaint the book itself leaves a lot to be desired.  The photographs in the book are rather poor.  They are simply clips from a video and suffer from all the problems that causes.  It was really mind boggling to me that the publisher was so cheap as to not pay for a still camera to take photos.  The poor quality images make it difficult at times to really understand what the author is refering to in the picture.  It is most unfortunate that the authors obvious knoweledge is hindered by this  problem.  Further
column4: there isn't a modern fad (running barefoot
column5: neuromuscler training) that the author doesn't fall for.  It used to be "muscle memory" was all the rage.  The book would have been stronger if these issues were left out as the author comes across as pandering.     All in all I think this is a book that might serve some useful purpose for a person who knows little about proper running technique.  But for a person with difficulties it is not a substitute for a some sessions with a good coach.

column1: The premise behind this book is that by following the techniques advocated by the "Fools
column2: you can pick stocks on your own and do better than the market as a whole and better than most professional mutual fund managers.  Think about it.  If this premise were true, then most of the professional mutual fund managers would be out of a job, replaced by anyone that could follow the Fools" advice.  The book is principally a big advertisement for the Motley Fool's web-site (www.fool.com) and much of the content it references isn't even there any more.  For instance
column3: the book references real world stock portfolios called the Rule-Breaker and Rule-Maker which you can supposedly see and follow for free on their web-site.  If you search google
column4: you'll find a page on their web-site announcing that both have been discontinued.  I'm guessing it wasn't because of their stellar performance.  Fortunately
column5: you can still *buy* the Motley Fool Rule Breakers Newsletter for $199.00 per year.  Whew!  The book also announces the creation of a new stock index
column6: which the book calls the "NOW 50
column7: but which the Fools renamed Fool 50" after the book was published.  Today
column8: if you go www.fool.com's stock index section
column9: you'll find no reference to the index.  You can still find links to the old pages if you search google (fool.com "fool 50")
column10: but not if you search on fool.com.  An index that lasted no more than 3 years!  Amazing!  Perhaps the best critique of the Fools is in Investing for Dummies (Fourth Edition) on pages 382-383:  "[O]nly one of their seven portfolios has actually performed better than the market averages--two of their portfolios were shuttered after poor performance (one of which plunged 50 percent during its short six-month existence)."  Fools indeed!  By the way:  "Investing for Dummies" is a great book full of sound investment advice.  Make sure you get the latest editions (the Fourth was just released and the Third is still on many store shelves) The companion title "Personal Finance for Dummies" is also full of advice worth hundreds of times its cover price.

column1: An album of outtakes and rarities is an odd thing.  Obviously
column2: the songs weren't good enough to make the album they were originally intended for.  Either that or the artist felt they didn't fit right.  So how does one go about grading an album of this type?  It's not easy.  Graded as a stand-alone album on its own merits
column3: I'd give this one a single star.  Marked by inconsistencies and a lack of flow
column4: it's a poor effort that starts out extremely strong and ends gasping for breath.  Graded as a complementary album to "Illinois
column5: however, I'd give it three stars.  I can understand why the songs weren't used and find several of them worth repeated listening.  If i could give half stars, this album would get 1.5 simply because of the overwhelming length.  The respective lengths of Illinois" and "Michigan" weren't an issue as the albums both contained an overwhelming amount of good tracks.  A compilation like this of rarities and b-sides would have been better served as a 35-40 minute production rather than the 75-minute opus this package is

column12: I see this as a mere footnote in the Mingus catalogue

column1: After reading Old Wounds
column2: I was left to wonder whether a book series could get any worse.  I was almost dreading picking up the second book
column3: Enemy of my Enemy
column4: but since I had already bought it
column5: there didn't seem to be much reason not to.  Whatever its problems were
column6: Old Wounds was a quick read
column7: so this one promised to at least be the same (despite being 30 pages longer).  I am happy to say that it is a lot better than the first book.  I am unhappy to say that the reason for this is because the first one is so bad
column8: not because this one is that good.  Enemy of my Enemy doesn't have near the number of howlers as Old Wounds did
column9: but that's mainly because it's using the same story and characters and thus we are used to them.  Enemy of my Enemy contains many of the same problems as Old Wounds
column10: but they aren't as prominent
column11: mainly because there is actually some action and intrigue in this book.  The cat and mouse game between "Chakotay" and the doctor got interesting at times
column12: even if some of the scenes were just laughable (especially the scene where Kaz sneaks into Kim's quarters to wake him up.  What
column13: the door buzzer doesn't work?).  While I didn't buy how long it took for everybody to figure out that something was wrong with Chakotay (as spiritual a man as Chakotay is leaving behind the body of his sister when it would be very easy to retrieve her?  That's not the Chakotay I
column14: or most of the others
column15: know)
column16: I was able to put that aside and let some of the individual scenes wash over me.  Granted
column17: there weren't many of them
column18: but there were a couple.  The problem with this plot is that it's not even remotely believable.  Not retrieving Sekaya's body is one of the main points.  Sure
column19: it makes everybody think that something's wrong
column20: but nobody seems to realize that Chakotay's grief in no way explains it like they seem to think it does.  It drags out the plot a lot longer than it should have (but then it'd be a pretty short book
column21: wouldn't it?)  Golden's "romance novel" language is slightly toned down in this one
column22: or at least I didn't notice it as much.  There is one "heaving [...]" reference which I had to laugh at
column23: but overall it's not too bad.  The prose itself is fairly wooden
column24: but at least I didn't feel like putting my finger down my throat.  She has an annoying turn of phrase at times.  One time
column25: referring to Kaz and Kim
column26: she actually says "The two Voyagers exchanged glances."  Excuse me?  Ugh.  Golden also continues to have problems keeping continuity within her own books.  In Old Wounds
column27: Kaz's previous host's personality keeps coming to the forefront of his mind because his isoboromine levels were too low.  Then
column28: on page 97 of this book
column29: he claims that his problems were caused by "elevated" isoboromine levels.  Which is it?  Golden gets most of the other characters right (or at least close)
column30: but one character continues to stick out as being horribly designed.  That is Astall
column31: the Huanni ship's counselor
column32: who continues to be written as overly emotional and
column33: thus
column34: unrealistic as a counselor.  "Her huge purple eyes searched his
column35: and tears welled in them.  She blinked them back
column36: striving to maintain her professional demeanor despite her almost overwhelming emotions."  This is a counselor?  One of my earlier complaints was that the scenes with the holographic doctor and Seven of Nine didn't appear to have anything to do with the story.  I still believe that
column37: but at least their few scenes in this book actually did have a little relevance.  The same can't be said for Torres' scenes.  Torres is on the Klingon monastery world of Boreth
column38: and she begins delving into the prophecies that may involve her daughter.  This storyline is clearly intended for subsequent books and just feels shoehorned into this one
column39: bringing what little tension there is in the main plot to a screeching halt.  The Deep Space Nine relaunch series does have a lot of continuing plotlines that carry from book to book
column40: but at least all of the characters are interacting within those plots.  The O'Briens had gone back to Earth
column41: and they weren't featured in any of the books until they returned to the station.  Torres is so far removed from this story that she seems completely out of place in it.  All in all
column42: Enemy of my Enemy is a marginally better book than Old Wounds.  Some of the scenes are more interesting
column43: the writing foibles are toned down slightly
column44: and it didn't irritate me nearly as much.  Consider it a mild sunburn to the poison oak of Old Wounds.  I'm still not going to try any more of these Voyager relaunch books unless they get good reviews from people who are known to have hated these two.  David Ro

column1: This supposedly "new" item looked like it had been either used a few times or someone had left it out in the rain.  It arrived with the one-page instruction sheet wrapped around the plastic tool.  The silver knob that you can see on the left side of this "tool" was rusted and would not turn very easily.  I'm not sure how this tool is effective in removing stubborn watch band pins.  Maybe this tool is effective in only removing pins from cheaply manufactured watches - much like this item.  When I attempted to use it
column2: the entire plastic body would flex and I was afraid that it would snap if I twisted the knob any further.  Not worth the sale price that it was advertised.  The most effective way of using it was to remove the knob and pin from the apparatus and gently tap the end with a hammer in order to loosen the pins.  This is definitely not worth the sale price

column1: I had high hopes for Requiem of Darkness since it had a dark atmosphere to it. Also
column2: the characters looked very unique and intriguing. Unfortunatley
column3: the beginning is very rough
column4: both in content and speed of the show.   The plot is about a writer who wants to create a book of horror stories. He is always interested in cursed places and people with bad omens hanging over their head. He meets up with a gang of three people with dark powers who murder the murderers
column5: and immediately becomes their intrusive groopy.  Unfortunately
column6: the show is not as slick as the plot sounds. The first episode immediately starts off with the story-telling. It is centered upon a man who murdered a talented child for he was jealous. Throughout the episode
column7: you see the man going insane with guilt and hearing strange noises. The problem is nothing interesting is revealed about any of the main characters and some of the events feel rushed and confusing without the nice introductions of who's who.   The second episode I found more enjoyable since it was unique. It is about a man with a hotel protected by the willow woman. The willow womanis infatuated with the owner and killed all of his wives and children. It even has a little plot twist
column8: nothing extrodinary but still welcoming.  And once again
column9: the third and fourth episodes deal with insane murders. This is when the show became boring for me. I do find crazy murders interesting to read and watch about
column10: but I like to have more variety if this is what the who show is going to be about. Also
column11: the show's trick of using violence and paranoia to be scary lost its buzz by the end of the DVD.  I give it an extra star since one episode is decent and the character design is great. Unfortunately

This book is a tormented stream of consciousness from a lady who was obviously fighting major demons.  It is exactly the type of book that you would expect an amateur academic to "wow" and "gush" over
column2: as it nicely fits into the dogmatic radicalism of Chicano Studies.  The discerning reader
column3: on the other hand
column4: sees page after page of outdated cliches
column5: sob-stories
column6: and anger-filled tantrums.  Anzaldua would like you to believe her suffering and self-searching  is all the fault of the "white" culture encroaching upon the enlightened cosmic race of the mestiza.  She'd like you to think that her mestiza/chicana/lesbian/female identity is the sole cause of her misfortune and hardship.   What becomes overwhelmingly evident upon reading her unabashed torrent of decadent self-pity is the learned and self-enforced quality of her "opression".   Anzaldua helplessly wallows in her romantic fatalism dreaming of the great mestiza revolution that will fix all of the world's problems by turning the middle class value system upside down.  If you like romantic literature
column7: and enjoy the hopeless and sorrowful ramblings of society's self-marginalized
column8: I might suggest "The Sorrows of the Young Werther" by Goethe or some poems by Lord Byron - at least then you get some literary value

column1: Term Limits is so bad
column2: it should become a pop culture icon ala Rocky Horror Picture Show; fans should be made to wear strange clothing and recite the worst passages to music at midnight. It's so bad that by the end
column3: the act of reading has become blatant rubber-necking - ooh
column4: wow
column5: did you see that?  Ugh!   The writing is amateurish at best.  The author's favorite action verb is 'grab' and he uses it repeatedly in scenes ranging from the mundane (the grabbing of keys and doorknobs) to the romantic (the grabbing of hands and other body parts).  Similes and metaphors are conspicuously absent
column6: but there are plenty of adverbs and adverbial phrases to fill the gap.   The author switches back and forth between referring to his characters by their first and their last names; sometimes he uses one and then - in the very next sentence! - the other. "Michael grabbed her by the shoulders and turned her around. O'Rourke saw the tears in her eyes and tried to put his arms around her..."  He makes many grammatical errors
column7: the most irritating of which is the substitution of 'that' for 'who' consistently ["Congressman O'Rourke received this tape earlier today along with a letter from the assassins that were responsible for killing..."]  The dialogue is stilted and clunky - at the lowest point
column8: he has his assassin ask another character to tell him what has 'transpired' since last they talked.  Rather than simply 'saying' things
column9: the characters yell
column10: shout and scream them
column11: resulting in the unfortunate image of the president of the United States waxing shrill and screechy at his chief of staff.  The plot is neither plausible nor compelling.  The protaganists include a bunch of renegade CIA operatives who murder 'bad' politicians
column12: and a Congressman who approves of these actions and even helps to kidnap and murder a 'bad' retired CIA black ops director.  The antagonists include the aforementioned black ops director
column13: the head of the national security agency
column14: and the bumbling and ridiculous White House chief of staff.  The demand made by the 'good' assassins
column15: following their murder of four prominent politicians
column16: is that the president present a BALANCED BUDGET with NO NEW TAXES to the Congress!  Our intrepid hero-Congressman finds this a worthy cause
column17: and when some 'good' politicans (i.e. the sort who push for the balanced budget idea) are murdered
column18: he is inspired to wreak some violence of his own.  No one
column19: whether they be protagonist or antagonist
column20: seems to possess a moral compass.  'Bad' guys can be murdered indiscriminately and no consequences will be applied; the murder of a 'good' guy may be avenged
column21: again

column23: I can't reveal the ending

column1: The essence of "Iraq Confidential" is that the CIA and NSC were unwilling to permit a U.N. arm led by an American to successfully investigate what weapons Saddam had.  The problem was that U.N. policy was to lift sanctions once Saddam had shown disarmament
column2: while U.S. policy was to retain sactions until regime change
column3: regardless of Iraq's armament.  In addition
column4: there were also problems with poor coordination between the CIA and FBI.  The key "bottom line" is that this Machiavellian U.S. strategy to defeat arms inspection probably led to the U.S. and G.B. being convinced in 2003 that Saddam had WMD when he actually had none
column5: and thereby an unnecessary war.  As for Scott Ritter
column6: he ended up becoming controversial himself (to say the least); fortunately Seymour Hersch's vouching for Scott makes the book credible.  Regardless
column7: "Iraq Confidential" should have only been an article - not nearly 300 pages

column1: The Crossing by Cormac McCarthy is an interesting but somewhat confusing look on the early west of America. The story begins with a father and two brothers trying to track and trap a wolf that had crossed over from Mexico. The Wolf is a mother and is supposedly carrying around pups with her. This part was particularly well written
column2: but became confusing when Spanish was being used heavily. In review of this part I believe that there was something deeper in the crossing of the wolf and thought of it as a metaphor to immigration issues. The short-lived story of the capture of the wolf was ended by a cleverly placed trap by one of the sons. 	Instead of killing the wolf as some would have expected (though that would have ended the book rather abruptly) the two sons decided to return the wolf to Mexico. After this happening the brothers go on various adventures including running away with a heartthrob
column3: attempting but failing to join the U.S. army and crossing in and out of Mexico a total of 3 times.  	This was a well written book but there were many useless characters in it that just seemed to distract you from the actual point. The over use of the Spanish language confused me and would confuse anyone who doesn't speak it. I thought this book lacked motivation and suspense
column4: but because of the author's brilliant mastery of the English language he was able to entangle me enough to finish it all the way through

column1: I tried to listen to this story on CD
column2: and aside from the story not being terribly interesting
column3: I was surprised at Asimov's attitude towards religion. I suppose I shouldn't have been. He is a sci fi writer
column4: after all. But I thought he was supposed to be a smart guy. He's not -- at least on this point.   The basic outline of the story (at least the beginning -- I didn't make it all the way through) is that some guy predicts that the galactic empire is going to fall
column5: so he tries to make provision to preserve technology so that the succeeding dark ages don't last as long as they otherwise might. Toward that end he gets a select group of scientists onto this relatively isolated planet where they can carry on their work
column6: which becomes the invention and maintenance of a religion that's supposed to preserve certain technologies through the coming dark ages. In this religion the high priests understand the theory -- the technology and all that -- but the local priests and the people are duped into believing in some mumbo jumbo.   It's as if you're supposed to picture some priest waving incense and saying prayers while he adjusts the knobs on the nuclear reactor
column7: believing that it's God doing something while it's really just technology.   I know that "technology as magic" and "religion = magic" are common themes in the sci-fi genre
column8: but for some reason I expected better from Asimov. It shows a rather alarming lack of thought.   Religious rituals are always geared towards the chaotic and the mysterious. There aren't religious rituals to cause the sun to rise
column9: because it's regular and dependable
column10: but there are religious rituals for storms and floods and harvests and childbirth and whatnot. Religion is also used to explain hidden things -- psychology
column11: forgiveness
column12: etc.   IOW
column13: religion is subject to criticism ("it's not measurable") in precisely the area where Asimov is trying to squeeze it. He's trying to make religion the mystical cloak for something that's regular
column14: predictable and logical. It just doesn't work that way.   If religious rituals had precise
column15: measurable results
column16: people would suspect that there's nothing religious or mysterious about them and they'd look for a material cause. Anyone who doubts that simply doesn't understand the religious mind
column17: or hasn't been paying attention. Sure
column18: there are gullible religious folk out there who'll believe anything
column19: but the majority have half an eye out for tricks and deceptions.   The very idea that you can hide technology behind a cloak of religious ritual is a rather silly science fiction writer's fantasy.  Anyway
column20: the story wasn't that compelling
column21: and this "religious cover for nuclear technology" business was so incredibly stupid
column22: I couldn't finish it.

It is infused with the 1930s' corporatist ideas and tends to favour the Communist version more than the Nazi/Fascist version. Keynes is indisputably the 2oth century's most important economist but why does Schumpeter and his creative destruction occupy position #2? I put it down to the same reason as Marx' Theory of Alienation gained such sway. As there was little else to salvage from Marx' writings
column3: they hit on that to make him apear relevant. Marx was a dangerous idiot and the fact that Schumeter heaps measured praise on him suggests that Schumpeter should also join him in the intellectual trash can of history. I see little relevant in his work which I feel has gained prominence simply because economics has lost its intellectual direction. Unlike Gary Becker and other recipients of the Nobel Prize
column4: Schumpeter tackles big issues. But the big issues shrug him off. Nothing here to ponder over

Why Palestinian nationalism is valid

column10: 2003).  Such twisted thinking is evident through "Nations and Nationalism
column11: where Mr. Hobsbawm spares no effort, however subtle, to demean nationalism that doesn't conform to his pre-existing prejudices.  In short, when writing about nationalism, Mr. Hobsbawm allowed his considerable analytic and writing skills to become corrupted by his religion, communism.  Therefore, unless you are an acolyte of that religion, this book is not worth your time, money or effort to read, and if you *are* a member of that religion, I suggest you broaden your intellectual horizons a bit, perhaps by reading Liah Greenfield's Nationalism: Five Roads to Modernity" or Benedict Anderson's "Imagined Communities.

column2: he discusses arguments about how Roosevelt may have tried to force Japan to attack the U.S. to drag us in to WWII. He views everything from that viewpoint. And then

column4: his conclusion is that Roosevelt unequivocably forced Japan to attack us.  And then he made the same claim that Roosevelt forced Germany to also declare war on the U.S. And in the case of this conclusion
column5: basically didn't even bring up any strong arguments.  Viewpoints I disagree with that are intelligently reasoned I love to read as they make me think. But random conclusions reached solely on the author's biases are a waste of paper

column1: I thought "End of Racism" would be about how to *end* the very real phenomena of racism that is based on the inexistent concept of 'race' (see any encyclopaedia). Instead
column2: the book seems to continue the disease
column3: but in a new form. For what? So it can take us another few centuries to identify the problem in its mutated form before we actually try to solve it? As for stupid and dangerous ideas like different peoples being more inferior/superior than others - what nonsense! Such lies leave an awful taste in my mouth. I find that the book just perpetuates ignorance and it might do worse if taken seriously: cause new troubles.  I have never lived in or visited America
column4: and must ascribe my knowledge of its social situations to just the local TV. But I feel the situation of African Americans to some extent has parallels in the unhappy state other peoples find themselves in: Native Americans
column5: the Maori people of New Zealand
column6: the indigenous peoples of South Africa
column7: the Australian Aboriginals
column8: the Gypsies etc. Although the symptoms are different in each case (in some communities
column9: the reaction is violence or breaking the law
column10: in others it is drinking or an unwillingness to conform)
column11: the causes might be similar. These are all peoples who have been been separated from their traditions
column12: cultures
column13: etc.
column14: most often in very violent and oppressive ways. Other cultures
column15: foreign to theirs
column16: have been imposed on them.  Isn't it possible
column17: that like a grown-up still dealing with trauma endured in childhood
column18: a community as a whole can be going through the same thing? Having only studied about the terrible centuries of slavery
column19: I can but imagine its impact in making a community feel devalued. It can hardly be surprising that the past affects the present
column20: the grown-up still trying to come to terms with his unfortunate youth. Different communities in such countries might live in the same present
column21: but their pasts are different
column22: and can be very influential in how each copes with current situations. Removing the centuries-long traumatic effects of slavery or other oppression in what is still a very short time would be hard. This would be even more difficult
column23: if not impossible
column24: if the wrong methods were used to try to heal the effects of past wrongs. As for positive discrimination
column25: I don't see it working in most cases. Of course
column26: I like the idea of special scholarships
column27: funding and extra help in unfamiliar territory like `getting a job' for those who just finished school. But not positive discrimination on one side and pushing back the previously-favoured on the other. This only segregates current generations
column28: and can lead to future resentment.  It would be good to look into whether the cause for present difficulties in these cases is *because of* human communities having been separated from their original cultures. In many countries
column29: people have been robbed of their millennia-old wisdom and traditions
column30: and so are now unable to go back to the teachings of their communities. Having their pasts erased
column31: a feeling of not belonging or even resentment is only natural. Once they were allowed to go back to their traditions
column32: Maori in New Zealand have become much more accepting of and comfortable in the present society. They also have a better overall well-being
column33: because of the support given by being part of their own ancestral form of society. Maybe in America
column34: this could be the case as well? As more Native Americans go back to their spiritual roots and spend time in their communities
column35: their overall well-being could also increase. They might not have the feeling of loss
column36: of a robbed past
column37: because they have a living present and future. And perhaps if there are African-Americans wishing to investigate their animist roots
column38: they might find a peace and hope in their ancient philosophical beliefs and myths. I can very much believe that it is when people's traditions have been forcibly stolen
column39: their past erased
column40: their original communities violently disbanded
column41: that they lose any chance of happiness and do not really have the ability to truly live for a future. (Unless they've found some other culture to replace it with
column42: which they think equally-acceptable). With former-colonies
column43: it's slightly different. In my own country of India
column44: people have been mistreated and oppressed for centuries. Eg. According to British records
column45: 25 million Indians died between 1800 and 1900 (this is only a portion of the time that they were in charge)
column46: without the British caring much. Many of the deaths were because of famine
column47: induced by the Crown taking away desperately needed provisions or hiking prices so that people couldn't afford them. India's people were able to move on after Independence
column48: even if only just
column49: because they were able to fall back on culture: they had managed to hang on to it. It's a slow process of healing
column50: and one day we'll be fine.  If any other peoples had undergone the slavery and torments that African-American people suffered
column51: the former would be in the plight that the latter are now in. As it is
column52: I wonder that African-Americans have been diligently trying
column53: and often succeeding
column54: to reconcile the past with the present - in spite of past wrongs. I do believe that the solution to current difficulties lies in their hands themselves (although everyone else can help if so willing and able). They have to search for what kind of culture they need that can help them in the present
column55: what kind of community they require to rebuild their confidence and support them with exorcising the difficulties they had faced. I don't mean a new form of segregation keeping sub-communities of America separate
column56: I just mean a culture or traditions African-Americans can turn to for guidance
column57: that understands them uniquely. Perhaps looking to their roots in African animism might provide starting points. Celebrating their far-off past
column58: but also their current identity as Americans.   Unfortunately
column59: in Africa at least
column60: the end of racism is not in sight. Around the start of the 20th century
column61: 80% of Africa was still animistic. In the 1980s/90s
column62: this was only 30%. I shudder to guess what it might be now. Soon people with African ancestry can't even look back with love
column63: admiration and pride at where they came from
column64: what their ancestors knew
column65: their heritage. No longer will *anyone* be able to look for inspiration at what had been there relatively unchanged for millennia.  And as for Sudan
column66: for a long while now - much longer than the news has informed the masses of
column67: a deadly war has been raging. Here
column68: one religion is using unspeakable violence to punish 'incorrectly practising' followers and to force-convert the rest of the population. The destruction of the ancient and peaceful animistic belief systems of the continent are just a perpetuation of that old disease of racism.
