Ellis has obviously covered all of the ground with regard to what is known about Jefferson--but he doesn't objectively present all of the factual scholarship existing about our 3rd President.   If you want to know more of the detail of what was all involved with Sally Hemings
column5: you MUST read Douglass Adair's essay "The Jefferson Scandals."  This essay is found in the book: Fame of the Founding Fathers: Essays by Douglass Adair.  Published by W.W. Norton.  Sally Hemings was the daughter of Jefferson's father-in-law; and Sally's lover was not T.J. but T.J.'s nephew (his sister's son).  That's why Jefferson never talked about the "scandal" because his close family relatives were involved; however
column6: not the way Prof. Ellis says.  The unfortunate fact is that Prof. Ellis mentions Douglass Adair in American Sphinx
column7: but he never mentions Adair's research (which Ellis cannot reasonably be ignorant of) on the alleged Sally Hemings-Thomas Jefferson liason.  It's obvious from American Sphinx that Ellis has read Adair's essays.  Prof. Ellis must know that the best evidence exonerates Thomas Jefferson
column8: but he never tells us about that. The well publicized DNA test does NOT prove TJ was the father of any of Hemings' children.  TJ never fathered any children with Hemings and Ellis knows it. Prof. Ellis is intellectually dishonest on this point
column9: and on many other points of Jefferson's life.  Too bad because he would otherwise have written a tour-de-force.  Instead it's a tour-de-FRAUD

column1: This book is egregiously superfluous.  Sternhell
column2: who has written good monographs on integral nationalism and the birth of fascism in Europe
column3: suddenly finds that the Zionism which underpins his native land
column4: Israel
column5: is nationalist socialist -- hence a form of integral nationalism and perhaps proto-fascist if not actually fascist.  Is this a revelation?  Hardly.  It has been clear from the work some forty years ago by Carl Schorske that Zionism had the same roots as Viennese anti-semitism
column6: that Zionism was the Jews' finally adoption of a nationalism that every other European people had already adopted.  It was defensive and a recognition that only Jewish nationalism could protest Jews from the nationalisms of their host peoples.  Herzl wanted to make Jews like everyone else:  a people with a land; and Zionism succeeded in giving the Jews a form of militant nationalism.  Sternhell has suddenly discovered that all other isms in Israel -- socialism
column7: Marxism
column8: liberalism
column9: Judaism -- have been fronts for nationalism.  Well
column10: where other peoples have had to invent integral nationalism -- a modern religion of nationalism -- the Jews actually invented integral nationalism in the Old Testament before anyone else.  What Europe contributed to this was 1) rejection of Jewish emancipation and 2) Rousseau
column11: who invented the religion of the modern world
column12: what Sternhell calls nationalist socialism but might as well call National Socialism (pace
column13: Hitler) which is more or less the same thing.  Thus with his untimely revelations Sternhell feeds Arab and black paranoia about Zionism being racist
column14: when all nationalisms are racist or ethno-centric.  This book serves no purpose

column1: I will remember this book forever as being the most boring peace of literature I have ever labored through. Most stories have some sort of introduction
column2: a build-up to a plot and then the events of the plot play out in an entertaining way. I don't think Tolstoy got the memo.  The story goes on and on about the pointless
column3: uninspiring lives of rich Russians at the turn of the century. None of these people interested me and I found no one to root for
column4: they were self-centered blabbering idiots.   Lets start with Anna herself. All she did throughout the entire story was whine about this or that. I honestly don't see why she hated her husband so much
column5: he seemed to be a good man. And the fact that she would abandon her son for some man really alienated me. The best part of the book  is the train scene when we were rid of her for good!  Count Vronsky was so clearly a slime ball
column6: I do hope that Russian women of that era weren't so stupid as to fall for men like him.   Kitty
column7: basically she was a blithering 12 year old brat
column8: who was absolutely pointless to the story.   But alas
column9: the most pointless person we all know was Levine. I read somewhere that Levine and Kitty were loosely based on Tolstoy and his wife. I wish that were more true
column10: seeing as Tolstoy lead a much more interesting life
column11: referring to the possibility that he had an affair with someone you wouldn't expect. If that story was is the book
column12: it would have made Levine a lot more interesting. Sadly its not and  I will remember Levine as the most boring character in all of literature.  I couldn't even finish the last chapter.  I don't know why this is still held as such a great romance. There are so many better stories out there. People just buy into the notion of a "classic" and feel that they are expected to love it. There is no reason.  Pass on this book and find something with a story and characters you care about
column13: an actual plot and a decent conclusion.

The title of this book should be an alert as how one could class the oratory work of Abraham Lincoln with Bill Clinton is beyond what a reasonable mind could accept. It is like having Albert Einstein and then including Daffy Duck. For that reason
column2: I wonder of the agenda and the claim that the author knows more than anyone about these speeches and how he can pass over the oratory of the Comanche
column3: Cheyenne and Kiowa at the Medicine Lodge treaty or for that matter neglect the moving speeches of General Patton only to include Betty Friedan who history has already passed over like most to the recent "great" speeches included here. There is just too much a mix of extraordinary with the mundane which appears like a political spin to try and make people like Bill Clinton appear great by sticking him in with Lincoln. How one can compare the destruction of a people in the words of Chief Joseph to what some of these speeches entail is pure rhetoric. One would do better to seek out the people who made the speeches in biographies and autobiographies than to invest in this rendered work
column4: but if you enjoy rolling your eyes in how the compiler includes paid speech writers for leaders with people like Lincoln
column5: Theodore Roosevelt and Chief Joseph.....then you probably will enjoy this book. 1 star to alert readers to think before they buy

column1: Joe Carpenter lost his wife and two daughters when the plane they were traveling in crashed. A year later Joe is still grieving
column2: he quit his job
column3: sold his house and is thinking of suicide.  He visits the graves of his wife and daughters to find a woman taking pictures of the graves. He wants to know what she is doing
column4: she says she was on the plane and survived. Men start shooting at her and then start following Joe. He wonders how anyone could have survived the crash.  Joe goes back to visit some of the people who lost love ones in the crash. The greiving family members are happy now that a woman named Rose has visited them. Joe can't figure why they would be so happy. Then the family members start commiting suicide.   Joe decides to go back to the place where is plane crashed since he has not been able to face it before now. He meets a family at a ranch near the crash site. They tell him a woman and small girl visited them the night of the crash and her name was Rose
column5: and she had a small girl with her named Nina. The same name and description of Joe's youngest dead daughter. Could Rose and his daughter be the sole survivors of the crash?  Joe finally meets Rose and she tells him that his daughter is alive
column6: then she tells him the story behind her surviving.  Enter the twilight zone!!!!    I thought that this was one of the worst books that I have ever read. I started to quit reading so many times
column7: but I figured the story would get better. But instead of better with a ray of hope
column8: it got weird
column9: unbelievable
column10: and down right dumb.  The story could have been so much better with a different ending. Most of the things Rose talked about were so out there you had to be a scientist to even comprehend them.  First the book was sad
column11: depressing
column12: hopeful
column13: then weird.  This is the first book of Dean Koontz I have read
column14: I know a lot of people like his books
column15: but I will not read another one.

column2: a confused lunatic with confused visions and a hard line nationalist attitude. It is no wonder that one reader nicknamed huh concluded that Tesla was stupid and was not able to finish most of his inventions (by the way
column3: this guy sounds like someone from Edison's camp). Tesla was born in an environment of constant clashes between Croats and Serbs
column4: and Ottoman empire (not "Asian barbarians" as this author constantly portrays this great Empire) had nothing to do with Tesla's departure to US. Teslas's father was orthodox priest (a hardliner) who wanted to see his son in the Serbian army (it is the same army who completely escaped into Greece which is unknown example of cowardice in the history and whose king also escaped to England leaving his nation to German mercy
column5: thus Tesla did not see anything great in this "great army"). Tesla refused going to Serbian army and he refused being hard-line nationalist. Tesla once said:" I am proud of my country Croatia and my Serbian nationality". This indicates best that he was not hard-line nationalist (keep in mind that Serbian nationalist even today claim that Croatia is occupied Serbian territory and that it will be wiped off the map). This author actually invented many stories of Tesla's life and even more of them are from second or third hand

column9: you will not learn anything from it and could be infected with serious hate.   This book is a zero mark

column1: Think about Christianity.  About Catholicism
column2: and about Protestantism.  Think about it entirely dispassionately.  Think about it removed from its major role in shaping Western society.  Think about it removed from all the Christians you know
column3: or whether you yourself are a Christian.  Hopefully
column4: at this point
column5: you will realize that there is absolutely no reason whatsoever to subscribe to it.  Christianity
column6: in its purest essence
column7: is submitting yourself to a mythical authority that you will never see
column8: hear
column9: touch
column10: or truly know.  It is the intellectual laziness of assigning all that you cannot explain about the world as the creation of an entirely unexplainable being - in other words
column11: refusing to admit the general ignorance of yourself and
column12: indeed
column13: the human race as a whole by claiming that the only reason you can't explain something is because it is inexplicable
column14: thus saving yourself the frightening strain of having to actually make an effort to think about anything.  And
column15: if God is indeed as arbitrary in his predestination as Luther and Calvin claimed
column16: why follow him?  (Claims about 'The Elect' are not an answer; in saying that God predestined only certain people to enter heaven
column17: but in acting morally you show yourself a likely member of that group
column18: Calvin merely gives the Catholic doctrine of "good works" a new name.)  As polemicized as the above may sound
column19: it does have a purpose in the context of a discussion of this book.  Luther
column20: in trumpeting more ascetic
column21: predestination-oriented Christianity over the rich
column22: material hypocrisy of the established Catholic Church
column23: was merely  replacing a material
column24: class-based slavery with a moral slavery.  In claiming that Desiderus Erasmus' promotion of free will is merely an invitation to sin
column25: Luther shows his true colors.  He demonizes choice and diversion from "the true way" in order to convince others to follow him and add to his power.  Funny
column26: he wasn't quite so opposed to free will when he himself chose to defy the established Catholic order.  It is not wrong to enjoy alcohol
column27: sex
column28: or material possessions.  It is wrong to have these things while also preaching against them
column29: as the Catholics did
column30: but it is not wrong to enjoy the material pleasures of the world.  In Luther's steadfast opposition to other people enjoying themselves
column31: and advocacy of instead living your life according to a supposedly otherworldly moral authority which conveniently seems to have been revealed only to those who gain power
column32: we have merely the cynical and
column33: yes
column34: thoroughly materialistic manipulations of a man too bitter to acknowledge others any kind of pleasure
column35: independent thought
column36: or deviation from Luther's arbitrary set of standards.  The Catholics cynically exploited the masses by selling indulgences and fake relics through promises of a nonexistent paradise (see:  The Pardoner's Tale in Chaucer's Canterbury Tales).  The Protestants cynically exploited the masses by demonizing anything that might distract those masses' attention for one second from doing exactly what the Protestant leadership said (see: John Calvin's nightmarishly despotic Geneva).  Neither was any better than the other
column37: and both attempted to squash dissent mercilessly.  Luther's book is just another one of these attempts

column1: Regardless of whether you agree with Hendershott's views
column2: you must admit that there isn't any actual sociology in Hendershott's book. There is virtually no reference to social science research
column3: except to criticize studies without any reason except that she doesn't like the results. Instead
column4: Hendershott provides anecdotal evidence from nonscientific sources as if it is generalizable.   There are two testable hypotheses in Hendershott's book. First
column5: that definitions of deviance have changed greatly over time. Second
column6: that this shift in definitions has affected people's behavior in negative ways. Both of these are easily testable hypotheses
column7: but she unfortunately doesn't test either of them
column8: and just provides examples that support her arguments. This is what sociologists call relying on an "N of 1." She should have learned that as an undergrad.   I hope this review helps you avoid the massive time-waste that reading this book would be. Instead
column9: I'd suggest reading Joel Best's "More Damned Lies and Statistics
column10:
which points out very well how dangerous it is to rely on examples and case studies as if they represent large-scale social patterns. 
 The movie is fine.  The problem is the DVD.  Poor color, sound and the images are not clear.  It is though someone taped this show with their home video camera.  Wish I had not bought this DV 
 The timing for this book couldn't be better - an era of skyrocketing deficits, an aging population (boosting pension outlays), inexorable increases in healthcare costs (fewer workers with health insurance, aging population), and businesses increasingly threatening to move elsewhere unless they receive tax relief.   Simply cutting budgets accomplishes little - as Osborne points out, it does nothing to improve areas retained. In addition, service recipients or proponents (usually providers) simply complain ad naseum until an opportunity to restore funding occurs (eg. tax increase or economic upturn) presents itself - thus setting the stage for the next crisis.   Osborne is also correct in pointing out that the most common budget cures" are simply illusions - accounting gimmicks (timing "games" regarding outlays and receipts
column11: fudging estimates
column12: temporarily ignoring voter mandates)
column13: borrowing
column14: and delaying maintenance.   At this point
column15: however
column16: Osborne goes off the track by proposing some intelligent-sounding changes in approach (eg. identify the results wanted)
column17: and proceeds to go through a lot of razzle-dazzle that simply ends up with "business as usual."   Using Washington state as an example
column18: Osborne cites how a citizens group decided to focus on providing more early-childhood-education and implementing skill-based pay for teachers - neither a "REAL" result. During the last 30+ years innumerable education "improvement" programs have been funded
column19: while progress has been non-existent - eg. scores by 17-year-olds on the National Assessment of Education Progress (the only unchanged large-scale test in the nation) have remained unchanged
column20: as have drop-out rates. This
column21: despite a more than doubling of inflation-adjusted per-pupil spending in the last 30 or so years. As for "skill-based" teacher pay
column22: study after study has found that - after taking into account pupil differences - payment for EXISTING "skill-set" programs (teacher experience or degree levels) contribute little (only the first few years of experience) or nothing to pupil achievement. So why add another dubious dimension? If one needs any more evidence
column23: consider the fact that most private schools only cost about half that of public schools.   Universities are another major State-level expenditure; like K-12 education
column24: MAJOR overhaul (not rethinking budgets)is required. Since the early 1990's
column25: professors' teaching workloads have been reduced from three classes per semester to two. Nationally
column26: and undoubtedly in Washington also
column27: the length of the academic year shrunk from 191 days in 1964 to only 156 in 1993. Meanwhile
column28: only 21 cents of every funding dollar goes into the classroom - the number of non-teaching professionals (eg. counselors) has increased from 3 per instructor in 1976 to 6 in 2001. Returning to those recent productivity levels
column29: substantially reducing admissions of the roughly half unable or unmotivated to graduate
column30: and shortening the average 5+ years required to graduate would allow savings of about $500+ million/year in Arizona and it is assumed that similar opportunities exist in Washington.   As for healthcare
column31: Osborne's Washington process suggested dropping coverage for low-income workers - an ACCOUNTING GIMMICK that simply transfers the costs to providers
column32: and adding more clinics. However
column33: what is really required is a review of incentives and other care drivers - eg. the highest-spending areas in the U.S. spend about 60% more on Medicare recipients than the lowest
column34: despite access to care and patient outcomes being better in the low-income areas. A second problem is that healthcare providers are REWARDED for their errors - payors need to insist on adherence to quality standards. A third major problem is that care recipients have no incentives to conserve - Health Savings Accounts (allowing cashing out of any funds remaining from a set amount) do so.   Clearly Osborne's work would be more useful if it focused on outcomes - both good and bad. Associated with that should also be a discussion of benchmarking (staffing levels
column35: compensation for staff
column36: and benefit levels)
column37: and continuous improvement goal-setting that emphasize reducing waste and improving quality "Toyota-style" - keys to success in the private sector.   The "bottom-line" is that the focus should not be on the budget process
column38: but on permanent reform of the biggest consumers of government funds - education and healthcare.

column1: This is something I would find on a humor website. And it's not very good. Most of the jobs listed is only held by a few people and not what I call real jobs. There is a show on The Discovery Channel that is titled "Dirty Jobs". One job that Racz mentions was featured on it. Chicken sexer. And what the job is about is quickly finding out what sex the baby chicks are. But he mentions silly stuff mostly like Saddam Hussein Double and Exorcist. A few real ones like Data Entry and Shopping Cart Valet.   I got this book from the library by placing it on hold. If I saw the inside of this book I wouldn't have bothered with it.
I found the characters to be mostly caricatures; there's no sense that any of them are actual human beings. As a result
column2: there's no change -they're static
column3: and whatever changes they supposedly go through feel completely unbelievable. And while much of the book focuses on how different classes don't truly see each other
column4: Forster commits that same sin himself by ignoring the poorest family in the book
column5: the Basts. Instead of making them seem real
column6: he reduces them to mere plot devices.  In addition
column7: Forster
column8: a product of his time
column9: is given to making sweeping pronouncements about the human race. Again
column10: if he intended some irony here (as
column11: for example
column12: Jane Austen
column13: who was so good at shading her prose with those kinds of hints)
column14: I'd think better of this book. Novels typically rely on either a solid plot (i.e.
column15: the stuff that's happening) or on solid characters (i.e.
column16: the stuff that happens in people's inner lives) or both to carry the reader through. I found neither here. At the very least I would like to feel the author's genuine love of language; I can forgive a bad book if it's exceptionally written. I didn't find that kind of prose here. You can skip a good third of the pages and lose nothing

column1: I just received the book "Exhibition Design" today from Amazon.  I was very excited to find the title because there are so few books on the subject of museum exhibition design.  I was however very disappointed with the overall quality of the book. I have other W. W. Norton books ( Building the Empire State) and I own close to 300 architecture and design books.  I have never been so shocked at the poor quality of the photography in any of my books. Some of the photos in Exhibition Design book were not sharp....some where so dark you could not tell what was really going on in the exhibit...but most seem like they were photographed with a camera phone.  I was even shocked at the poor picture resolution of the Ralph Applebaum exhibits (blurry non sharp pictures and poorly lit)... I have a couple of books that cover the same projects and the photos in those books are wonderful...I assumed that companies like Applebaum send out a specific press kit with professional photographs.  I guess I have learned that I should always see a design book in person before buying it on line
This is a well written and clever book
column2: and the author is very talented. The thing is
column3: I'm a little irritated and bored by the story of a 20-something
column4: commitment phobic
column5: seemingly adolescent kind of guy who is such an emotional midget that he can't even say "I love you." The protagonist reminds me of the quintessential young (immature) single guy whose self destructiveness is matched only by his narcissism...the kind of guy women (girls?) really go for until they get a little older and grow a backbone. Harry's a horrible jerk until she draws a line in the sand...then he realizes how much he cares and wants her back...have all of us not lived or heard this scenario in some way a zillion times since we began dating? Are we not tired of it yet? Maybe I'm getting old...it's just not very cute or alluring anymore...it was hard for me to sympathize and consequently hard for me to stop rolling my eyes.

column2: I don't find endless descriptions of sex with minority boys to be very entertaining reading
column3: let alone genius. I also don't find pointless prose that appears to have no discernable thread of thought to have much value. Personally
column4: I like to read good story tellers
column5: authors like Tom Robbins or Salman Rushdie. Naked Lunch is about as opposed to them as you can reasonably get.  This is one of those books that sounds a lot better when someone translates it for you. In reading the preface where Norman Mailer talks about it in the context of the court proceedings in the 1960s
column6: the book sounds interesting and culturally pertinent. However
column7: upon reading it the book falls far short of the lofty status we get from Mailer's answers on the stand. I understand how Alan Ginsberg
column8: a proclaimed NAMBLA member
column9: would find it's material suitable. I wonder about Mailer though. While I'll never take a stand against a person's writing what they want
column10: I do take pause when someone recommends something like this.  This is not literature so much as a heroin clouded view of the author's own serious problems and his interpretation of our culture's deficiencies. The notion that this is the "naked" truth
column11: or lunch as it is so called
column12: is so absurd that the book should never have been accepted as remotely resembling cult literature
column13: in the past
column14: present
column15: or future. Who reads this and resonates with it? Who thinks
column16: "Yes
column17: gay sex with boys is what my mind is all about? Oh
column18: and all the better that they're Arabs!" Very few people
column19: the author included. Burroughs himself admits this was difficult to write. This is probably due to the fact that the vignettes portrayed here do not
column20: in fact
column21: represent anything so much as the anarchy resplendent in the author's own mind while he struggled with various addictions. As a case study in heroin and morphine addiction
column22: this may have some merit. As a counterculture commentary on society I find it worthless.  This isn't about my sensibilities being assaulted - far from it. If I can read & enjoy Robbins's linguistic forays into sex with nuns
column23: I can handle just about anything. I'm not offended with flying sperm so much as I am insulted that anyone felt this was worth reading; that I was lured into thinking this was a work of art. It's not.   Sometimes I read books that don't suit me
column24: but I understand why someone would like it. This book falls squarely in the camp where people feel they need to proclaim it genius because they're so confused or intimidated by it. As an Artist (Painter) who buys many art books and counts Jenny Saville as one of his favorite younger painters
column2: I have been eagerly awaiting this books release.  I was also fortunate enough to get the Catalogue for Saville's Territories exhibition
column3: and not I don't want to sell it.  Considering the quality of the Territories and Migrants publications
column4: my expectations for this book were admittedly high.  I also saw both shows in person.  As for this book
column5: Disappointing is an understatement.  Let's start with the obvious
column6: it is incomplete and does not contain any of her earlier work and the text is nothing new
column7: just a collection of older stuff.  Then the reproduction quality is poor
column8: the images are too small
column9: the colors aren't accurate
column10: they're overly contrasting.  This leads me to believe that someone that never saw the actual works ran the images through some Photoshop printing filter and didn't actually compare the printed images to the paintings.  In addition
column11: the layout of the artwork in the book is just plain bad.  Instead of centering the images on the page
column12: they hug the center
column13: which makes them awkward to look at.  For a book publisher
column14: this is unforgivable.  The positive aspects of the book are:  well
column15: there's finally a book on Saville and the photos of her studies
column16: references and studio a well done
column17: in fact there could be more.  They do provide detail shots of her painting
column18: which is mandatory with her work considering the scale.  However
column19: the few positives can't make up for a very poor book overall on an important contemporary artist.  One reviewer said
column20: "Move over Lucian Freud"
column21: I think not.  A comparison cannot be made until Saville is in her 80's
column22: then we'll (well someone will) talk.  While her earlier work is very impressive
column23: I'm becoming concerned about where she is going paint wise.  The earlier work has "character"
column24: the newer work and pieces from the Migrants exhibition seem slick
column25: rushed and overly pretty.  The new work also lacks the conceptual strength of the early work (her weak point anyway).  It seems to me she's becoming a clich of herself.  The best comparison I can think of is the animation style of the early Simpsons or South Park compared to later years.  The rough edges and distinctiveness have disappeared
column26: replaces by standardization and predictability
column27: never a good thing for an artist.  I hope that this phase of Saville's career will pass quickly.  Final Score  4 out of 1

column1: I agree with those in the majority who have reviewed this book.  It was a terribly boring story and hard to follow at times.  I am a huge Minette Walters fan.  In my opinion
column2: she's right up there with Ruth Rendell. The word by word e-mails from one character to another were dreadful.  I found myself skimming over them.  It appeared to me that they were put there to take up page space because they certainly were not there to enrich the story or provide anything of interest.  There wasn't even really a mystery here.  It was obvious what was going on right away.  I did not care for this book one bit.  The two star rating is because I do love this author and one star would just be shameful (although two stars seems generous).

column1: Richard Dawkins is a world-class evolutionary biologist and one of the best popular science writers working today.  His "The Blind Watchmaker" is
column2: I think
column3: the best layman's book on natural selection ever written; I re-read it every few years just to enjoy the clarity of his style.  "A Devil's Chaplain
column4: then, is a book I really wanted to like.  I understood walking out of the bookstore that Chaplain" would not
column5: in the main
column6: be about evolutionary biology.  And I have seen enough examples of scientists -- brilliant within their own areas of expertise -- who write commonplaces or even twaddle when off their home turf.  That caution did not prepare me for the spectacle of Dawkins's plunge into unselfconscious dogmatism and graceless bile in large sections of this book.  Portions of "A Devil's Chaplain" dealing with evolutionary biology are quite good.  Sections dealing with "memes" are less satisfactory.  I actually finished Dawkins's first essay on memes _less_ convinced that they are a viable analog to genes than when I went in.  In particular
column7: Dawkins's  postlog on why science is not a meme was unconvincing
column8: weak argumentation at best
column9: hand-waving at worst.  Dawkins's opinions on social institutions and politics recall William F. Buckley's  quip that it would be preferable to be ruled by citizens drawn randomly from the Boston telephone book than by the members of Harvard's faculty.  Dawkins's disparagement of the concept of trial by jury (in favor of `more rational' trial by judge) misses the point of that institution in a particularly elephantine way.  His viewpoint is elitist in a distinctively cozy
column10: English
column11: university-don manner.  Dawkins seems so nauseated at the thought that some gaggle of dimwitted proles might sit in judgement of _him_ that he is oblivious to the notion that an individual judge -- albeit a credentialed professional and Dr. D's intellectual equal (more or less) -- might treat him unfairly.  And some of the notions Dawkins advances are just loopy.  For instance
column12: at one point he imagines being in the presence of a genetically-engineered approximation of an australopithecene and "tearfully taking her hand in mine" -- as if the hominid in question were an actual australopithecene
column13: not a laboratory-made chimera
column14: and as if the poor creature were capable of understanding his emotion
column15: let alone reciprocating it.  "A Devil's Chaplain" is an instant classic
column16: but not of any sort that Richard Dawkins could have intended.  With it
column17: he joins the list of brilliant specialists who missed their opportunity to leave intact the assumption that they were sages in a broad way
column18: instead of solely in their fields of specialization

 I bought this book, in part because of the glowing reviews others have left for it, and in part out of a general interest in the subject, having read several fictional books which dealt with it. I was completely shocked, however, to find a poorly written, trite piece of crap. Seriously. Now, I'm not claiming to be a great writer myself - I'm sure this review will be ripe with spelling & gramatical errors - but I'm not a professional author, so I shouldn't be held to a strict standard. Mr. Sutton, who claims many academic credentials, certainly couldn't name writing ability" amung them. He regularly reverts to the passive voice
column19: uses academic cliches repeatedly (in one paragraph he mentions the "Hegalian Dialectic" 3 times...)
column20: and puts words he thinks are particularily important in bold
column21: like an elementary school text book. Furthermore
column22: his conclusions are very poorly supported
column23: given the nature of his supposed "research"
column24: and he is prone to refer to evidence which doesn't support his point whatsoever. I have no problem with the idea that skull and bones
column25: and secret societies in general exist; but Mr. Sutton's work doesn't exactly pull it all together or even convince me that our lives and the American government are really puppets of the above mentioned orders. One of Mr. Sutton's first assertions is that he is going to use "Occam's Razor" - that the simplest explenations are usually correct. Fine. But he overlooks the simplest explenation of them all - rich people who go to elite schools help out other rich people. Wealth and power in America (and throughout most of the world) are self-perpetuating. People in power assist others to stay in power. Its not a secret
column26: its sociology. Don't waste your time
column27: - and don't belive the inevitable conclusions that I'm part of the "conspiracy" for speaking ill of this book. I didn't go to any Ivy League school

column1: Consumers should be aware of serious design flaws which exist in Samsung DLP televisions.  Cooling fans and color wheels are highly susceptible to failing.  (As a non-techniocal person I should have no idea what these parts are
column2: but alas
column3: I bought a Samsung DLP)  Expect these to fail within 1-2 years.  Expect to pay approx $400 to replace the color wheel and $200 to replace the colling fan.  That is
column4: if your service technician can find them in stock anywhere.  These parts are commonly in a national backorder because of the very high failure rates.    You should also expect the lamp to fail sooner than advertized.  Many people need to purchase a new lamp between 1-2 years
column5: and some more often than that.  The lamp costs approx $150-$250 depending on your model
column6: but you should be able to replace it yourself without too much difficulty.  This cost will be in addition to replacement costs for the color wheel and colling fan.  Please remember that these maintenance costs are recurring
column7: and you will have to fix them again in another 1-2 years.  While I was very satisfied with the quality and performance of my DLP
column8: my color wheel failed very early.  I called tech support to report a grinding noise
column9: and was told to "turn it off"
column10: wait 15 minutes
column11: and turn it back on like this would fix the problem.  After doing this for a while
column12: the color wheel finally failed
column13: actually shattered!  Now I am out of warranty
column14: and Samsung wants nothing to do with me.  I have even tried ordering the part myself from two different online vendors
column15: and they are both backordered indefinitely!  It has been 6 weeks and they have no estimate for when this part will be available.  Samsung cannot even give me an estimate when the supply of replacement parts is expected to meet demand.  I have had my TV for 18 months
column16: and apparently there is a national epidemic of them breaking at the same time!  I have a 42" Samsung Plasma which is a beautiful set along with a 26" CRT.  Both are wonderful products
column17: but Samsung is selling DLP LEMONS and will not stand behind them.  DLP is a great bargain up front
column18: but a maintenance NIGHTMARE!  You will pay in the long run
column19: and by the long run I mean every 2 years.  If you still want to purchase a DLP television
column20: PLEASE BUY THE EXTENDED WARRANTY!  IT WILL SAVE YOU A TON
column21: BUT YOU WILL STILL HAVE TO WAIT FOR THE CIRCUIT CITY TECH TO FIND PARTS WHICH MAY TAKE MONTHS!    I expect Samsung to abandon their design flaw riddled DLP sector
column22: and focus on their beautiful plasma line.  Expect DLP prices to drop even further
column23: but please...LOOK BEFORE YOU LEAP

column1: "Ready for Anything" is a pointless book full of information and ideas that anyone who went through school should already know. I learned a long time ago to write things down instead of keeping them in my head and I also know that being organized gives me more flexibility and less stress so why would I want to read a book in which Allen writes about basic concepts in a philosophical way. Yeah this book might be good for someone who didn't pick up on these basic skills in Middle school but for me it was a waste of my time which I'm sure Allen would agree is not a good use of my skills.  Do yourself a favor and don't waste your time on this book because maybe then you will open yourself up to more time for "creativity" which is the point of the book in the first place

Almost 2 hours long. A film about filmmaking. A narcissistic view of the movie business. The film is about a film being shot
column2: and ends when this is accomplished. We see what goes on in the daily lives of those involved in the work
column3: from the director (the same Truffaut) to the producer
column4: to the cast
column5: to the stuntman. There's a curious lady
column6: a wife to one of the employees
column7: who sits knitting and watching her husband so he doesn't cheat on her during work. Everybody keeps busy working and flirting chaotically
column8: and the only one who does not mix work and pleasure seems to be the director (and maybe the producer). It's supposed to be funny
column9: and even nostalgic. There are visual references to the great classic directors in film history
column10: to how the film industry has changed... One thing to learn from this story is that fiction plays a role in our lives: it serves as a contrast to the frivolity and emptiness of our real lives.  "Do you think the story of a woman who falls for her father-in-law can still be interesting today?"
column11: asks a reporter to the leading star. That question is quite revealing of what our world has become. Sex and alcohol keep these pitiful troupe working like gasoline keeps a car running. Another important moment is when the knitting lady (mentioned before) gets tired of watching so much promiscuity going around and starts yelling at the whole crew. What role does she play? Is she the typical conservative fun-spoiler? Or is she Truffaut's alter-ego? Hard to say. And that's one reason why this whole film is pointless. It just describes what goes on

column1: Moen's book recounts an intriguing series of personal journeys undertaken during classes at the Monroe Institute (TMI). The classes there build on experiences by its founder Robert Monroe detailed a series of books written over a span of many years. In a sense the Moen chronicle (this is vol 3) picks up where Monroe leaves off using the same kind of annoying jargon. Fortunately there is a glossary to guide the reader. Many other authors have tried to capture the goings-on at Monroe
column2: but Moen seems to have turned it into a career. If you are a current or prospective TMI student
column3: these writings could be the ultimate guide (or puff-piece) to bring a new level of understanding. However
column4: if you are the average reader thinking from the title that you are going to learn something more about the afterlife as depicted by books in the spiritualist tradition
column5: forget it. Science fiction fans would probably find great enjoyment with the work. Moen is an effective writer who maintains a fast-paced description of his experiences
column6: but the jargon-laden pages are a bit much to attract attention from a general audience. His fun-filled episodes with their never-ending sexual overtones are more reminiscent of a teen-ager at Disneyland than a metaphysical explorer pushing to new levels of understanding. The volume is a testament to Moen's amazing astral abilities and his mentoring of TMI students. If you would like a description that is an order of magnitude more useful try the "Life in the world Unseen" series from Anthony Borgia or free afterlife ebooks at spiritwritings.co

column1: "Internal Combustion" by Edwin Black is an entertaining but uneven history about the control of energy with a purported emphasis on the ascendancy of the gasoline-powered automobile. To his credit
column2: Mr. Black has managed a substantive research project that has uncovered a great deal of arcane historic information about the automotive industry. Unfortunately
column3: this preachy book suffers from an acute lack of focus
column4: where it is suspected that the large amounts of extraneous background material was added in an attempt to obscure the book's shortcomings. Indeed
column5: the author ultimately fails to prove his central thesis
column6: thereby casting doubt about the validity of both his research and his conclusions.  Mr. Black opens the book with a scene depicting the burning of Thomas Edison's research laboratories in December
column7: 1914. Mr. Black's conspiracy theory proposes that sinister forces aligned with the gasoline-burning automotive industry may have intentionally destroyed the world's one and only hope to mass-produce an electric car. Unfortunately
column8: Mr. Black provides no evidence to prove this allegation.    Mr. Black attempts to buttress his case by explaining that electric vehicles were once utilized as taxis in New York and other major cities in the late nineteenth century and
column9: therefore
column10: could have and should have been mass marketed to an appreciative public. We are supposed to accept Mr. Black's thesis that success would have been an inevitable and logical outcome despite the severe weight
column11: cost and range limitations of the electric car when compared with the gasoline automobile. In fact
column12: while Thomas Edison and Henry Ford were still tinkering with an electric alternative a full thirteen years after gasoline-powered vehicles had already been in mass production
column13: it is evident to the reader that internal combustion vehicles prevailed because they were affordable
column14: the first to market and could traverse longer distances than electric cars. That all of this was not a good development for people's health and the environment is not in dispute; rather
column15: it is Mr. Black's contention that the white-hatted purveyors of electric vehicles could have prevailed save for the obstructionism of the black-hatted petroleum industry that remains in question.    In the end
column16: what is conspicuously lacking throughout the book is a credible attempt at analyzing and critiquing the history of governmental and popular struggle with the fossil-fuel industry. But instead of scholarship
column17: we have a vainglorious author who is determined to salvage the barren results of two years' worth of study by substituting analysis with a highly questionable work of narrative. The end result is little more than a masquerade of nonfiction; at best
column18: it is a book that might have limited appeal to readers who crave pseudo-historicism at the expense of intellectual rigor
column19: consistency
column20: insight or coherence.

column1: I will admit that I too read this book cover-to-cover and was intrigued by its story. The problem is
column2: I became so engaged that I began doing subsequent research into the field of remote viewing and
column3: appropriately enough
column4: began to "see the truth." Psychic Warrior is a highly fictionalized
column5: exxagerated
column6: self-serving vehicle for its disgraced author to exploit his fleeting brush with the RV program for money.  David Morehouse had the shortest tenure of any of the Army's remote viewers who have gone on to make a living as "experts" on the technique. According to those fellow viewers
column7: most of the "exploits" in RV that Morehouse takes credit for in this book were actually accomplished by other people. The best example is his "Mars expedition
column8: which was in fact conducted by Joe McMoneagle. An actual transcript of Joe's session is available as a bonus with purchase of Skip Atwater's book Captain of My Ship
column9: Master of My Soul" and it more or less proves that Morehouse is trying to take credit for someone else's work. The Psychic Warrior book is full of events and accomplishments that Morehouse tries to take credit for
column10: most of which actually occured when Morehouse wasn't even in the program.  In fact
column11: most of the revered remote viewers (McMoneagle
column12: Ingo Swann
column13: Russell Targ
column14: Paul Smith) seem to consider Morehouse to be the RV community's "odd man out
column15: especially after he was forced out of the Army for having an affair with his enlisted driver's wife among other things. That part of the book is even more suspect; Morehouse continually makes excuses for himself and tries to paint himself as a victim of some sort of government plot as a result of his threat to expose the truth" about RV
column16: instead of taking accountability for his illegal and immoral actions.  But two facts must be considered here: First
column17: the Army itself declassified the program and released mountains of information about it; it is highly doubtful that they would make attempts on the lives of Morehouse's entire family over something they were already planning to open the lid on. Second
column18: practically every other significant member of both the SRI program and the military's program has gone on to write books
column19: author instructional materials and even teach courses in remote viewing
column20: and not a single other one has been "targeted" by higher powers as Morehouse claims to have been.  If anyone out there is interested in reading about remote viewing and its history within both the civilian science sector and the military/government
column21: I would highly recommend that you read Paul Smith's "Reading the Enemy's Mind" instead of Morehouse's fictionalized waste of time. Smith
column22: who acted as unit historian for the Army's program
column23: provides an infinitely more reliable
column24: intelligent and engaging account of the development and implementation of remote viewing. And if you would then be inclined to study the technique yourself
column25: I would suggest you examine Skip Atwater's course at the Monroe Institute in Virginia before plunking down the $1
column26: 000 + to study with Morehouse. After all
column27: Atwater spent years training most of the viewers in a program that Morehouse was kicked out of after only a brief time.  I wouldn't have had such a problem with Psychic Warrior if it had been marketed as a work of fiction. It is a shame that such a perversion of the truth ends up being many people's initial introduction to something as significant to humankind as remote viewing.

column1: It's healthy bear in mind
column2: as Horgan urges
column3: that neuroscience has yet to produce medical or technological breakthroughs on the scale of physics

Horgan's negative claims are not borne out by an honest look at the field.  For example
column10: he professes not to be able to come up with a single solid discovery that neuroscience has made in its history.  Really?  What about the discovery of receptive fields by Kuffler and others
column11: a fundamental fact about sensory and motor neural organization every student learns?  How about functional neural columns in V1 (Hubel & Wiesel) and elsewhere?  The neural correlate of eye movement commands in the superior colliculus (Wurtz
column12: Goldberg et al.)?  And what exactly was the objection to Kandel's groundbreaking work on the molecular basis of memory supposed to be?  Rather
column13: Horgan's methodology is to exploit the modesty and self-effacement of many neuroscientists
column14: who will say `But of course we have no idea how X works' to temper the enthusiasm surrounding their discovery of Y.  But modesty (or jadedness) notwithstanding
column15: no neuroscientist believes that the field has learned nothing important about the brain in the last 100 years
column16: or that important questions haven't been answered definitively.  Horgan also offers a sort of argument from ignorance-if he and his colleagues at Scientific American can't get their heads around Goldman-Rakic's work in an afternoon
column17: it must be beyond human comprehension altogether.  Other interpretations of the situation are possible.  In sum
column18: a grossly misleading book

column1: Clifford is a journalist and he personalizes issues and focuses on details that don't illustrate as much as they trivalize. He wants this to be a book about the ski industry but it is really about Vail with anecdotes about other players thrown in if Clifford thinks they are juicy. He defines the golden years of skiing to be that time when he was in his mid-twenties. He wants to get rid of the big corporations to return to that period. He wants to blame the financial markets for all of the enviornmental and social issues of the rocky mountains. I kind of doubt if ski towns were ever as idyllic as has he would like to remember them. Co-ops and non-public companies can be  just as short-sighted and just as rapacious as public ones.  And even if the resorts drive the economy there are a few other trends and relationships that deserve some blame. The Latino racism / exploitation thing that Clifford describes is less of an issue in California than it is in Colorado
column2: and I  don't think it applies at all in the Northeast or British Colombia. (Somebody obviously washes the dishes and makes up the beds in those resorts
column3: but the issue of undocumented aliens may be a local one.) The water for snowmaking issue is not relevant in BC (or even at Mamoth with their coastal weather patterns) - and I suspect that Hal has glossed over the nuances between the Northeastern resorts (mainly on private land with lots of snowmaking necessary for operation) and the front-range areas (mainly public land and snowmaking  necessary mainly to extend the season.) Water rights have been a contentious issue in the West as long as there have been competing users and at least the snowpack gives up it's runoff in the spring. The top end resorts are clearly not about skiing - duh - but that only applies to the developments in the highest rung and doesn't provide much insight into the industry as a whole.  If you're going to bring up Pellican Butte (which is irrelevant to any of  the organizations he addresses) why not talk about Early Winters where the community - or possibly the outside environmentalists - prevailed? If you're going to talk about Silverton Mountain why not talk about all of the lost ski areas in the same range? There are some interesting debates inherent in this issue - conservation vs. recreation
column4: tourism as an extractive industry
column5: regulation of development
column6: commodification of leisure
column7: - etc. But the resort is not the sport and it isn't even the community and when Clifford wants to blame everything on the impersonal corporate bad guy he ends up sounding like another anti-globalization [supporter]

column1: I received this as a gift a year ago and I like the coffee maker part
column2: the coffee comes out with a good flavor albeit a bit cold but it seems all coffee makers these days make the coffee a little cold. Once you mix in milk or 1/2 and 1/2 it is only lukewarm. The removable tank is nice (you can wash it) but awkward to use if you have the unit under a cabinet. Also the unit has a big footprint so that may be of consideration if your counterspace is limited.   I used to have a Delonghi pump-driven espresso machine that worked great. This one has a steam driven espresso that most coffee connoisseurs will advise against. I now know why. The pressure builds inside the water tank as the espresso brews and after 1/2 a shot the machine just shoots out steam. I've tried different grinds and tamping the coffee really hard (you have to buy a tamper with this one) it still builds too much pressure and it shoots out bitter coffee flavored steam after a short while. Also the markings on the pots peel off pretty quick. Not worth the money unless you get it for cheap on ebay.

column8: turning the magazine into a political direction will probably bring them more sales. I don't think that reading and literary magazines are dead by any means but the format needs to be revamped so that people will want to read it.

column1: I work for a book summary company.  One of the books selected for summary is this book.  When you have the world famous author who made the startling expose on the Watergate scandal and Assistant Managing Editor of Washington Post
column2: write about the eventful hours following the 9/11 attack at the World Trade Center
column3: your expectations are naturally very high.  But Woodward lets you down
column4: as this book leans heavily on transcripts of National Security Council meetings and extended interviews including over 4 hours of interview with George Bush
column5: to reveal the layers of decision making process that followed the cataclysmic incident.  By providing the details of the close-door meetings amongst the key central players
column6: we do get to size up partially on the personality of those involved.  We are privy to the arguments and ideological differences amongst the principal leaders as President Bush
column7: Condoleezza Rice
column8: Colin Powell
column9: Donald Rumsfeld
column10: CIA Director George Tenet
column11: and Deputy Defense Secretary Paul Wolfowitz
column12: forcefully put their weight and power behind their viewpoints and decisions.  We are treated to how the CIA successfully waged an intelligence war against Afghanistan leading to the fall of the Taliban.  Beyond that we get precious little in terms of clear opinion on the dynamics of the decision making or the wisdom behind it.  A mere reportage of the collection of meetings and interviews are best served in a newspaper
column13: and thus could ideally have found its way into Washington Post.  In the publication of a book
column14: we expect a renowned media investigator as Woodward to undertake a more serious study such as on policy matters or the depth of leadership involved or an incisive analysis of personalities and so forth.  This is a rather tame book and hardly adds anything of great value
column15: and much less so to the trailblazing work that Woodward is capable of.

column1: I'd purchased this biography to learn more about a fascinating woman who left an indelible mark on her profession
column2: acting.  But my disappointment was great; this is less a biography than an infatuated paean -- something one might write for a fan club or public relations campaign.  Though Mr. Spoto and his crew of researchers obviously undertook considerable investigation into Bergman's life
column3: Mr. Spoto failed to complete the last -- and most important -- task of a biographer:  a critical analysis of his subject.  Instead
column4: throughout the book
column5: Mr. Spoto repeatedly (and I emphasize "repeatedly") flogs readers with superlatives about Bergman's acting
column6: looks
column7: intelligence
column8: strength
column9: spirit
column10: wisdom
column11: and character.  Why the Pope hasn't yet canonized this woman
column12: based on Mr. Spoto's writings
column13: is beyond me -- perhaps it is only because she was not Catholic.  I do hope that someday another biographer -- say
column14: someone with the talents of Edward Tytell (biographer of Ezra Pound) or Noel Riley Fitch (biographer of Sylvia Beach and Julia Child) -- might undertake the task of penning a more informative
column15: insightful biography of Bergman.  The woman certainly deserves this.

column1: Let's see
column2: besides our protagonist being a nominal Milton scholar (though like all the other literary lights cited in this book
column3: there is no real connexion with any of Milton's works in this book)
column4: we have the following names dropped
column5: seemingly gratuitously throughout this opus: James Joyce (5 times)
column6: Yeats (5 times)
column7: Thoreau (3 times)
column8: Bertrand Russell (2 times)
column9: Ezra Pound (2 times)
column10: Wordsworth
column11: Emily Dickinson (at least 3)
column12: Matthew Arnold
column13: Jack London....and I stopped counting after that.  Come now
column14: does anyone save a literary groupie really appreciate all this display of superficial literary knowledge? Is it really intrinsic to the story? ---Here: My favourite example of the inanity of these quasi-literary speculations by Ray-" `The drop that wrestles in the sea/Forgets her own locality' was from Emily Dickinson
column15: a poet he hadn't read attentively enough
column16: since clearly she had something to say to him.".....And
column17: well
column18: what is it?  Never mind
column19: no time for serious pondering.  It's on to more Yeats among others before the paragraph ends (p.351).  - The one exception to all this name dropping is Ray's recital of Matthew Arnold's "Dover Beach." to Morel.  But
column20: as is commonplace
column21: the exception proves the rule here. - I could go on about how disappointing the meretricious scholarship is in this work: Is Morel serious about citing Matthew 15:24 as proof that Jesus came only for the Jews?  Is Rush?  Anyone who has read the whole chapter knows that this is where Jesus turns to the Gentiles and heals the Canaanite's daughter because the Jews have rejected him.  Is Rush trying to show that Morel's idealism about a non-Christian Africa is superficial and misplaced?  Or is Rush simply showboating himself---I very much fear that it's the latter.  2 Stars for the few poignant passages on conjugal love.  But
column22: in the end
column23: I would have come away much more enriched had I spent the time reading actual literature: Joyce
column24: Yeats
column25: Wordsworth
column26: Dickinson........Milton

column1: This is the first time I delved into the HellRaiser series
column2: and I have to admit
column3: I kind of regret it. The film opens with a collage of disturbing images
column4: I guess to get my attention
column5: but there is no real reason for them to be there. From there the film falls into a freefall where it jumps from one messed up scene to the next. It all looks perfectly twisted
column6: but who really cares. Clive Barker
column7: as he did in "Night Breed
column8: shows his taste for creative costumes and set designs. Of course they are all very self-indulgent, but beautiful nonetheless in their own little way. Had this film showed up at a modern art museum I would have labeled it pretentious. But since it showed up in movie theaters I have no choice but to label it crap.  I would love to describe the plot to you, but it didn't make a ton of sense to me. Kirsty (Ashley Laurence) is in a mental hospital and is convinced that her dad is calling out to her from inside hell, and thus she must go save him. Meanwhile her evil step-mom (and speaking from experience they are all evil) is reemerging from hell with the distinct disadvantage of not having any skin. Upon her return she uses her bloody pulp of a body to engage in a sexual act with another evil doer. I'm sure that gets laughs every time from the children who are watching, but to me it was silly and unnecessary. She goes on a quest for skin which goes off without a hitch, and from there a battle ensues between Kirsty and her step-mom over the soul of a little girl named Tiffany (or so everybody calls her). The whole point seems to be that our minds make up our own personal hells, and that is an idea I can get on board with. One overview shot of hell has it looking strikingly similar to an M.C. Escher print. With dead ends and trap doors and boogeymen we all travel through the labyrinth of our mind on a daily basis. But I cannot get on board with this film. It is sensational for the sake of sensationalism, which is fine with me, but not when it is mixed with a brain dead plot. What do I, or anybody for that matter, get from watching a man carve himself up with a knife? I guess that at least it is not soft like modern horror movies, but this one does not earn its gore.  For those of you who demand nothing out of your movies other than the experience of a bad dream where nothing makes sense then this is your film. For the rest of you this is failed storytelling of the highest degree. I still have HellRaiser" on my shelf to watch and I must say it won't be hard for that one to top this mess. I may never understand why people think atmosphere is enough to create a scary movie. It is the major flaw of this film and Japanese Horror in general
column9: but I want a story to go with my scares. What this one is selling is a chance to be grossed out of your mind or bored stiff. . .or both. I hated this movie
column10: and no I don't care how realistic it looked when the characters were peeling the skin off of their faces. *1/2

column2: while U.S. policy was to retain sactions until regime change
column3: regardless of Iraq's armament.  In addition
column4: there were also problems with poor coordination between the CIA and FBI.  The key "bottom line" is that this Machiavellian U.S. strategy to defeat arms inspection probably led to the U.S. and G.B. being convinced in 2003 that Saddam had WMD when he actually had none
column5: and thereby an unnecessary war.  As for Scott Ritter

column7: "Iraq Confidential" should have only been an article - not nearly 300 pages

column1: It sure is easy for pundits and commentators to get book deals these days
column2: when you can sell a tirade of personal opinions and second guessing as in-depth political analysis. Joe Klein has the added distinction of criticizing other people for doing exactly what he does
column3: and of complaining about political and media trends from which he benefits directly. Klein has a reasonable basic point here about modern lowest-common-denominator politicking
column4: in which image and sloganeering are seen as more important than knowledge and leadership. But Klein
column5: in a display of mind-boggling myopia
column6: can't even see that this exact same phenomenon allows weak and opinionated books like this to qualify as serious political analysis.  Granted
column7: this book gets off to a pretty good start
column8: with a prologue describing a 1968 campaign speech by Robert F. Kennedy
column9: in which RFK spoke intelligently and respectfully to an African American crowd just hours after the Martin Luther King assassination. Klein laments the total disappearance of RFK-style dignity in modern American politics
column10: and vows to analyze what has gone wrong and how modern campaigns can be made intelligent again. But this potential focus promptly disappears without a trace after the prologue. What follows is actually a history of the influence of villainous pollsters and consultants in recent presidential campaigns. Klein usefully criticizes the sappy image experts and number crunchers first
column11: before spending much more time second guessing
column12: with 20-20 hindsight
column13: the losses of unsuccessful candidates.  The unintentional irony of Klein's punditry is unstoppable throughout the book. He complains about everyone else's unyielding ideology while simultaneously
column14: and unilaterally
column15: pronouncing certain positions
column16: such as U.S. military superiority
column17: as "correct" or "unassailable." Klein laments how over-hyped pollsters have made it a liability for politicians to appear realistically human
column18: but then declares that certain presidential candidates (Democrats in general and Al Gore in particular) lost because they didn't appear - you guessed it - realistically human. In another contradiction
column19: Klein forgives George W. Bush for lacking issue-specific knowledge
column20: but later slams Howard Dean for the exact same thing. Klein also fancies himself a nonpartisan because he can criticize and disagree with both Republicans and Democrats
column21: but this is merely an equal-opportunity mutation of the shallow punditry that he disdains from everyone else in his field. Even in these ridiculous political times
column22: it's stupefying how much this book contributes to
column23: and benefits from
column24: the very problems it claims to debunk. But that's what passes for "analysis" these days. [~doomsdayer520~]

column1: Burleigh's political agenda
column2: made so obvious throughout this long and otherwise useful book
column3: has to my knowledge never been mentioned by a single reviewer.  The author bludgeons the reader with his unoriginal contention that the Soviets were as murderous as the Nazis (or so very close the difference hardly matters)
column4: and he turns to this comparison at every possible juncture
column5: including roads that do not meet.  One can hardly read two pages without a reference to the author's obsession. The book would have better been entitled
column6: "The Soviet Union and Nazi Germany: A New Comparison
column7: and that would be fine, but that's not the title I bought and wasn't the one I intended to read.  Not one serious reviewer mentions Burleigh's tendency to revel in his supposed political incorrectness, as if the year is 1965 and droves of lefties park their parkas in cafes, praising Stalin and railing against the bourgeoisie.  Obviously, someone has failed to inform Burleigh that his much beloved political incorrectness has become politically correct, his almost giddy pleasure in playing the role of a conservative rebel" reminiscent of Bob Roberts in the Tim Robbins' film and rather ridiculous given the current political climate.  In several interviews
column8: Burleigh rails against the continued interest in Nazism as a kind of pornography generated by
column9: of course

column11: which seems to have taken a vacation on the day it published his 800+ page tome about...Nazism. Burleigh's account of Nazi terror

column13: comes as close to his own definition of pornography as anything I can imagine
column14: with the only possible exception being a person -- and the Internet suggests fetishists exist for nearly everything in the universe -- addicted to concentration camp footage. column23:
only he seems to realize this would be a little too politically incorrect even for his tastes.  In summary, five stars for the information, one star for the interpretation. column1: Overall
column2: I found this episode in the life and adventures of Randy Komisar to be interesting
column3: but not groundbreaking.  Though certainly filled with some valuable insights
column4: there was something more to be desired.  There was still a lot to learn
column5: however
column6: the most important being the general observations from a real-life perspective on what it takes to enjoy life in the entrepreneurial world.      The work itself was often scattered and forced.  There was no real continuity between the flashbacks
column7: often sounding as if Mr. Komisar decided to insert various triumphs in his life whenever he felt like it.  Furthermore
column8: I found the characters of Lenny and Allison to be more symbolic than human.  They were not actual individuals
column9: but prompts put in by Komisar to respond to the questions he wanted answered.  In his interactions with them
column10: Komisar walked an unhealthy line between humility and arrogance
column11: presenting himself as a sort of low-key person who thinks outside the box
column12: yet is always right on everything and draws reverence from those around him.  At times
column13: I wondered whether this book was more of a teaching tool or a testament to his own greatness.      I found his main message to be useful
column14: but somewhat hypocritical.  His criticism of the "work first and then retire" philosophy struck especially close to home
column15: as that is one I have often embraced.  I paid close attention to his words and was partially persuaded.  I think he is downright contradictory
column16: however
column17: when he tries to use his own life as an example of how a business does better when fueled by complete passion and the expectation of it being one's life's work.  There were many times when I felt like screaming out
column18: "Mr. Komisar
column19: practice what you preach!"  Furthermore
column20: I can think of so many ways that his theory is wrong.  Sometimes
column21: the best businessman is one who has passion for what he/she is doing
column22: but also has the ability to be objective and analyze the situation with an objective business savvy.  When he and his mentor Campbell (of Columbia fame!) ran GO to the ground
column23: sticking with it through its crash landing
column24: he writes as if that is a good thing.  That is fine when you have enough money to absorb that kind of failure
column25: but most beginning entrepreneurs do not.  Komisar got where he is because of the strategy he condemns.      The other major problem with the book is the premise of funerals.com.  I found it to be a very poor example
column26: as it unjustly generalized the funeral market.  While I am sure there are funeral homes who take advantage of people in their vulnerable
column27: grieving states
column28: I cannot think of anything less comforting than making arrangements over a computer instead of with people.  The character of Allison in representing the opposite extreme really represented absurdity.  If she were so feeling and caring
column29: why not establish a not-for-profit website for grieving families?  I was never convinced that they were after anything but money
column30: and the only evidence that their purpose was primarily moral was Komisar merely claiming it.  If this had been some kind of technological advancement in medicine
column31: for instance
column32: then I could have understood the enduring desire to save lives while also profiting.  The funeral example
column33: however
column34: is weak at best
column35: and so is the pathetic Celestine Prophecy/Richest Man in Babylon rip-off with the riddle.      The strength of the book is in Komisar's thoughts about achieving happiness in life rather than about success in business.  Unlike the other characters
column36: I was able to connect with Komisar as a human being
column37: experimenting with different companies and developing his own tastes.  I gained a lot from reading his experiences
column38: even if they were disjointed
column39: and while I may have disagreed with him on some points
column40: I learned from them.  I am glad I read the book
column41: found it useful
column42: but would hardly call it a masterpiece.

column1: I bought this book primarily for information regarding accounting and general ledger systems. I read all the great reviews here and thought this would be a great book.  I am very disappointed.  The entire section on accounting is only 40 pages and contains only a cursory overview of accounting systems and structures. They include a CD with the book which is supposed to contain actual SQL data structures but you have to pay them $350.00 to unlock the CD.  Given the depth of the book I would be reluctant to risk paying them that much for simple data structures which you can easily find elsewhere on the web for free.  In all honesty I have not studied this book fully but in my opinion it was a waste of money and I will try to return it to Amazon.

column1: False Doctines from the pit of hell
Years ago
column2: the trainer of my 3-months old coonhound recommended staying away from this book
column3: describing it as "the best way to get your dog to be afraid of you and mess up your relationship forever!".  But I wanted to read it
column4: to know what it was all about... I cannot tell you how many times I was fuming realizing how ignorantly these Monks approach dogs' psychology and the physical and psychological violence they use. The temptation of throwing that piece of junk out the window was strong
column5: but I read it through to make sure I could talk about it as bad as I can with the knowledge of its contents. I am saddened to find out that they are still out there... This is the training philosophy for frustrated humans that need to dominate to compensate their own insecurities.  Meanwhile I am a trainer myself and I support a more constructive approach to dog training based on positive reinforcement.  If you know nothing about dogs' psychology
column6: and want to learn more from "The Voice" in dog behavior I suggest "The Other End of the Leash" by Patricia McConnell or "Culture Clash"  by Jean Donaldson or "The Power of Positive Dog Training" by Pat Miller. If you would like to become a benevolent leader of the pack without imposing yourself to your dog with violence or fear
column7: I suggest "How to be the Leader of the Pack...And have Your Dog Love You for It" ("How to" booklets from Dog's Best Friend) by Patricia B. McConnell. All these books are written by professionals that have been working with dogs and studying dogs' behaviors
column8: but they are very entertaining and easy to read and comprehend. Patricia McConnell also wrote a number of other books addressing specific behavioral issues.

column1: THREE VIEWS ON EASTERN ORTHODOXY AND EVANGELICALISM is one of Zondervan's "Counterpoint" books
column2: where theological issues are debated by all sides of the issue. Here the "Yes" position is taken by Bradley Nassif (Orthodox)
column3: the "No" position is taken by Michael Horton (evangelical) and Vladimir Berzonsky (Orthodox)
column4: and finally a "Maybe" position is argued by George Hancock-Stefan (evangelical) and Edward Rommen (Orthodox). Each of the participants makes an argument
column5: is rebutted by the others
column6: and then offers final words. As one might guess
column7: the Orthodox argue that their churches have been "evangelical" in a sense all along and one merely needs to stress those facets of their own tradition. The Evangelical commentators argue against Orthodox from several viewpoints. For Mr Horton
column8: Orthodox's view of justification
column9: which he sees as nebulous
column10: is a major problem. Mr Hancock-Stefan
column11: though he argues "Maybe"
column12: says that the traditions aren't really compatible at all from what he sees as a tradition of church and state oppression of evangelicals
column13: and suggests that the Orthodox should just cross to the other side.  As an Orthodox Christian
column14: I was unhappy with the book. For one
column15: it is simply unwise for the Orthodox to approach the evangelicals at all in debate. The inroads that evangelicals have made into Orthodox countries such as Romania have resulted in serious damage to local spiritual and cultural life
column16: and Orthodox synods (such as those of Iasi and Jerusalem) have repeatedly condemned them in no uncertain terms. But beyond that
column17: the biggest problem with this debate is that the editors did not set one specific definition of evangelicalism to work with. The EO commentators write in response to that non-confessional evangelicalism that has become mainstream over the last century
column18: which doesn't even look back to the early Protestant reformers
column19: let alone the Church Fathers. However
column20: Michael Horton
column21: writing from a Reformed perspective
column22: answers every critique of this evangelicalism by proclaiming how the Reformed churches are different
column23: how they look back to Calvin
column24: and how Calvin looked back to the early Fathers. Mr Horton seems to have entered the discussion with the assumption that his partners in debate would be speaking to him of his own tradition. A second problem is that the evangelical commentators don't really seem to get Orthodoxy at all. That's only to be expected
column25: since they happily remain evangelicals
column26: but it makes their entire treatment of Orthodoxy very frustrating to read. The insistence by evangelicals that the Orthodox Church does not stress a personal relationship with Christ is pure slander
column27: for the importance of the so-called "Jesus prayer" is known even by the least theologically educated Orthodox layman. Mr Horton seems to think that agreements in doctrine between the Reformed tradition and Orthodoxy actually amount to something
column28: but as the Reformed tradition simply lacks the continuity back to the day of Pentecost that the Orthodox Church can claim
column29: it's all quite meaningless to pile up similarities
