column1: I encountered this wildly overpraised critical study in college. I've should have known I was getting into trouble just by the stupid title. Hoffman's attempts at humor are lame (Camille Paglia is far more livlier  and insightful on Poe in her book "Sexual Personae")and his  insights pitiful (Paul Coates
column2: in "The Realist Fantasy"
column3: gives a  much more subtle reading of Poe's "William Wilson" in just three  paragraphs than Hoffman is able to accomplish). What really undermines the  whole book is Hoffman's complete ignorance of fantastic literature which I  think would be essential to doing a critical study of Poe. Only passing  mention is made of E.T.A. Hoffmann
column4: a major influence on Poe (and among  other great writers). Consequently the influence of Hoffmann's doppelganger  tales (such as "The Double" and "Devil's Elixirs") on  Poe's doppelganger tales ("William Wilson" and "The Black  Cat" among other tales)and their influence on such short story writers  as Borges
column5: Paul Bowles
column6: and Julio Cortazar
column7: is not mentioned because Daniel  Hoffman is ignorant of it all and the whole genre. And his conclusion that  Poe only wrote "pure" tales devoid of any inner meaning is pure  bunk and pure laziness on Hoffman's part. To any unfortunate reader or  student who picks up Hoffman's book expecting any critical acumen be  warned: this book isn't it. Two other critical studies (David Ketterer
column8: J.  Gerald Kennedy) are far better

Coltman gives his work credibility by freely admitting two important truths: Castro enjoys the warm support of a majority of the Cuban people
column2: and Guevara and Castro were not at daggers drawn
column3: but remained comrades-in-arms to the very end of Guevara's life. But with every political event and turning-point in the revolution that he describes
column4: Coltman systematically distorts or omits the impact of popular mobilization by the Cuban people. He leaves out the milllions who marched in favour of socialism during the Mariel boat lifts in 1980. He says nothing of the hundreds of thousands who poured into voluntary work brigades during the fight against bureaucracy and stagnation in the late 1980s -- under the leadership of the Cuban Communist Party. He insists on seeing the revolution as the work of one talented megalomaniac
column5: leaving out the facts in order to bolster this view. In 1960
column6: for example
column7: the Cuban delegation to the UN in New York was greeted by enthusiastic crowds in Harlem when Malcolm X arranged for the Cubans to stay at Harlem's Hotel Theresa. The delegation had been subject to politically-motivated and racist harrassment in their Manhattan hotel. Coltman portrays the incident as a shameful foray into the realm of prostitutes and shabby digs. Completely missing the point. As does his whole book

column1: In taiji circles (no pun intended) it's common knowledge that Cheng taught select students a set of nei gong exercises that he found invaluable for taiji and even calligraphy.  William C.C. Chen mentions receiving this training from Cheng in his book about taiji's body mechanics
column2: and there was a group of Malaysian students (some of whom still teach) who got this training.  Cheng didn't teach any of his American students this all-important nei gong (internal work) that is an essential part of taiji.  He was known rarely to discuss it.  Cheng was very secretive and he usually taught only the hand form.  The hand form without the nei gong is really only half an art (though some would say the nei gong is in the form).  Lowenthal learned the form and push hands
column3: and had a great time
column4: and his enthusiasm for Cheng comes through
column5: as does much of Cheng's personality
column6: which was wise
column7: mischievous
column8: and cultured.  So if you want to read a series of anecdotes
column9: which is what the book contains
column10: it's defintely worth buying--particularly if you're a Ching devotee.  But don't expect instruction.  It's not a textbook or manual
column11: but a memoir.

column1: When I was given this book by a guy friend
column2: I thought
column3: why am I getting a book from a Jackie Collins type writer? I had heard of some of Sydney Sheldon novels and most of them seem like JC or Danielle Steel like potboilers that appealed to housewives. but I gave it a chance and I finished it two days later.   The book revolves around Tracey Whitley (as referred to as TW in the rest of the review)
column4: a well to do computer programmer who is engaged to a wealthy banker. However
column5: due to the death of her mother a series of unfortunate events leads her to jail to attempted murder. She was setup.   The book then follows her in jail and then her release and revenge to those who put her there. The last part of the book leads to her new life as a Master Thief and romance of a roguish competitor.   The writing style of Sydney Sheldon is not unlike that of a soap opera. He provides you enough twists and turns to keep you interested
column6: but ultimately his books are like Chinese Food. You consume it and then forget it. It is not because the book is badly written
column7: but because the characters have major flaws.   The main flow of TW is the fact that she is given a cloak of invincibility. Everything she does is perfect
column8: there is literally no suspense later on in the book when she goes to Europe of her getting caught. Her antagonists are idiots
column9: the mafia are clowns and the genius tracking her is lame (and of course crazy). When she lives in a world of cartoonish badguys
column10: of course
column11: she'll come out on top.   Another problem is believability. If anyone thinks that this plot is even remotely possible
column12: they need to get their head examined. TW goes from being a meek
column13: young girl to a Master Thief who easily robs the Prado Museum
column14: the Diamond Exchange in Amsterdam
column15: tricks mobsters and master chess players at their game in less than 2 years. Simply ridiculous.   Associated with the above problem is that Sidney Sheldon does not respect the robbery crimes. They are given like 15 pages each and there is no detail to any of them. Some of them have interesting twists (like how she tricks a emerald dealer in London)
column16: but the Prado robbery
column17: pure fantasy.   So maybe that is what Sheldon is getting at all along. He is not a technical writer
column18: he is all about the Female Fantasy (meek
column19: proper woman blossoming into a strong
column20: sophisticated Master Thief who gets the finer things in life and the bad boy-whom she converts). In that case the book works
column21: but from a realism stance
column22: it is a wash....Rating: C

column1: After some investigative reporting by the media
column2: it was discovered that this alleged "true story" of a Holocaust survivor was anything but. The facts? Binjamin Wilkomirski is actually Swiss-born Bruno Grosjean Doessekker
column3: and his experience was about as real as that of the supposed "fellow survivor" who corroborated his story
column4: Laura Grabowski.  How did Grabowski play an indirect role in unmasking the author? She claimed to be an orphan who suffered torture at the hands of Nazi war criminal Josef Mengele and was later adopted by an American couple
column5: only to have these stories be exposed as equally untrue (her childhood photos show a happy
column6: healthy American girl w/not even hints of the emaciated sate commonly associated w/those who spent time in concentration camps). Additionally
column7: she was revealed to actually be Lauren Stratford
column8: author of the equally fictitious-but-presented-as-a-true-story "Satan's Underground"
column9: which detailed her alleged involvement in Satanism and the sexual abuse she endured from the time she was a young girl (something she'd also had a history of lying about since her late teens); as it turns out
column10: "Grabowski" was actually the surname of her maternal grandparents.  Don't the Wilkomirskis and Grabowskis of this world realize that their exploitation of one of the most despicable events in history is not only self-indulgent and unbelievably selfish
column11: but giving credibility to those misguided Holocaust-denying racist groups? Such lies will allow these scumbags to convince the lesser-informed folk out there that the attempted extermination of an entire race was also nothing but lies
column12: which I'm sure never occured to these self-indulgent storytellers as they proceeded to betray countless REAL survivors

column3: it might have been much easier to understand.  I did enjoy the beginning of the book where Kitty goes into detail about the beginning of Hawkings life but I feel like it was just an overview of how he became who he is today. I would not recommend this book
column4: instead I would recommend A Brief History In Time because it is much easier to understand because it has great illustrations and is not so mathematical

column1: Tao Teh Ching is a monumental work.  Unlike other religious texts
column2: the Tao Teh Ching is barely 5000 letters spread over 81 single-page poetic passages.  You can probably read thru it in a couple hours or less.  But for the serious reader
column3: it can take a lifetime of study and contemplation.  In ancient times
column4: scholars in China and Korea really did spend a lifetime on this one text
column5: not only sudying
column6: but transcribing it
column7: discussing it
column8: and abiding by its tenets in their daily lives.  I've myself pored over it many times in Chinese
column9: Korean and now English
column10: and every time I read it I cannot but be amazed by the wisdom of Lao Tse (or
column11: as some allege
column12: the group of people who contributed to this text).  The problem with English
column13: or I suppose any language not associated with Chinese
column14: is that it is almost impossible to translate Tao Teh Ching with sufficient coherency.  Chinese words are each and all very efficient
column15: in that virtually every single "letter" is replete with meaning.  Therefore
column16: whereas the Chinese may use 10 words to describe something
column17: English might require 10 times that words to adequately translate the meaning.  For example
column18: in the second passage
column19: third stanza
column20: the translated text says
column21: "therefore
column22: the Sage manages his affairs without Ado."  What does "without Ado" mean?  In chinese this is stated in two letters as "Mu Wi" - non-action.  It does not mean to sit back and not participate or instigate any activity.  Rather
column23: "Mu Wi" means doing things in a very natural
column24: spontaneous way that is not forced
column25: does not create conflict and has no secular motives.  As there are no secular motives behind the action
column26: it is as if the Sage does not "act" in the way other poeple act.  His actions are like breathing
column27: and almsot imperceptible; thus it is as if he does not act.  Concepts like "Mu Wi" and "Mu Ji" - non-knowledge - abound in Tao Teh Ching.  These cannot simply be translated away with a couple english words.  In short
column28: a Tao Teh Ching ranslation requires pages and pages of footnotes to accurately reflect the rich meaning behind every passage.  Moreover
column29: many passages can be read in more than one way.  In fact
column30: different translations sometimes say radically different things about the same passage precisely because of this ambiguity.  Any serious translation of Tao Teh Ching should point these out.  Tao Teh Ching is very concise
column31: and written in a poetic style.  But unless you are versed in ancient Chinese language and tomes
column32: you should really consult the literally thousands of guides that scholars wrote over the years to help you read thru the text.  Tao Teh Ching is not some kind of Buddhist sutra that you can just recite over and over without knowing what it means.  It is deeply profound and rich with hidden subtexts.  In China and Korea many of these guides - some of them more than a thousand years old - still survive.  I've yet to find an enligsh guide.  But I am sure they exist.  PLease find them; refrain from reading the translation by itself
column33: for most times all you will see are a jumble of meaningless words

column8: left me entirely cold - this book hit the airport trash can the minute I debarked

column1: INVOLVEMENT AFTER 11 NOVEMBER 1975 After independence
column2: Cuban forces and an unlimited number of Russian armamaents streamed into Angola and completely took over the military function from MPLA. FOXBAT
column3: strengthened by ZULU
column4: had to contend with heavy 122mm fire on 13 November 1975
column5: after which this battle group also requested artillery from the RSA. While the build-up of Cuban forces took place mainly in the Quibala area
column6: the South African supported Unita and FNLA concentrated on the retention of their traditional areas of influence. Action in which these forces were concerned took place mainly in no-man's land between Quibala and Santa Comba. The need to hold the territory resulted in an escalation of South African involvement and the creation of additional battle groups to such an extent that the South African involvement just before withdrawal stood at just under 2000 men (logistics element included). As a counter- move to the Cuban build-up and especially to the 122mm rocket launchers
column7: 140mm guns were brought into the struggle. This caused chaos among the Cuban ranks. The following events are exceptional:   Bridge 14 To deny the Cuban forces access to the anti-communist line of defence
column8: the Battle of Bridge 14 took place on 9 December 1975 in the Catofe area. During this battle
column9: the battle group FOXBAT dealt the Cubans a shattering blow. FOXBAT comprised 3 FNLA/Unita companies
column10: a company of South African infantry and an armoured car squadron
column11: supported by eight 140mm and four 38mm guns
column12: a platoon of mortars and an engineer element
column13: all South Africans. The Cuban/MPLA force consisted of a battalion of Cubans
column14: an MPLA battalion and a mixed supporting battalion with 122mm rocket launchers
column15: artillery and mortar support. The battle raged from 9 December 1975 to 12 December 1975 and yielded the following results:  i. 200 Cubans dead  ii. 200 MPLA dead  iii.10 x 76mm guns seized  iv. 22 x 122mm mortars seized  v. 4 x 122mm rocket launchers destroyed  vi. 1 x 122mm rocket launcher seized  vii. 4 South Africans dead    Occupation of the Salazar Bridge A newly appointed battle group
column16: known as ORANGE
column17: comprising a Unita battalion
column18: an armoured car squadron
column19: a company of South African infantry and artillery occupied the Salazar Bridge over the Cuanza River
column20: north of Mussende
column21: the northern border of the Unita area
column22: on 12 December 1975.  Apparently the South Africans lost air superiority. Below are records of South African/Cuban air engagements. On 6 November 1981 then-Major Johan Rankin of the South African Air Force (SAAF) shot down a MiG-21MF (the SAAF identified it as a "MiG-21Bis")
column23: flown by Teniente Danacio Valdes
column24: over Angola with 30mm gunfire while flying a Mirage F-1CZ. It was the SAAF's first victory in air-to-air combat since Korea. Almost a year later on 5 October 1982
column25: the second aerial combat of the war took place. The duo formed by Tenientes Raciel Marrero Rodriguez and Gilberto Ortiz Perez
column26: clashed with a couple of Mirage F1s
column27: again under the leadership of Johan Rankin; Marrero's MiG-21 was lightly damaged by the 30mm gunfire. The MiGs broke contact and returned to their base in Lubango
column28: without encountering any further problems. The South Africans however
column29: declared that Rankin had shot down one of the MiG-21s and that the other had crashed after being damaged
column30: two supposed MiG loses that never took place. The only recorded aerial victory for the Cuban MiG-21s occurred on 3 April 1986 when a pair of MiG-21MFs intercepted two C-130s reportedly carrying cargo to UNITA. They shot down one and the other escaped seriously damaged. According to South Africa (and the International Air Transport Association) they actually shot down a civilian C-130 registered to the Angolan government airline.  The best-documented loss of a Cuban-flown MiG-21 over Angola was on 28 October 1987 when an armed two-seater MiG-21UM was downed by ground fire near Luvuei. The two crewmembers successfully ejected and were captured by UNITA

column1: Being a huge fan of Golden Age mystery fiction and also an admirer of Gypsy Rose Lee

column3: which follows the book fairly closely and which I thorougly enjoy.  However
column4: although Gypsy Rose Lee "stars" in the story which involves murders among the striptease acts in an Opera House
column5: the writing is rather uninvolving and I who read voraciously had trouble staying interested.  I also confess to being rather annoyed at the petty squabbling between the women which fails to capture the friendships that also develop between women.  In fact
column6: the characterizations remain on an extremely superficial level and the few colorful instances (almost "pre-code" sort of moments) do not rescue the story or make it any more compelling.  I found myself bored and wanting to read something else.  It's a pity
column7: because I truly did want to like it and the premise was promising.  My conclusion:  Gypsy Rose Lee was a very beautiful woman and I imagine a powerful and provocative performer with some class to boot
column8: but she is not a great writer by any stretch of the imagination.  Being a great performer or leading a colorful life does not necessarily mean that you can write; writing is a whole other art form and too many people think it requires no particular skill since one is not required to do eye-high kicks or hit high notes.  They're absolutely wrong
column9: as misfires such as this demonstrate (although I've read far worse).    A disappointment
column10: but may fill the bill for someone looking for a light read.  To use an apt cliche:  mediocre fare.

Between the two of them all of the hostages get out a live and they hit off a good friendship.  	Then Kate starts to become a target

I liked almost everything part of this book because it was a mix of books that I like. The only part that I didn't like about it was that is some places it was dragged on a bit too long.  	I would recremend this book to any body who likes novels of suspense and people over coming odds and ending up at the top.

column1: I took Just Enough Chinese with me to China in October 2001 but never used it because I found its phonetics to be faulty.  For example
column2: the first phrase to learn is Xiexie
column3: which means thank you.  This book would have you say "Sie-sie
column4: by which I guess it means See-see."  However
column5: "ie" in pinyin spelling is said like the "e" in "yes."  Furthermore
column6: the pinyin "x" is much closer to our "sh" than it is to "s
column7: so nothing about the pronunciation offered is sufficiently accurate.  Our tour guide in China said that see-see" is the Chinese equivalent of what we euphemistically call "tinkle" (urination by a small child).  Is that what you want to say instead of thank you

Since the end of the Cold War
column2: writers and political commentators have suggested that we have entered a new war - a war brought on by the "clash of civilizations". The theory
column3: as told by writers such as Samuel Huntington and Bernard Lewis
column4: amongst others
column5: suggests that "the west" is at war with Islam and that this global divide will replace the earlier Cold War acrimony. Not for any particular reason or circumstance is this war being waged against us
column6: they suggest
column7: but merely because of its violent nature and hatred of western civilization. It is the very essence of Islam

column10: CNN
column11: and most newspapers
column12: this thesis has been regularly used by the powerful to justify wars. The U.S. used it to justify the war with Iraq and Afghanistan; Serbs and Croatians used it to justify ethnic cleansing of Bosnian and Kosovar Muslims; and it is used by Israel to justify their "war" with Palestinians.    The Clash of Civilization rhetoric suggests that the world will always be at war. As opposed to the Cold War with the Soviet Union (a country only in existence for less than a century)
column13: Islam is an old religion spread  throughout the world. The framework of the Cold war between the Communist "east" and the capitalist "west" did prove useful in making this theory. The new war is between the rational
column14: democratic
column15: secular
column16: and tolerant "west" and the irrational
column17: fundamentalist
column18: and violent "east". Orwell could have predicted this well: the new enemy created on the morning after the old enemies fell. It almost seems that for the "west"  to feel at home with itself
column19: it needs to be at constant war with some "other". Perhaps it provides some guidance to what we are and what we are not - we are simply not the "other". Perhaps Chomsky and others who have suggested that a major reason that states fight wars is for domestic reasons and for the disciplining of a nation's own population are right.     Not according to the "clash theorists" like Bernard Lewis
column20: who claim that the clash will continue as long as Islam exists. He believes that the radical Islamic militants are not deviants from Islam
column21: but actually have a more correct view of it. They will therefore likely become more influential over the years. But if such a clash really existed

column24: be it with Iraq (during and after the Iraq-Iran wars)
column25: the Saudi Monarchy
column26: or the Afghani Mujahadeen.     Perhaps this theory falls within the entire framework of colonialism. Western colonial nations conquered the world and forced its non-western inhabitants to submit to their authority. It was believed and advocated that colonialism would help these "backward" people in the long run to become just like the colonists. Beyond the arrogance of the idea
column27: colonialism developed sophisticated systems of slavery and servitude that sought to extract valuable natural resources from these areas for the sole benefit of their the colonizers own nations. column29: repressive
column30: soulless West and the just
column31: truthful
column32: and moral center of Islam. Speaking to this subject
column33: writers Qureshi and Sells note:     "Those who proclaim such a clash of civilizations
column34: speaking for the West or for Islam
column35: exhibit the characteristics of fundamentalism: the assumption of a static essence
column36: knowable immediately
column37: of each civilization

column39: and the desire to lead the ideological battle on behalf of one of the clashing civilizations".

 Maybe this book is good if you don't know any better, but I couldn't help but notice a Zionist slant when it came to discussing either the greatness or victimhood of the Jewish people, as compared to only about 6 instances of mere mention of the Arab people but only as slave traders.  So, there you go, the vilification of Arabs yet again by an unsuspecting Zionist.  Only 6 lines dedicated to a people who have been greatly instrumental in much of civilization as we know it today, and all this person can say is they were instrumental in the slave trade?  And lest we forget, Palestinian Arabs have been and still are victims of the criminal Zionists going on over 100 years now!  Where's that mention?  I thought this book was about race, why not mention the racism that exists today that is wiping out a large group of indigenous people today, the Palestinians!  Looking at the mega ratings this book has gotten, I suppose I'm one of the few people who would notice such things because this sort of Zionist superiority and Arab bashing is so rampant in this country it's often overlooked and is why it's so easy for us to bomb Arab countries without too much of an outcry.  But Arabs have contributed greatly to our world especially in the fields of medicine, physics, chemistry, mathematics, and astronomy, and I happen to be a big fan of their contribution to arts (especially music) and literature (too many to mention).  So it seems I will have to continue my search to find a book that isn't so self serving and narrow in its agenda disguised as defining race and culture. 
 This book exposes nothing.  There are way-better books out there, better written and better researched.  I bought it after watching her much needed bashing of these retarded Neo-Cons on Bill Maher's show.  Here's the lowdown:  She grabs one subject and repeats it dozens of different ways, adding new twists, puns and jokes.  The book has no cohesive structure.  Like an ADD-sufferer on coffee. Worst of all, she was part of that system.  She gets divorced, and boom.  Her politics take a 180 degree turn.  How's that supposed to work?  If the payoffs from these interest groups are providing for your cushy life, it's good.  But if you divorce your Neo-Con husband, then, all of a sudden it's bad.  Honestly, I see a lack of integrity here.  So, if tomorrow she marries a communist, will she be singing Lenin's praises?  Or how about a devil-worshiper?  Will she go satanic? Then, I watched her devolve on Maher's show, constantly doing nothing but vent her anger at her ex-husband in a thin veil of politics.  She ran for Cali governor and her points were high.  Then, she started opening her mouth, and her points plumetted.  For good reason.  Because she ran a negative campaign against the Governator. (Which is exactly the same thing she acuses Neo-Cons of doing in this worthless book). But, of course, knee-jerk liberals love her, because they see her as a repented sinner who sees the error of her ways.  LET ME SUM UP THE BOOK FOR YOU:  A party holds on to power too long, it becomes corrupt.  Campaign reform is needed.  End of story

 I have been using a Marineland Bio-Wheel 280 for over a year now and each month it is a horrible chore to clean the thing. In addition it's noisy. Sure it filters okay, but I got so tired of having to clean the thing I decided, just for convenience, try a much less expensive and LESS powerful filter. I got a Whisper 20-40. I was shocked that the Whisper 20-40 works a LOT better than this 280 and churns out a lot more power with truly whisper quality noise. Easy to maintain too. I put my Marineland Bio-Wheel 280 in the shack and will probably throw it away.   THE MARINELAND BIO-WHEEL 280 IS A PAIN TO START--TRY GETTING IT RUN WITHOUT THAT WHIRR WHIRR WHIRR LIKE IT'S IN PAIN TO A STEADY FLOW TAKES ABOUT 5 TO 7 MINUTES WITH CONSTANT THROWING WATER IN THE CONTAINER. The Whisper 20-40 only took 10 seconds with the container even just half full of water. So what's the deal with this 280? As far as I'm concerned it's a waste of money. THE BIOWHEEL IS ALSO TERRIBLE--sure bacteria grows on it, but take it out of the water for a few minutes say goodbye to your colony.

column1: An amazing transformation came over me while reading this book. No
column2: I did not turn into a lizard or a bird. Never before have I experienced such an enormous swing in my state of mind while reading a book. No classic has moved me so much. No works of Hume
column3: nor Kant
column4: nor even Harry Potter's chambermaid have driven in me such a force of wild-eyed realization as compared with this amazing collection of words. I will do my best to describe the story
column5: without boxing your ears or tugging my braid.  The story starts like all of Jordan's stories do
column6: which is to say that an avalanche of words were used to describe such mundane things as grass and horse eye lashes. Nevertheless
column7: Jordan's indispensable and uncanny knack for stringing words together kept me in the game. I had read the first seven books in the series and knew what I was up against. This was nothing. A hundred
column8: two hundred
column9: or even fifty thousand words to describe yet another immature dialog between a pair of immature people wedged in an altogether immature scenario would never get me down.  But as time wore on
column10: it started to wear on me. Like water over a rock
column11: my meddle started to wan
column12: slowly washing away with the sands of the wheel of time. I began zoning out
column13: unable to focus on the words on the page before me
column14: finding myself having read an entire paragraph with no recollection of having done so. I wondered
column15: am I really taking an SAT test? All my previous training seemed to have left me. My eyes were failing me
column16: my brain quitting. I was aghast. This series of books that had heretofore been as straight in it's narrative as a pentangle was bogging down more than I thought even possible. I was losing interest. The flame was going out.  But I dug deep. I concentrated on the void
column17: the endless void
column18: the taint of Boredom making the void sickly sweet and palpable in my veins. I could taste it
column19: it's sickening blackened bleary broken bleakness trying to take over my mind
column20: my body
column21: my soul. I controlled it. And with that control
column22: Jordan's world of Boredom coursed through my veins like a pat of hot butter on a toasted English muffin on a hot summer day in Florida when the air conditioner is broken.  Shortly I had discovered the long lost Talent of Skimming. What had previously taken hours to read now took minutes! Pages down in seconds
column23: chapters in no time at all. Boredom? Shredded to bits. Single words picked here and there
column24: dialog grasped in an instant when the words "boxed" or "grasped" sprung from the page. I was alive
column25: I was being tainted by Boredom! The lost Talent of Skimming
column26: an astoundingly rare yet miraculously rediscovered Talent much like others I came across while reading this book
column27: made me feel more alive than ever. Not to be outdone
column28: Skimming was joined by Sleeping
column29: Ignoring
column30: Laughing
column31: Putting Down
column32: and Reading Something Else. All amazing powers in their own right
column33: but nothing to hold a candle to Skimming.  In no time
column34: Jordan's 8th book came to a close
column35: and the narrative was no closer to being resolved than if all the characters had jumped into a blender and pressed the puree button
column36: using the One Power of course. I mean
column37: how else would they press the puree button if they were *in* the blender? I dare say that it would be improbable.  In any event
column38: this book was so bad that the time invested in all 8 can't keep me coming back for a 9th. Fool me 8 times
column39: shame on you. Fool me 9

 It is not so much that I did not think the plot plausable, but the characterizations are untrue to the original book.  I feel not enough time and care was taken to move the plot within the parameters of the characters as set by JA.  Miss Darcy, although entertaining, becomes a pale shade of Elizabeth Bennett.  Lady Catherine becomes flaccidly comic (has she become a vicar or even transposed with Mr Collins?)  It pains me also to see the most interesting and engaging characters of Elizabeth and Darcy pushed so far into the background.  I also take issue with the use of Lizzy and Fitzwilliam as the familiar names the couple uses when refering to each other.  I am almost certain that Elizabeth would always be Elizabeth in Darcy's eyes and that none of the characters in P&P would have used anything but Darcy's surname.  All of this censure aside, it was a good attempt.  I thought the phrasing and meter of the work to pay homage to Austen.  I also admire the care taken in research of the subject matter and time period.  I would recommend this book as what it is aptly titled :An Entertainment"

column1: Where's the subtitle of this very effective book?  Did the modern editors simply take it away?  Darwin titled his book: "The Origin of Species by Means of Natural Selection" and subtitled it: "The Preservation of Favoured Races in the Struggle for Life."  When Hitler came to power in 1933
column2: he had one overarching idea in mind: his radical Nazi racial philosophy built on the Darwinian principle of natural selection.  Hilter thought the Aryans were the fittest and he wanted to help speed up the "inevitability" of natural selection.  He first started off with the sterilization of nine categories of "the unfit" which were feebleminded
column3: schizophrenia
column4: manic depression
column5: Huntington's chorea
column6: epilepsy
column7: hereditary body deformities
column8: deafness
column9: hereditary blindness and alcoholism.  He then worked his way up to attempting the complete extermination of entire categories and entire races of people.  Speaking of modern day little Hitlers
column10: the Columbine High School shooters carried out their bloody rampage on Hilter's birthday
column11: April 20th
column12: and had planned on causing more than 500 deaths at the high school.  Shooter Eric Harris had written on his website
column13: "YOU KNOW WHAT I LOVE??? Natural SELECTION!  It's the best thing that ever happened to the Earth.  Getting rid of all the stupid and weak organisms."  After the bloody rampage
column14: Harris' autopsy report revealed that he was wearing a T-shirt with the words "Natural Selection" emblazoned on the front.  Beware of those who hold this book dear to their hearts.  This book is not about man descending from the apes.  The ideas in this book have caused and continue to cause more deaths than any other notion in modern history

column1: Before buying this book
column2: I wished I had read the review below that says
column3: "For every winner there is at least one loser. For every big winner generally there are a few losers. The successful ones do study the stock market in detail and they depend upon substantial understanding of the share market system but knowledge is not enough
column4: you need something else as well. If it was simply knowledge and easy
column5: then arrogant inexperienced fools like this writer who are obviously extremely intelligent would have made money instead of losing it."  For one thing if the author knew at least a little bit about stop loss techniques before entering the stock market
column6: he would not have lost so much money with his stock purchases. Maybe he is just so frustated and wants to show how smart he is and that only a random market could beat him as it did. Maybe he just wants to show that with the mathematics he had all he needed to enter the market
column7: that no additional domain knowledge would be needed.  But then he goes on to show how technical analysis is flawed and how smart he is to see this so clearly. As the other reviewer noticed
column8: he quickly jumps to conclusion whenever things don't follow his logic. I could list many cases in this book where his very own analysis is flawed
column9: where his arguments are not well constructed
column10: where the next step is avoided whenever the path could lead to a different conclusion.  I have a Theoretical Physics background and the I-know-it-best position that the author shows does not appeal to me either. Most of his humor seems to be based on a deep-seated sense of arrogance.  Yet
column11: he is an intelligent man. One can hardly believe that this is the same person who wrote his other good books
column12: especially the excellent "Innumeracy". Well
column13: they were more in his domain of knowledge.   But he thinks that knowing Mathematics he knows a lot more than he knows
column14: and a lot more than the average Joe. And the market is unforgiving to people who behave like fools and without proper domain knowledge.  I have given two stars to this book because it happens to be an interesting book for people who works with technical analysis. To find the errors and flawed arguments of an intelligent man trying to beat technical analysis is intellectually gratifying.   It may also turn out to be very enlightening to see how the market turns an intelligent man into a fool if proper domain knowledge is missing. It is a lesson that many learn the hard way.  This book probably has a typo in its title.

I wanted to like this book.  I love Sagas of Icelanders.  I was ecstatic over the Poetic Edda.  Snorri's "Prose Edda" was frequently mentioned in my other reading
column2: and I decided I would have to check it out.  What a disappointment. I must clarify that by saying that the Prose Edda is an EXTREMELY important book of immense value to students of Medeival literature (specifically Scandinavian / Norse / Icelandic.)  It is the single most complete record of  Norse mythology which we have today
column3: and along with the Poetic Edda
column4: constitutes practically the sole source of material for all books which re-tell the mythological stories.  But the Edda is
column5: unfortunately
column6: a book to be read only for the value of the information it contains; not for entertainment.  All of the interesting material in the Edda is re-told (in much more readable ways) elsewhere.  Snorri himself
column7: in the course of this book
column8: re-tells "Voluspa" (from the Poetic Edda) and gives a brief synopsis of the Volsunga Saga. Edda was written as a handbook for poets and scholars
column9: to aid in understanding ancient Scandinavian poetry
column10: which was thick with mythological allusions. Edda also provides guidelines for composing new poems using traditional forms.  It was written two or three centuries into the Christian era of northern Europe
column11: when old pagan lore was already nearly forgotten.  Snorri's book kept his ancestor's cultural heritage from disappearing completely.  He treats the old myths very kindly
column12: but is careful to throw in the obligatory Christian warnings about "false religion."  According to "Gylfaginning
column13: (the first and most interesting part of the Edda) the Norse gods - the Aesir - were originally a tribe of people who migrated to the North from Turkey.  They were veterans of the Trojan War (!) so cultured and technologically advanced that they were regarded as gods by the ignorant folk in the lands they conquered and settled.  According to Snorri, most of the mythological stories are analogous to episodes from the Iliad. The second section of the Edda is called Skaldskaparmal" and it is very tedious.  It consists of a mythological discussion between Aegir (the sea god) and Bragi (the god of poetry) in which Bragi explains various kinds of kennings.  A kenning is a poetic figure of speech in which a person or object is referred to by describing it in terms of another person or object.  Then that secondary person or object can be referred to by yet another substitute
column14: down to 4 or 5 levels of circumlocution
column15: all of which has to be figured out by the listener to determine exactly what the poet is talking about.  Kennings are like riddles
column16: allegories
column17: metaphors
column18: and allusions rolled all into one.  A fairly detailed myhtological background is required to make sense of them - thus
column19: the reason for the Edda.  A few stories are told which explain some kennings
column20: but gradually Snorri loses track of the "conversation" that initially provided structure for this section
column21: and the reader gets mired amidst interminable lists of poetic synonyms for swords
column22: ships
column23: gold
column24: and so on.  Quotes from old poems illustrate the use of many of the kennings. The translator - for reasons which are certainly valid - opted to render all of the verse as prose
column25: preserving its literal meaning [with allegorical meanings choppily inserted in square brackets
column26: ] but utterly detroying its power as POETRY. The final section is called "Hattatal" and it consists of a few verse quotations and three original poems composed by Snorri himself in a different style for each verse
column27: with sections of prose in between stanzas to explain the technical details (rhyme
column28: meter
column29: alliteration
column30: etc) of each style.  There's a total of 102 verses in the Hattatal
column31: and the poetry here is actually somewhat interesting; more so
column32: at least
column33: than the nuts-and-bolts discussion of the fine points of skaldic composition.  In this section
column34: each verse is presented in the original Old Icelandic (with modernized spelling) with English translation underneath. At the end of this volume
column35: the translator has provided a handy eight-page summary that will tell you what you missed and/or forgot as you slogged in a bleary-eyed daze through Skaldskaparmal and Hattatal.  There's also an alphabetical index of names so you can look up things and use the Edda for what it was intended to be: a reference book. I'm glad I read it
column36: I guess
column37: since I am pretty "into" this kind of thing ... but I wouldn't recommend it for anyone who is just curious about Norse mythology.  Sure
column38: this book is "the Source" but you'll have more fun reading one of the dozens of more recent re-tellings

column1: The Claim purports to be an adaptation of Thomas Hardy's classic novel
column2: The Mayor of Casterbridge transplanted to the Old West. The producers clearly wanted The Claim to be accepted as a literate Western and it is clear that the critics fell for it. However
column3: as anyone who has read the original Hardy novel can tell you
column4: the movie fails as a Hardy adaptation. Meanwhile
column5: any fan of movie westerns can tell you that The Claim is a failure in that department as well.  The Claim begins in 1869 where Daniel Dillon (Peter Mullan) lords supreme over his company town. His gold mining company is a topflight operation. Dillon is easily one of the most admired men in California
column6: if not in the nation. However
column7: Dillon is not a terribly happy man. Deep down
column8: he broods over a dark secret that
column9: if exposed
column10: could lead to the destruction of his reputation.  You see
column11: the gold claim was originally made by another man
column12: but Dillon sold his wife and daughter to the original claimant in exchange for the claim. The prospector thereupon took both wife and child to Boston and raised the family there. Meanwhile
column13: Dillon ruthlessly exploited the gold claim to become one of the richest men in all of California. Needless to say
column14: if it became public knowldege that Dillon's success was based on the sale of human beings
column15: that would be nothing short of disastrous.  Matters are brought to a head when his wife (Nastassja Kinski)
column16: daughter (Milla Jovovich) and his wife's subsequent daughter with the other man (Sarah Polley) show up in town and request that he take them in as his family. Just when you think that things are going to get interesting
column17: the rug is pulled out from the audience's feet when it is revealed that Dillon conveniently never married after making his dirty deal. This enabled him to marry his ex-wife without never having to publically admit that they were previously married or what happened to that union. This effectively removed all dramatic tension and helped make The Claim a colossal bore

Some people complain that this book has no romance.  Others complain that the mystery is too dark.  My complaint is that I don't know what world Kay Hooper's characters are operating in but it isn't our world.  Never mind the fact that the major premise of this series is that there is a special unit of FBI agents who have psychic powers.  I can live with that.  I can live with them facing a host of otherworld nasties.  What I can't put up with is the failure of basic common sense.  For instance.  There is a maid at a fancy resort who is pregnant by one of the guests.  She is worried about her pregnancy showing because she knows she is going to be fired.  What!?!   Then what will she do to support herself?  What!?!  First
column2: if they fire her because she is pregnant she gets a lawyer and sues their money out of their pocket.  She also notifies the father that he has another mouth to feed and had better get ready to hand over child support.    I've seen this nonesense in romance novels so often that I kind of expect it there
column3: but this is not supposed to be a romance.  Now
column4: as to the mystery part:  this special FBI unit would be far better off if they would stop depending on their psychic abilities so much and do a little gum shoeing.  A child is kidnapped and taken far from the place where she was last seen to a cabin in the mountains. Our dauntless FBI agents find her by psychic means (This isn't a spoiler
column5: it's part of the back story)  and 1) do not take the child to the hospital for examination; 2) do not call in forensic people to search and process the cabin for evidence of the identity of the abductor; and 3) do not seem to follow up at all in a rational
column6: FBI sort of way.    So if you want no romance with all the romance nonsense about the way the world works
column7: a mystery that could have been solved briskly with a little digging into the circumstances and characters that are paper thin at best
column8: then grab this book at once.

column1: "The Beast in the Jungle" is the most effective sleeping pill you are likely to find anywhere. I challenge any reader to go through this text in one sitting and not falling asleep or
column2: at least
column3: not to experiment a tremendous mind-numbing feeling. Of course
column4: I haven't read all the books in the world
column5: but I dare say that this is the most boring piece of writing ever conceived by anyone. I find it very hard to imagine something more awful than this. It's absolutely impossible
column6: unsurpassable.  Henry James' style is so artificially conceited and pompous that you have to ask yourself if the trash he used to write wasn't a very calculated joke after all or if he's just trying to take the reader for a ride (a ride into a world of dullness and boredom
column7: that is). The supposedly "psychological insight" of James is just a mere exercise in nothingness
column8: the highest form of pretentiousness in its purest expression.   In this short???-story (James wasn't very strong on things like "precision" and "conciseness")
column9: the terrible fate that seems to be in store for the main character after pages and pages of monotonous text
column10: turns out to be that "nothing is to happen to him". Pathetic and childish. In my opinion
column11: "The Beast in the Jungle" is the greatest proof that James was a dreadful writer (not to say "an insipid donkey").  Actually
column12: James is so comical as to excite parody. In the old days H.G. Wells likened his prose to an hippopotamus pushing a pea and Ambrose Bierce said that James' work would benefit if someone took the pain to translate it into English. I personally agree with the two of them but
column13: you know
column14: many things that in the past have been judged as "ridiculous" or "stupid" are considered today
column15: through some arbitrary process known as "reassessment of literary figures"
column16: as something pretty relevant and sophisticated. That's life
column17: isn't it?.  "The Beast in the Jungle" is a poor story that serves James as an excuse for writing a lot and not to say anything significant. Completely worthless. In case I had to choose
column18: I'd prefer to read a telephone directory instead.  Of course
column19: this prime example of literary incompetence is regarded as a masterpiece by many scholars.  Well
column20: each to his own..

column10: one a grizzled and thoroughly corrupt veteran (Russell) and the other a somewhat principled but weak-willed and easily manipulated rookie
column11: Bobby Keough (Scott Speedman). Russell's character (Eldon Perry) is controlled and protected by an exceedingly corrupt superior officer
column12: Jack Van Meter (nicely played by Brendan Gleeson)
column13: who uses Perry to further his profitable and flagrantly illegal interests.   If you have ever watched "The Shield" on FX cable network then you will be familiar with this general setup....a morally ambiguous detective is used to further his superior's agenda.....but here is the problem: The Shield (a television series) is vastly superior in every way: plot
column14: acting
column15: characterization
column16: dialog
column17: direction
column18: etc. to this feature film. It is like comparing filet mignon to cheap hamburger. Once you see a quality
column19: nuanced drama like The Shield
column20: this movie and all like it are rendered unwatchable.   Characters in Dark Blue are caricatures with almost no depth. They guzzle whiskey and laugh about their flagrant crimes. The plot and dialog are contrived and unrealistic. There is no subtlety....no intellectually stimulating complexity. Eldon always does exactly as he is told: if mass-murdering thugs (employed and protected by his superior) are to be sheltered from arrest
column21: simply go out and murder a couple of stray ex-cons and let them take the rap (posthumously) for the real criminals. Never mind that neither of the ex-cons is even close to being a plausible suspect. No one would be fooled by this ruse
column22: except perhaps in this mindless movie.   Eldon gets his partner Keough to perform one of the cold-blooded murders ordered by Van Meter
column23: and thus begins their downfall
column24: because Keough has a spontaneous change of heart and suddenly cannot accept the guilt of his actions. One minute he is guzzling whiskey with his cronies and laughing about lying to a shooting review board
column25: and the next he is overwrought with guilt. Not at all likely in real life
column26: but it suits the plot.   Things gets even sillier when the partner (Speedman) then teams up with the assistant chief's (Ving Rhames) predictably beautiful ex-mistress (Michael Michelle) to try to arrest the real thugs and use them to bring down the whole perverted mess. Heaven forbid that he simply come forth and provide evidence to accomplish this end. What follows is a lengthy
column27: confused
column28: and poorly choreographed pursuit of the thugs and a predictable gun battle with equally predictable outcome.   The ultimate farce
column29: however
column30: is reserved for Eldon himself
column31: who drives around South Central Los Angeles during the peak of the Rodney King riots trying to find and arrest a black suspect....which he easily accomplishes....and then drives away without a scratch. This reaches the level of surrealistic absurdity and is an insult to the true horror of the riots.  Equally unconvincing is Eldon's spontaneous change of heart at the end of the movie

column34: preposterous and unconvincing indictment of his father
column35: himself

I doubt Anna spent more than a night in Rocky Mountain National Park.  Not only does she completely miss the unique character of the park but the park has no necessary link to the story. column1: Leading Evangelical theologian Wayne Grudem continues his mission of defining and defending the "complimentarian position" with his very fluent pen. It is no secret that Grudem finds the controversy over the role of women in the home and in the church to be the most important issue Evangelicals face today. He warns that there is a connection between evangelical feminism (egalitarianism) and liberalism
column2: and believes the current state of evangelicalism regarding manhood and womanhood is in need of desperate revision. Grudem amplifies his polemicist skills by interacting with over 100 egalitarian arguments and stops short of denouncing them as heretical.   Yet
column3: despite 800 poised pages to the contrary
column4: I still am not able to see the logic in Grudem's positions. Doug Groothuis illuminates (see his review of Recovering Biblical Manhood and Womanhood)
column5: 1) the Bible is true in all that it teaches
column6: 2) Men and women are equal in value as human beings and essential human capacity
column7: and 3) God ordains men to be in authority over women cross-culturally and perpetually. These three propositions cannot all be true
column8: because if (2) is true (3) cannot be true
column9: since (3) restricts women and confirms that they are not equal to men. If the Bible teaches both (2) and (3) to be true
column10: the Bible itself teaches errors
column11: thus contradicting (1).   Nevertheless
column12: Grudem takes 25 years of scholarship and packages it neatly into one volume that is readable and accessible

column1: This book is about a Jewish girl named Hannah Green who flees from Spain in fear of the Spanish Inquisition after witnessing her mother being captured and burned alive at the stakes for being a Jew.  She comes to England with her father and lives as a Christian while following the Jewish religion in secrecy.  Through a chain of events she becomes a royal fool and a spy - for both Queen Mary and Elizabeth.   Throughout the book Hannah talks about how she misses her mother and can still smell her mother's burning flesh from the stakes and then also professes her love for Queen Mary and what a wonderful woman she is.  It is well documented in history as well as this book about Queen Mary's burning of hundreds of non-Catholics at the stakes.  A practice that earned her the name - Bloody Mary.  The book is very sympathetic towards Queen Mary and portrays her as a virtuous woman who believed that she was burning people for their own sake - "only doing what she believed to be right in her heart".    The fact that Hannah was living her life in fear of being discovered as a Jew and continued to deeply love Queen Mary was extremely unbelievable and ridiculous. I could not help but roll my eyes every time I read how much Hannah loved and admired Queen Mary.
I was outraged in reading this book.  I can't imagine why someone who obviously has absolutely no faith would write a biography of Mary.  Other than being an insult to anyone of faith
column2: it is not a biography at all
column3: but a book about the times that Mary lived in.  It is quite clear that the author has no knowledge of the biblical Mary and no understanding of faith or Christianity.  Don't waste your money or time on this book. I had to give this book one star
column4: but it deserved none

Readers here are always quick to revolt against 1-star reviews of respected figures
column2: but hear me out here. I'm a big fan of Pierre Boulez
column3: and not a day goes by when I don't delight in some of his great works like "...explosante-fixe..."
column4: "Sur Incises"
column5: and "Repons". This disc
column6: however
column7: is a disaster from an otherwise heroic composer.  "Pli selon pli"  for soprano and orchestra is a lengthy setting of poems by Stephane Mallarme
column8: whose idea of a work in "perpetual expansion" preoccupied Boulez for much of the 1950s. The work grew in stages. It began first with three "Improvisations sur Mallarme" for voice and small ensemble in 1958 and 1959. Then a grim end
column9: "Tombeau" for large orchestra
column10: was added later in 1959. Finally
column11: in 1960 the work gained an introduction with "Don" for large orchestra
column12: whose opening big tutti chord will sound familiar to anyone familiar with Luciano Berio's "Sinfonia" (where it's quoted in the passage "I have a present for you" *whomp*). Originally the order of many elements were left to the discretion of the conductor
column13: a form similar to that of the Piano Sonata No. 3 and "Eclat"
column14: but Boulez ultimately fixed the parts in the order they are here. The completed work has been revise several times since its introduction
column15: and various versions have been recorded. This recording is of the latest revision
column16: that of 1989.  Along with "Le Marteau Sans Maitre" of 1953-1955
column17: "Pli selon pli" ushers out the bleep-bloops and Webern-inspired crystal sounds of early Boulez and introduces the interest in wide contrasts of timbre and the warm tones of alto range that marks all of his subsequent work. The forces of a traditional ensemble are accompanied by guitar and mandolin
column18: and while the soprano has a decisive role
column19: her intonations serve more as exotic instrument in the ensemble than a communicator of poetry.  Unfortunately
column20: "Pli selon pli" is a rather unfocused work
column21: for certain moments drag on for far too long than they should. There can indeed be moments of immense wonder here
column22: the general exploration of the ensemble's capabilities
column23: the soprano's wild gesticulations
column24: and especially the grimly beautiful end
column25: which is among Boulez's most frenetic writing. On the 1969 recording on Sony where Boulez leads the soprano Halina Lukomska and the BBC Symphony Orchestra
column26: there's a good aggression about the performance that overcomes the sluggish parts to make for a three-star listening.  On this revised version
column27: however
column28: those dragging moments drag on even longer
column29: and Boulez's conducting lacks any of the old violence. It's over an hour of extremely sluggish pacing
column30: and the result is unlistenable. I can't believe that at the same time Boulez did this revision
column31: he was at work on the new version of "...explosante-fixe..."
column32: one of the most wild and exuberant pieces I've ever heard.  "Pli selon pli" for me has never ranked among Boulez's best work
column33: though at least on the Sony recording it was entertaining enough. But I can't find much good to say about this performance

 To give context to my comments, I have a degree in Middle East History and bought this book, first edition, in 1992.  I began it several times over the years, only to be defeated by the dry prose and ceaseless repetition of unrelated facts.  I finally sat down to read it from start to finish a few months ago.  Now that I've finally finished, I realize that I wish I had never made the attempt.  It is boring, but worse than that, it is deceptive.  All references come for the first edition, hardback.  1. p. 191, Regarding domed buildings, the transition from the square hall to the round dome posed a problem which was solved by the use of the squinch or pendentive
column4: often with stalacites for decoration."  This quote gives the false impression the Arabs solved the problem of placing a dome on a square hall.  Google "Haggia Sophia" and you will see a dome sitting on a square hall built by Eastern Roman Christians in the 500s.  2.  Constantly discusses communist Arabs in a neutral to positive light (p. 325) but fails to mention the presence of fascist influences in Arab politics
column5: especially the roots of fascism in the Ba'ath Party as a result of Arabism's fascination with 1930s European power politics.  3. p. 359
column6: Regarding the move by the surrounding Arab communities to crush the newly created Israel
column7: Arab "forces moved into the mainly Arab parts of the country."  Hourani then claims fighting broke out because the absence of borders allowed Jews "to occupy the greater part of the country."  This is a deliberate falsification on Hourani's part.  The Arab forces publicly stated aims was the destruction of Israel and the removal of the Jewish community from Palestine.  4.  p. 368
column8: Regarding the resolution of the 1956 Suez Canal Conflict
column9: "Under American and Soviet pressure . . . the three forces withdrew."  Here Hourani implies
column10: falsely
column11: that France
column12: Britain and Israel were affected equally by U.S. and Soviet threats.  In fact
column13: the U.S. Sixth Fleet shielded the three combatant forces from the irrelevant Soviet forces
column14: while acting to pressure the combatants to withdraw.  Even more
column15: Eisenhower's use of economic retaliation against the weak French and British economies did most of the work.  5.  p. 413
column16: In one of the most egregious passages
column17: blames Israel for a war of aggression against the peaceful Egypt
column18: Jordan and Syria in the Six Days War.  I recommend the book
column19: aptly titled
column20: Six Days of War: June 1967 and the Making of the Modern Middle East to dispel any misunderstandings fostered by Hourani.  6.  Even when writing honestly
column21: Hourani tends towards dry
column22: and needless
column23: repetition.  By way of example are his nearly indistinguishable passages on Arab poetry on pages 12-14
column33: which could be summarized as "Poetry
column34: both oral and written
column35: is the greatest achievement of Arab culture.  Even today it retains many of the same themes and similar structures to that created in pre-Islamic times."  Except Hourani takes 18 pages over the course of the book to say it.  In conclusion
column36: I can not recommend this book for either the beginner or specialist.  The beginner will be overwhelmed by the flood of unexplained names
column37: dates
column38: facts and figures.  The specialist will constantly find problems with Hourani's accuracy and honesty.  There are too many good books on both Arab and Islamic history for you to waste your time on this one

column1: I'd say this book was mediocre and trite. You can judge a book by its cover here- an awful title for an awful read. It is written from a fairly feminist perspective despite the fact that the authors are men. It had a few good points but I could have spent my money in much better ways. A lot of it is stories (Bruce is the fictional 'hero' and Bob is the 'failure' and they keep re-appearing to illustrate the ideas in the book) and the stories are awful. There are  checklists in each chapter ("what to do during the date") and these stories recap what the checklists and ideas say. When one of the stories quoted the checklist verbatim (something like "bruce touched his date on the arm at least once to make physical contact with her blah blah blah") I nearly vomited. At that point I literally threw the book into a fire and made it useful. YOU HAVE BEEN WARNED

column1: As a 4th year medical student and

column3: I am confident that Mr. Kessler is on a rabbit trail that will never pan out across the spectrum of diseases he suggests. His ideas sound wonderful
column4: but he is missing a fundamental problem. Diagnostic tests inevitably incur false positives and false negatives
column5: and to greatly simplify
column6: as you improve on one
column7: you amplify the other. So
column8: for example
column9: as whatever algorithm you want to concoct becomes better at predicting disease and reducing false negatives
column10: the false positives will go up. People will be treated unnecessarily and that often is harmful. There's a word for that-iatrogenic. This is nothing new and well-known in medical research. Thus
column11: silicon is hardly going to displace MDs. But
column12: it may foster lots of unnecessary and iatrogenic care that will drive the cost of medicine far beyond where it already is today. In addition
column13: it will provide new fodder for the med mal lawyers. Truly
column14: medicine is an art and a science.

One day a retired historian turns up dead in a field near the village of Helmthorpe
column7: leaving Banks with an old-fashioned whodunit. Pretty quickly

column9: his old friend and publisher
column10: his mystery-writing drinking pal
column11: his local GP and drinking pal
column12: a local entrepreneur developer drinking pal

column16: like the old-fashioned constructions of Christie

column1: As is becoming unfortunately common today
column2: this text has not been seriously edited. In many places it either lacks proper punctuation or the punctuation is improperly employed. The text is sometimes missing conjunctional words
column3: and numerous sentence fragments occur. The book sometimes reads as if the manuscript was in point form; at others
column4: it is almost like a rushed translation into English from some other language. Although this is the fault of the editor
column5: it is an irony that the author sprinkles (sics) liberally throughout his book
column6: where these are intended as quibbling corrections to the spelling or technical inaccuracies of the autobiographies and field reports of the soldiers involved in the action the author is describing.    Moreover
column7: several-page introductions/historical overviews (of such mundane topics as the 'Second World War
column8: ' but also of some of the geographical locations discussed in the text) preoccupy the first pages of several chapters; these have been included as backgrounders
column9: but serve only to distract
column10: as they are either unnecessary given the expected audience
column11: or largely irrelevant to the book's thrust. Some readers will inevitably skip over them on sight
column12: as I found myself doing.    The endnotes in the book's first half are largely technical data on the weapons mentioned in the text; this is another curious addition considering the (assumed!) intended audience
column13: who likely know this information from memory. The book's structure therefore anticipates an informed (although not specialist) audience
column14: but the introductory narrative of a few chapters and most of the notes assume a general readership. (On the other hand
column15: the author does not explain the lion's share of the requisite military jargon and acronyms; he assumes they will be understood by the reader).    The operational descriptions would have benefited from additional maps for contextualization (only one map is given of Operation JUBILLE
column16: when the book concentrates on the actions of 4 Commando on the far right flank; a map of the RAF's flight paths on the right flank seems to have taken precedence over the movements of the Commando. (?))    Ironically
column17: the end of the book
column18: which describes events after the withdrawal of 4 Commando from the beaches of Dieppe (chapters entitled "Homecoming" and the "Aftermath")
column19: are much more skillfully and thoughtfully written without unruly harping on the results of Dieppe proper
column20: and it is these entries that make the overall effort worthwhile.    The book ends up reading like a narrative
column21: and not a scholarly commentary; this will make it more attractive to the general readership
column22: and is perhaps the more fitting introduction to this little-known subject. Ultimately however (regardless of the format!)
column23: the context and intended audience of the work was never definitively solidified
column24: so the book cannot decide whether to comment technically (which it does occasionally
column25: but not very well)
column26: or try to characterize the figures that are important to the operation. Sadly
column27: it makes a partial attempt to do both
column28: but fails to do either. It is however a quick read
column29: and I wasn't put off enough to give up on it (if you don't mind the editing
column30: you'll find it fun).    The subject of 4 Commando's actions in Operation JUBILEE merits serious treatment
column31: within the larger context of the result of the Dieppe raid. Two stars given for the importance of the topic; no more is fair
column32: given the organizational quality

column1: Not to put too fine a point on it but this book is DRY - almost like a text book. column2: with excruciating detail. In one part
column3: Mr. Stockwell describes what he did to finally get a desk to work from at Langley by sitting in the hall in everyone's way and stacking his papers up beside him.  What took him pages to describe should've been done in a simple paragraph.  To be fair
column4: the book is written from the viewpoint of an intelligence staffer not a cloak and dagger operative. Yes

column9: in the latter chapters the account does get more interesting as he discusses "plausible deniability" and the deception of the CIA to "hide" their involvement. column10: the propaganda strategy
column11: the political workings thru committees
column12: the State Department and the President to gain support

column5:
an emotionally gripping, sophisticatedly plotted and lyrical novel about the intersections of love, art and life in 1980s and 1990s New York City.  I found nothing really enchanting or enchanted about Hustvedt's protaganist in this one, a blond buxom waitress withering as in smalltown Minnesota but hoping for a career as an actress.  The story might have been about a young woman discovering something within herself and her surroundings, but instead, the reader gets a murder mystery with a psycho, as well as a handful of caricatured and unbelievable characters who all seem to love Lily Dahl but never seem to get her.  Don't judge Hustvedt by this one

column1: Nothing new or the slightest bit insightful can be found within these pages. Anyone who's read a decent book or two about Led Zeppelin (not counting the terrible Hammer of the Gods or Richard Cole's travesty) already knows everything supposedly "revealed" here. There's a lot left out
column2: and Fyfe seems to attribute every good idea the band had to drugs. He keeps calling them "hippies
column3: and has the nerve to claim that they never went on to release an album on par with the fourth. Excuse me?  He also mentions the ridiculous deal with the devil" rubbish far too many times
column4: giving the '70s media hacks more attention than they deserve and actually claiming that Zeppelin cared about what critics thought
column5: designing their fourth album around media "respectability." He has the audacity to try defending the press's treatment of the band during the '70s
column6: and says mean things like how Jimmy "ate his words" when he agreed to play with Plant again. This kind of unwarranted criticism can be found throughout the book.  One gets the idea that Fyfe was never much of a Zeppelin fan
column7: but read a few books and stole their best bits for this assignment. His wording's often identical to that in other works. His grammar's not very good; it's full of run-on sentences and annoying word repetition.  There's so much good information left out from dozens of great interviews over the years
column8: regarding the making of the fourth album alone (which is what this book's supposedly about
column9: although you get a condensed bio of nearly everyone mentioned on the fringes of the band
column10: which is unnecessary and tedious)
column11: that the book is unacceptably incomplete.  There's also a lot of erroneous information. For instance
column12: Fyfe quotes John Paul Jones as stating that "Going to California" was recorded outside in the garden
column13: and that a plane can be heard flying over. He's actually talking about "Black Country Woman
column14: which is on an entirely different album! Fyfe quotes In the Evening" by claiming that Robert sings "I'm in pain" (no
column15: he doesn't) and says that hip-hop as we know it wouldn't exist without the Beastie Boys ripping off Bonzo (very wrong).  He also contradicts himself constantly -- stating
column16: for instance
column17: that Page and Plant arrived at Headley Grange with "Battle of Evermore" worked out
column18: but then later telling the story we already know: Page picked up Jones' mandolin while staying at Grange and began writing the song based on his experiments with the instrument.  The book's full of things like this. Save your money.

column1: Oh
column2: dear. Le Carre is
column3: or was earlier in his career
column4: a brilliant writer.   I have read and reread a number of Le Carre books lately and what is clear to me is that the quality of his novels has deteriorated over the years
column5: as one might expect
column6: I suppose. Single and Single reads like something written to fill out a publishing contract for a certain number of books.  The plots meanders and is hard to follow. You may think that this is par for the course in the novels of Le Carre
column7: but all I can say is that his better works like Spy Who Came In and Honourable Schoolboy have elements of this trickiness
column8: but it is not overdone.  There is a certain tendency in modern English novelists--I'm thinking of people like Martin Amis--to give the reader a hard time
column9: and in his later books Le Carre seems to be increasingly of the school of letting the reader try to figure out on his own what is going on in the book. My interpretation is that this is due to lazy writing
column10: and the author losing sight of the reader. Others may disagree.  In earlier novels Le Carre leaned a great deal on what appeared to be inside knowledge of the espioniage business. Well
column11: he had me convinced
column12: anyway. Once he gets away from that territory
column13: it seems to me that he is much more inauthentic.  My guess is that the character of Tiger Single is somewhat based on Le Carre's own father
column14: who was something of a jet-set conman.  The book has plently of brilliantly witty  dialog
column15: very much a Le Carre specialty
column16: and passages of superb descriptive writing
column17: so all is not lost
column18: but I would only recommend it for the diehard Le Carre fan who has read everything else and has a lot of time on his/her hands

I read this book and couldn't believe that it would have actually been published. column2: BUT *GENDER* DOES NOT have anything to DO with "Social Interaction. *Gender* is what someone IS on the *inside* NOT on the outside or how they are perceived by others in society. This book was a waste of time AND money!!!!

column1: The general theme of this book is
column2: to quote Lerner and Loewe in My Fair Lady
column3: "Why Can't a Woman be More Like a Man?"  Frankel does point out some behavioral tics that women would do well to ditch
column4: like the infamous framing of statements as questions. But she goes far beyond that to advocate what is essentially a complete overhaul of behavior
column5: appearance
column6: speech
column7: body language
column8: office decor and relationship style. Women are urged to act in ways that feel unnatural all day
column9: every work day. I don't think even Meryl Streep could keep that up for long. Work is inherently stressful and exhausting enough without pretending to be something you're not 50 hours a week.  Frankel encourages women to think that to be female is to be inherently flawed. Freud must be smiling
column10: wherever he is.   Maybe to some women the pursuit of "the corner office" or however they define outward success is worth sacrificing their personhood
column11: but I question the assumption that male behavior is the normative standard to which women must conform---or fail. The corporate and political worlds have historically been dominated by supposedly male traits of aggression
column12: competitiveness and "winner take all" (I doubt
column13: by the way
column14: whether men as a group consistently display those traits)
column15: and look where that's gotten us--Enron
column16: obscene executive compensation at the expense of other employees
column17: falling middle class wages
column18: growing disparity between wealth and poverty
column19: foreign policy debacles. I think women should be trying to improve the organizations of which they are a part instead of slavishly copying male behavior that has proved dysfunctional. Let's face it---a man is going to "outman" a woman every time.
