column1: This short book is about the small Tuck family (a man
column2: his wife
column3: two young-adult sons
column4: and their horse)
column5: who inadvertently drink from a magic spring which renders them immortal.  Thereafter
column6: they do not age
column7: and seem immune to death by violence or accident.  In this state
column8: they seem to live a happy
column9: almost idyllic existence.  Nonetheless
column10: they bemoan their fate as a sort of curse
column11: which has removed them from the cycle of life.  Mrs. Tuck especially seems convinced that it would be a disaster if anyone else were to find out about the magic spring.  The exception to this sighing and moaning is the youngest son
column12: who
column13: perhaps because he has the good fortune to be stuck at 17
column14: seems reasonably satisfied with his fate.  The main events of the story take place 84 years later
column15: when a series of improbable coincidences involving the Tucks
column16: an 11-year old girl
column17: and a mysterious stranger
column18: together with some idiotic behavior by all concerned
column19: converge to force events to an contrived climax.  The author hints that these improbable convergences have some deep mystical significance.  Since this mysticism remains obscure
column20: one is inclined to instead suspect lazy plotting.  The stupidity
column21: and moral depravity
column22: of the Tucks is evident in the fact that
column23: for the last 84 years
column24: they have done virtually nothing to conceal
column25: guard
column26: protect or destroy the magic spring.  And yet when (by pure luck) they learn that the spring is about to be discovered
column27: they are willing to commit kidnapping and even murder to keep the secret from getting out.   The author strives to make the murder victim as unlikable as possible so that the killer (the Tuck mom) will retain our sympathies.  But the bottom line is that the sole motive for the murder is that the victim knew too much and could not be counted upon to keep a secret.  I cannot possibly agree that Mrs. Tuck had any right
column28: therefore
column29: to take his life.  The fact that the victim gloats about his less-than-noble intentions immediately before she shoots him
column30: does not make her act any more morally palatable.  The stream
column31: after all
column32: does not belong to the Tucks.  What right have they to play God
column33: and take lives to prevent others from sharing their high and lonely (if idyllic) destiny?  Setting aside moral questions
column34: the stupidity of the Tucks is nothing compared to the stupidity of the villain.  Why on Earth did he not drink from the stream and render himself immortal?  Why on Earth did he not do this before going all by himself to a secluded location to have a gloating
column35: taunting confrontation with four fully-grown immortals.  He is fully aware that the Tucks are determined to keep their secret
column36: he knows exactly why
column37: and he knows they are desperate or depraved enough to commit the kidnapping of a child for this purpose.  In fact
column38: why does he confront them at all?  They were completely unnecessary to his plans
column39: as he himself points out when
column40: predictably
column41: the Tucks refuse to agree to them.  Bottom line is
column42: he went merely because the author wanted to give Mrs. Tuck an opportunity to shoot him
column43: and he gloated and taunted only so the reader might say "Ha
column44: serves you right"
column45: when sweet Mrs. Tuck blows his head off with a shotgun.  One of the ironies of this story is that
column46: although the Tucks are convinced that the widespread availability of the magic water would be a disaster
column47: we are nonetheless supposed to despise the villain for his selfishness
column48: when he reveals his plan to disseminate the water only to those well-paying persons he considers most deserving.   And yet when Jesse
column49: the youngest immortal
column50: starts plotting to do something similar
column51: we are expected to retain our sympathies for him.  I suppose this is because Jesse is a hot-looking 17-year old
column52: is motivated (one supposes) by romance rather than cash
column53: and his offer is
column54: in effect
column55: being made to the young female who is the target audience of this book.    I have no need to say how this latter plot thread resolves itself.  In the end
column56: the moral of the story is ambiguous.  There is a lot of preaching about the curse of immortality
column57: and the virtue of remaining a part of the life cycle

column59: or that
column60: if we should find it

column1: It is true that most trading systems whether rigorously conceived or whimsical will generate at least momentary profits. However
column2: this books disguises a whimsical trading system with nebulously defined rules as something derived from the rules of probability. While few popular books follow the rigor of a financial engineering text
column3: this book is appalling. Not only could this have been written in ten pages
column4: but those ten pages are not worth reading. The language of the market is statistics but a rigorous introductory text is the way to go rather than the appealing but false illusion of "high-probability setups". Mr. Toshchakov should consider how much of his performance is luck. Learning to trade successfully in the markets requires a firm backing in finance. Your money would be better spent on a subscription to The Econonmist or Financial Times
column5: than on Mr. Toschchakov's next Jaguar.

column1: If mind-bending thrillers like Basic Instinct prove anything

column3: nothing much happens of this premise. We never find ourselves feeling for the agent or his liege. No romantic overtures with dangerous undertones. No edge of the seat interactions ala Sharon Stone films of the early 90s. Instead

column4: a portrait and his biography plus every other major builder on the planet.  Reviewed by Terry Roorda  QUOTE  Dated photos gleaned from the collection of photographer Michael Lichter combine with perfunctory prose by writer Mike Seate to bring us "Choppers: Heavy Metal Art
column5: a shameless effort to cash in on the current chopper craze by using the exact format found in the highly acclaimed and successful Art of the Chopper" by Tom Zimberoff. That's it in nutshell
column6: folks. The similarities in physical size
column7: style and content between this work and Zimberoff's are striking to say the very least: A fat highly- produced coffee table book that examines a roster of custom bike builders through portraiture
column8: some biographical verbiage and studio photos of some of their creations.  That's where the similarities end. In the execution of that formula
column9: Zimberoff's "Art of the Chopper" is fresh and literate while "Choppers: Heavy Metal Art" is stale and sophomoric. Seate's writing is lackluster at its best and painfully awkward most of the time
column10: reading like the first draft of a work being produced on contract and on deadline. In three of the early vignettes in the book we are informed that "Colorado's Arlin Fatland has what you might call a wicked sense of humor
column11: and that Pat Kennedy of Tombstone
column12: Arizona
column13: is what you might call seriously old school
column14: and that Nothing about Kodlin's motorcycles is what you might call tradition- al." These excerpts are what you might call bad writing; the type of tedious template prose so devoid of creativity and enthusiasm for the subject matter that any editor worth the name would kick it back in disgust and demand another go. That's assuming there was an editor involved at all
column15: and judging from the wealth of typos and awkward usages found in this book
column16: there's little reason to believe there was. A truly ironic typo comes early in the going when in Seate's acknowledgments he pens this gem: "to Almetta
column17: for never letting us forget the value of the wirtten word." Yes
column18: folks
column19: it says "wirtten." How's that for value?  Here's some other stuff that made me wince: "Looking like a cross between a scene from a concert by gangsta rappers Insane Clown Posse and a Felliniesque circus nightmare
column20: Johnson's paint schemes grab a viewer's attention and hold it rapt for hours." Hunh? Or how about this stinker: "These self-anointed keepers of the hardtail faith congregate in Internet chat rooms and in the letters pages of custom motorcycle-enthusiast magazines to heap dis and envy on builders who aren't afraid to move the art of the custom motorcycle into the twenty-first century." Ouch.  There's plenty more where those came from. And the tragic thing about it is that Mike Seate is usually a competent and entertaining writer-and probably the most prolific wordsmith in the genre. Therein may lie the problem. This volume represents Seate's fifth book with the word "chopper" in the title
column21: and four of those
column22: including this one
column23: were published in the span of less than a year and a half. Who wouldn't get burned out? The upside of "Choppers: Heavy Metal Art" are the images furnished by renowned biker photographer Michael Lichter
column24: a man with one of the most impressive resumés in the industry. As always
column25: his photos are luminous
column26: and anyone familiar with his work in Easyriders magazine over the past couple of decades will recognize his style
column27: but there's a problem here as well. These photos apparently came straight out of his existing inventory of bike feature shots
column28: and many were taken years ago
column29: going back as far as 1992. When you're making the case for custom bike building being a vibrant and dynamic craft in an exciting period of change
column30: growth and popularity
column31: wouldn't you want the timeliest material you could bring to the premise? Other complaints in this regard are that the names of the featured bikes are not provided
column32: though they're often referred to in the copy
column33: and the sparse technical data given for each consists only of frame style (rigid; Softail- type) and engine style (Panhead; Evolution-type)
column34: which are obvious attributes to anyone the least bit familiar with the subject
column35: and of little or no educational value to those who aren't. Those criticisms aside
column36: we have to understand that doing this book right would have taken some time
column37: and clearly the publisher wanted to get into the market before Christmas with a product that would hopefully piggy- back on the success of "Art of the Chopper." That's understandable
column38: if not admirable
column39: from a business stand- point. From a creative standpoint it's disastrous. END QUOT

column1: I'm a huge Jeffery Deaver fan and until this book had never read one of his tomes that I didn't absolutely love. Bloody River Blues was anything but spectacular in my opinion and it was a struggle to even get to the end.   Character development was fair but not the usual style I've come to enjoy from Deaver. I never really knew John Pellam like an intimate friend and was only given tidbits of information about him. Along the way a few more scraps were thrown out but most seemed unimportant. Subcharacters were also underdeveloped - even the villain was so underdeveloped that when the identity was known it was anticlimactic. One of my favorite characters was the paralyzed cop but his story was often short changed - his doctor could have been developed to give so much more to the story but she never was and it left me lacking enthusiasm for the storyline. And his chanting
column2: nutsy wife could have been fun but again she was almost mentioned in passing and nothing more said.   The main plot was fair but not something that would grab the reader and not let go. In fact
column3: I kept putting this book down and it was difficult to muddle my way through it. The subplots were tossed in with no clear reason behind them. For example
column4: the subplot that has John Pellam trying to sell his own movie script so he can make it into a film himself had me scratching my head and saying
column5: "So what!" I really didn't care and didn't see what relevance it had in the big picture. The other subplots were similar and left me wondering why they took up page space.   Overall this book was just a tad below average but for a Jeffery Deaver book to even be average is a very unusual thing. His books usually grab me from the beginning and I lose sleep trying to finish them. If anything
column6: BLOODY RIVER BLUES put me to sleep! I'd definitely skip this one and read anything else by Deaver.

column1: I imagine there are some useful and perhaps even good ideas here. But the entire text is so self-obsessed that it's hard to see beyond the "travelogue" conceit. I watched it once with my daughter, and ended up covering her eyes for portions of this film.  For me, I kinda liked it, but I won't watch it very often.  For my daughter, I wouldn't want her to watch it again

column1: Where's the subtitle of this very effective book?  Did the modern editors simply take it away?  Darwin titled his book: "The Origin of Species by Means of Natural Selection" and subtitled it: "The Preservation of Favoured Races in the Struggle for Life."  When Hitler came to power in 1933
column2: he had one overarching idea in mind: his radical Nazi racial philosophy built on the Darwinian principle of natural selection.  Hilter thought the Aryans were the fittest and he wanted to help speed up the "inevitability" of natural selection.  He first started off with the sterilization of nine categories of "the unfit" which were feebleminded
column3: schizophrenia
column4: manic depression
column5: Huntington's chorea
column6: epilepsy
column7: hereditary body deformities
column8: deafness
column9: hereditary blindness and alcoholism.  He then worked his way up to attempting the complete extermination of entire categories and entire races of people.  Speaking of modern day little Hitlers
column10: the Columbine High School shooters carried out their bloody rampage on Hilter's birthday
column11: April 20th
column12: and had planned on causing more than 500 deaths at the high school.  Shooter Eric Harris had written on his website
column13: "YOU KNOW WHAT I LOVE??? Natural SELECTION!  It's the best thing that ever happened to the Earth.  Getting rid of all the stupid and weak organisms."  After the bloody rampage
column14: Harris' autopsy report revealed that he was wearing a T-shirt with the words "Natural Selection" emblazoned on the front.  Beware of those who hold this book dear to their hearts.  This book is not about man descending from the apes.  The ideas in this book have caused and continue to cause more deaths than any other notion in modern history

column1: Overall
column2: the book is fairly well written and easy to follow.  The recommendations (dietary and other) would probably be helpful...if indeed your problems are due to elevated cortisol levels.  However
column3: on pgs. 78-79
column4: the author makes the serious mistake of discouraging the use of hormone testing to determine actual cortisol levels.  Instead
column5: he recommends that you use his questionnaire (pg. xvi) as your sole guideline.  Unfortunately
column6: most of those questions deal with general stressors which nearly everyone experiences
column7: along with other general health related questions.  The point is
column8: anyone could get a high score on this questionnaire
column9: including those with high cortisol; low cortisol; fibromyalgia; chronic fatigue syndrome
column10: and any number of other ailments.  This creates a very serious problem
column11: because if someone with low levels of cortisol (common in CFS
column12: for instance) were to take some of the supplements that the author recommends
column13: that person's already weak adrenal glands would be depleted even further
column14: with potentially catastrophic consequences.  So
column15: my recommendation is to read this book with an open mind
column16: but definitely get your cortisol levels tested (contrary to the author's opinion
column17: salivary cortisol testing has proven quite reliable) before using any of the herbs or other supplements suggested.

column5: uneducated individuals.  This is very far from the truth.  There are a number of economic reasons why rural Americans SHOULD vote for Republicans. 1.  The poorness of rural Americans is overstated.  People that study these cleavages, such as Jeffrey Stonecash, contend (correctly) that the economic struggle in areas have been exaggerated."  This is due to the ultraliberal rejection of the relative cost of living.  Which will cost more: living in northern New Jersey
column6: or living in Wyoming?  Obviously in New Jersey
column7: where almost everything (except for maybe Haagen-Dazs) is more expensive. 2.  Rural self-images are not readily understood by liberals.  Many rural residents are either self-employed or work under few people.  This results in an emphasis on individualism and self-gain
column8: which is a tenet of economic conservatism.  Additionally
column9: which goes along with the lack of poorness argumet
column10: rural Americans are much more likely to own land and therefore are supportive of Republican measures that help landowners.  Jeffery Stonecash
column11: who has widely studied the ideas of the split between groups in American society
column12: completely omits this from his book
column13: "Split."  This is not to say that Stonecash has completely ignored the issue
column14: because his article "The Rural Side of the Urban-Rural Gap" studies the issue in-depth and actually refutes Frank's narrow and hasty argument.  The assumption that Republicans have victimized rural Americans and duped these poor "suckers" into voting for them is absolutely atrocious.  What has happened since the 1960s (with the civil rights movement and evangelical movement) and especially since the early 1980s (with the emergence of Ronald Reagan and his emphasis on cultural issues
column15: particularly abortion and traditional family values) is a greater emphasis on cultural rather than class issues.  Class issues (defined by economics) have remained generally the same and the views on these has not changed much among the parties.  Cultural issues
column16: on the other hand
column17: tend to polarize voters more.  The differences in rural and urban voters cannot be attributed to economics alone.  Women in rural districts are less likely to vote
column18: so there is less voting for Democrats.  There are fewer minorities in rural areas
column19: so Democratic votes are lower.  There are fewer secularists in rural America
column20: so voting for Republicans is higher.  From these arguments we can see that economics is not the only force driving rural Americans to vote for Republicans.  The emergence of cultural
column21: rather than class
column22: issues have caused a shift in votes to the Republicans in rural districts.  In some cases
column23: the Republican party actually is MORE attractive to rural landowners who have a sense of individualism

column1: Considering that the Edith Wharton novel on which this movie is based is a literary masterpiece
column2: I expected more from the filmmaking. I imagined it would be a tasty adaptation  along the lines of the marvelous "Age of Innocence." But this movie disappoints sorely.  For starters
column3: the two lead actors are just plain wrong. The actor playing Lawrence Seldon has an effeminate voice that negates him as a convincing love interest. And as a character
column4: he is dull and conservative
column5: not the thinking
column6: lawyerly man of the world we know from the book.   Other problems with this adaptation: Gus Trenor isn't alcoholic enough; Sim Rosedale isn't Jewish enough. Worse
column7: the actress who plays the tragic Lily Bart is a hollerer. When she's not pouting
column8: she's hollering her lines. The emotional scenes get louder and louder
column9: just when the viewer would be most affected by subtlety. Sashaying prettily out a door in an expensive dress does not replace good acting.  True
column10: the settings are plush and the costumes are wonderful. But the settings are sooo consistantly plush that one wonders where the non-rich people are hiding. In Wharton's novel
column11: there is contrast. Seldon's cousin lived in an unpretentious apartment  and was involved with social work amongst down and out women.   But this movie combines Seldon's  cousin with Grace Stepney
column12: the rich aunt's beneficiary.  So we never see this contrasting life in the movie
column13: and hence
column14: Lily isn't given the opportunity to redeem herself by showing  kindnes to the disadvantaged. And two  important  characters are rolled into one
column15: which eliminates complexity and serves to soap-opera-ize the movie even more.   Good points? I liked the rich aunt. She was believable
column16: despite being situated in a house too rich for her situation. I also liked the Grace Stepney character. With her hair down
column17: she was convincingly heartbroken. And the tour guide girlfriend of Lily's was nicely done. And so were other minor characters
column18: including George Dorset.   It's a shame that the poor editing or poor acting or whatever it was of the two primary characters served to slaughter this tragic drama so pitifully. I had a dificult time  finding the patience to watch it through it to the end.   While people who enjoy soap opera-like historic romances may like this movie
column19: if you're an Edith Wharton fan
column20: you'll definitely be disappointed. I recommend watching "Age of Innocence" again
column21: and skipping this one

column1: If you are afraid that sociopaths are learning effective ways to kill
column2: then this book will put your fears to rest. One of Minnery's suggestions is to find out what hotel room your target is staying in. Then rent two  hospital X-ray machines and position them in the two rooms adjacent to the  target's room. Aim them through the walls at his bed and crank them on. The  target will die of leukemia. The only practical method in his entire How To  Kill series was Hatchet To The Medulla. If these books were required  reading for every would-be killer in America the homicide rate would drop  considerably

Back in the beginning of the extreme music genesis
column2: these guys were one of the pioneers of extreme music.  They certainly weren't any of the forms of extreme metal and they certainly weren't punk.  Unfortunately
column3: they were put into the alternative category which was a catch-all for music that was basically pop while supposedly rejecting the "mainstream sound".  That's right The Butthole Surfers were stuck in the category that cursed the world with Nirvana / Nine Inch Nails / Ministry / Smashing Pumpkins garbage.  Oh
column4: that reminds me
column5: it cursed the 80s with all those hideous Sub-Pop label bands.  Still there were a few "alternative" bands that were quite good.  Only the Surfers and Big Black come to mind though.  Their live shows were incredible.  Flashing movie clips flashed strange scenes in the back ground including sex change operation footage.  The singer constantly lit his hand on fire for some reason (as if it were a big dangerous stunt)
column6: naked women danced on stage
column7: and a certain song they used a huge tuba.  Their two best albums were Hairway to Steven and Locust Abortion Technician but some of the earlier ones could be considered as good as these two.  There song styles varied from song to song.  They would have crazy fast songs such as Human Cannonball or really slow drugged out songs such as 22 going on 23 with a depressed radio talk show clip played in the background.  They would also utilize oriental sounds modified in their own weird style on the classic Kuntz(spelling).  We also got the weird rantings on "Johnny Smokes" who was a "crippled midget lesbian boy who stood ten foot tall WITH A KNIFE!"  Well
column8: they got to be pretty popular and appeared on the alternative music fest tour Lollapalooza and soon after actually got signed to a major label.  The last I heard probably over 10 years old was some songs off of the major label release "Independent Worm Saloon".  They had seriously sold out their style degenerating in a more acceptable mainstream sound.  I hadn't paid attention for these many years but recently checked out this Weird Revolution.    This has got to be one of the most extreme sell-out jobs ever.  I can't think of a worse bit of conforming to please mainstream record labels hoping for success.  I have seen plenty and most of them quite bad but I honestly can't think of any that tops this.  This is the kind of pumping technopop you see in bad movies.  What happened?   I am not aware of how popular these guys have become or not but it is one of the saddest falls of a great band I have ever known

column1: William Dembski is one of the great names in the Intelligent Design-movement.  He holds a Ph.D. in mathematics and philosophy
column2: and have earned grades in theology an psychology. When such a man writes a book and call it "Intelligent Design - The bridge between science & theology" I had great expectations that he had succeeded in making this important bridge.  I think  you can read this book in at least two ways.  One
column3: as an introduction to how the leading people behind this movement think
column4: and for such a presentation I give the book 4 stars.  Dembski is very good at using interesting parables to illustrate his arguments.  But as a bridge between science and theology it is totally failing.  And that is sad because the probability for Intelligent Design is in fact high as Dembski shows us
column5: but Dembski mess it up through most of his book.  As science I give this book 1 star and end up with a compromise at 2 stars.  Dembski uses much space to general logic.  As to show that if you have two similar books containing the same Shakespeare-play
column6: these two books doesn't have any more information together than one of the books alone.  OK. And so what?  After pages with such stuff you begin to be impatience and wonder how and when will all this logical stuff be used to prove Intelligent Design?  And then
column7: as you have waited and waited
column8: Dembski finally writes that it is not space in this chapter (and not in other chapters either)to explain the Big Bang by his Intelligent Design theories.  What a disappointment.  Couldn't he instead have skipped some of the logic?  But after a while you understand that Dembski actually lacks any intentions to reveal the most basic things that normally should have concerned Intelligent Design.  He claims that intelligence leaves behind a characteristic signature in nature
column9: and that these signatures are observable.  Why can't he tell us what this observable signatures are? He writes that God's fingerprints in nature are imperically detectible. But how? Why wont he tell us?   Dembski writes that something is made by intelligence when it can show both complexity and specification.  Ink spelt on a paper can show some complexity in pattern
column10: but it is not specified before the ink spells letters and words with meaning.  He then uses this criteria for intelligent design in nature
column11: and call it science and a proof of Intelligent Design when nature is both complex and specified. But can you prove God this way?  I think you only can believe in Intelligent Design
column12: and that a strong probability for God never fully can prove Him anyway. Dembski does not try to prove God either
column13: he just confirm that God exists because he have seen him in nature as the result of intelligent design.  No one can criticise you for believing in an intelligent designer
column14: but if you want to make this belief into science
column15: it is not enough just to call it science
column16: as Dembski does.  You have to fullfill certain criteria and rules to call something science.  Dembski dosen't follow these rules at all.    Dembski spend much of his time in this book to criticise others for not being scientific
column17: often just because they don't accept Intelligent Design as science.  He says that naturalism is metaphysic
column18: and not science based on evidence.  If he had used his own definitions he uses on others
column19: the Intelligent Design he presents wouldn't either be scientific.      He neither seems to remember what he wrote some pages earlier. After "proving" that Christ was the Logo by which the world was created
column20: he later writes that Intelligent Design not necessarily must have originated from any specifically god at all. Are you confused like me?  An interesting objection to the kind of Intelligent Design that Dembski presents
column21: namely that God interacts and design the nature all the time
column22: is why then He design crippled people
column23: hiv-virus an so on all the time?  Dembski just brush those with such objections off by calling them unscientific. If Dembski instead had advocated that God started it all by "shooting a billiard ball" with a very precision
column24: that interacted with other "balls" that fine-tuned the universe and started the evolution that eventually ended up with the complicated human being
column25: Dembski could have accepted naturalism as well as Intelligent Design
column26: and then nature could have been responsible
column27: at least in some way
column28: for it's mishaps instead of blaming God
column29: as Dembskis theories leads towards
column30: though he denies it.  In this book Dembski claims to represent
column31: among others
column32: the 90 % of the people in the United States who believe that some kind of transcendent force created the world. I believe the same
column33: but fear that books like this more destroy than helps to make a bridge between science and theology.

column1: If you want my review in a nutshell
column2: here it is: Two Defective Rise & Shine Lamps. One Call to Verilux. Verilux Refuses to Help.  If you wish to learn how this sorry state of affairs came to pass
column3: read on.   My Verilux Product Experience:  I exchanged my first Verilux Rise and Shine Natural Alarm Clock & Bedside Lamp due to a non-functional internal speaker
column4: ostensibly from loose wires that were shaken loose during shipping (if I am to understand the Verilux' company president's response to a similar defect report in these reviews). The good news: The speaker in the second unit now works. And contrary to some of the other reviewers I feel the Mylar speaker sounds quite good -- although dual stereo speakers would have been an even better choice (with a line-in jack for CD player or iPod). The bad: Despite the jumbo LCD display that might lead you to assume that the AM/FM tuner is digital
column5: the radio is completely analog. The station IDs are printed in roughly 7-point type on the tuning dial instead -- small enough that some owners will need their glasses AND a magnifying glass to select a radio station. By contrast
column6: I own an alarm clock by Conair with a similar analog tuner
column7: with the exception that it uses roughly 8-point LCD digits to represent the radio frequency in the lower right-hand corner of the backlit LCD display. On Verilux' comparatively enormous LCD
column8: I am left to wonder why the design team failed to consider that option. An analog tuner without a station display is something I expect from a $15 drugstore alarm clock
column9: but not from a product of this type
column10: which is otherwise very well thought out.  Unfortunately
column11: due to an apparent flaw in the shade and/or the lamp itself
column12: the shade on my replacement lamp -- the lamp I received from the store in exchange -- won't sit straight! One can remove the shade
column13: look at the lamp on a level surface
column14: and see the lamp "shelf" slope downward such that the shade itself also is similarly slanted! Making the situation worse
column15: the lampshade is also slightly off insofar as the ring is not centered. There are three metal supports attached at the top of the shade that are bent downward and welded to a ring that sits about half way down (as typical of most lampshades). The ring
column16: in turn
column17: sits on the lamp body (or shelf). The whole assembly is cockeyed
column18: including the socket into which the bulb sets (at a VERY obvious angle)!   Cosmetically speaking
column19: there are also problems that are surprising to see in a product of this type. Whereas the first lamp I purchased has a very prominent nick in the plastic edge alongside the LCD panel
column20: the replacement lamp has a scratch in the ivory plastic lamp body about an inch below the shade shelf
column21: and it
column22: too
column23: must have been obtained in manufacturing.   As for the shade itself
column24: it came out of the plastic wrap with a beige blemish
column25: roughly 3/4"
column26: that looks like a pale stain against the bright white linen. So while the second lamp did not have a DOA speaker
column27: I apparently traded one problem in for another. Worse
column28: the lamp appears lopsided even from the opposite side of the room (and would probably appear that way from down the street if I were to set it on the curb). In short
column29: the Verilux Rise & Shine lamp is just not up to the quality that the price/warranty suggests. And in case you are wondering if this might have been "gray market" merchandise
column30: it wasn't. I purchased my Rise & Shine lamp straight out of a high-end
column31: authorized retail store
column32: new-in-box.   The AM/FM clock radio paired to the sunrise-simulating full-spectrum light
column33: finished off by the eight high-quality digital nature sounds -- contained in a space-saving design roughly 6.5" wide at the base and 20" tall -- makes for an outstanding combination and concept. For this reason
column34: I hope Verilux will continue to refine the Rise and Shine model
column35: particularly where quality control is concerned.   Given that I am a gadget fan
column36: and someone who has rated products 1/5th the price of this lamp very highly
column37: it should be understood that I really wanted to give this a positive review. But two duds in a row?  IRONY  The Rise & Shine user manual emphatically instructs consumers to contact Verilux directly instead of returning defective products to the retailer. Given that my replacement lamp is also defective
column38: I followed these instructions. But in reality
column39: Verilux wants defective merchandise to become the retailers' problem
column40: not theirs (as per the instruction I received to make a THIRD 40-mile trip back to the store where I purchased it). Conclusion?  VERILUX DOESN'T BACK THEIR WARRANTY (in my experience/opinion).  Nor
column41: apparently
column42: does Verilux care what kind of impression they leave on first-time customers. So if you think the impressive three-year warranty will help you if something should go wrong
column43: consider what happened less than 72 hours into my ownership experience. And believe me
column44: there was no rudeness involved to provoke this kind of reaction on the part of Verilux' customer service department
column45: either.  What Verilux has apparently forgotten is that this is the age of the Internet. As it so happens
column46: I supplement my income writing product reviews for Websites. In fact
column47: I am a writer by training/trade. Translation: Verilux chose the wrong customer to let down. I have no intention of smearing Verilux' reputation -- unless telling the truth and nothing but the truth about my experience qualifies as such.  Would I recommend this product to a friend? Yesterday I might have said yes
column48: chalking up the non-operative speaker in the first lamp to a fluke. Today
column49: coupled with the fact that Verilux seemingly does not wish to stand behind their products even when it would take a mere lampshade to keep a customer happy
column50: my answer is a resounding NO.  Should anyone at Verilux read my review
column51: I wish to close with this thought: I could have learned to live with the cosmetic problems I noted
column52: but a ~$5 lampshade
column53: to replace the one that was blemished right out of the box -- and doesn't sit straight
column54: to boot -- is that not worth keeping a first-time customer happy?

column1: The only helpful thing in this book was the description of the five types.  This does provide a framework for analyzing different position.  The types could have been defined in a much shorter work.    The book does not offer clear Biblical argumentaion for or against differnt views.  One flaw (which is apparently common in Liberal theology) is that he talks about the New testament writers postions as if they were contrary and not complementary to each other.  For example he talks about Pauline and Johanine Theology as if they had separate
column2: and contradictory on some points
column3: views.   With each view Neibhur talks about a few historical people who have held this view.  These people are for the most part extremist who have taken one idea and thrown out the rest of the Bible. The majority of them were heretics.  The association of each view with some very extreme exponents of it may give the conservative Christian the impression that the view itself is heretical (Which it may or may not be).    More work needs to be done on this subject with Biblical argumentation for the different views.    If in reading this book you are (as I was) attempting to develop a Biblical theology of Christ and Culture I believe you will find it a dissapointment.

 Not worth the money as a technical reference or how-to book. Otherwise a pleasant read with some inpired pics and a very general overview of the process. Speaks, for the most part, to strawbale contruction as if strawbales are some naturally occurring thing harvested from the wild when are in fact a product of energy intensive industrial agriculture.  Fails to provide important technical details such as estimating for coverage, application on masonry, frame and other 'natural' structures, guidelines for plaster preparation. If you already have building experience and skills there are far better reference books available to actually base work upon.

column1: First off let me say that I am a huge fan of Cameron Crowe (read my review of vanilla sky if you don't believe me). Now let me tell you why this movie didn't work for me. 1.  The plot is almost a direct rip off of his previous movie
column2: Jerry Maguire:  Guy has nice job
column3: loses nice job
column4: gets depressed
column5: finds girl to change said depression. 2.  The acting is barely worth noticing.  Orlando Bloom does not make for a good narrative voice.  Kirsten Dunst was trying so hard to be quirky that she loses all appeal. 3.  The emotion was not there.  We are supposed to feel sorry for Orlando Blooms character (I actually can't remember his charcters name) but he conveys nothing that allows me to feel sorry for him.    AND THIS IS IS THE BIGGEST PROBLEM  4.  The music.  He has never failed to deliver a great soundtrack in the past with each and every movie he released
column6: but the problem with this one is that he tried to build a movie around the soundtrack instead of vice versa.  He misuses the songs that he chooses and he overuses songs altogether.  What he attempted to do was to evoke an emotion by inserting a song into a scene.  This doesn't work if the scene doesn't work.  What made his other movies so great was he allowed the music to reinforce the emotion of a scene
column7: but what he has done here is tried to make the music the only emotion there
column8: which doesn't have as much of an impact.   Three Tom Petty songs is too many for one movie (and I love Tom Petty).  Two Ryan Adams song is also too many for one movie.  If you oversaturate a movie with music
column9: then it starts to lose all its luster.  Cameron Crowe didn't trust his actors to deliver the emotion so he relied on the music. 4(a).  The music he didn't use.  During the road trip part of the movie the viewer gets to see part of the song list that he is listening to.  The list included songs by:  Red House Painters
column10: Sun Kil Moon and Nick Cave just to name a few
column11: but we never hear these songs anywhere in the movie.  Hey Cameron
column12: couldn't you have replaced just on Tom Petty song with a Sun Kil Moon song?  Salvador Sanchez is a great song and it was on the playlist
column13: so why didn't you use it?  Did you not trust the listeners to appreciate that type of song?  I guess what I'm saying is

column1: I just finished McCarthy's book
column2: The Road
column3: last night and frankly I have to totally agree with a. reader's (Upstate New York) comments.  Indeed
column4: it must be nice to be a recognized
column5: award winning author and get away with anything you write.  When I read the reviews and the flap of the book I was interested enough to buy and read it.  I'll be off to Half Price Books as soon as possible to at least recover some of the money I lost in buying this book.  I was led to believe the story would provide this "awesome" connection between a father and his son.  The conversations between these two are absurd with one and two word sentences.  One "Five Star" reviewer called this a "poignant story of love between father and son."  PLEASE
column6: give me a break
column7: most siblings have more than two word sentences between themselves and their father.  There is no doubt these two are traveling through horrendous times
column8: but McCarthy's description of the terrain is pathetic and redundant.  By the way
column9: how did these guys survive up to the point of when the book begins
column10: supposedly seven or eight years later?  What happen to the people who owned the storm cellar?  Leaving the storm cellar with all of its provisions was preposterous.  How did the father obtain additional bullets after only having one following the shooting?  The bullets he found were the wrong caliber.  Too many gaps and inconsistencies.    When I finally reached the end of the story
column11: I was completely disappointed.  The son had to be the luckiest person on the planet.  It seemed as if McCarthy had reached a deadline with Knopf Publisher and he had to wrap-up the manuscript instead of ending with some sort of a conclusion.  This was the most unrealistic story of a post "unknown disaster" I believe I have ever read.  This book is a TOTAL WASTE OF TIME AND MONEY unless you happen to be someone who reads McCarthy's writings regardless of what he writes.  Maybe the "Five Star" reviewers are running interference for McCarthy's weak excuse for a story.  If I were the CEO of Knopf Publisher
column12: I would be asking a lot of questions about the publishing of this book.   Bottomline
column13: if you are a devoted fan of McCarthy's buy the book and fall in line with all the "Five Star" reviewers; otherwise
column14: don't waste your time or money.  PS:  When did we start spelling couldn't as couldnt

column6: we see that this later universality has for its content restless individuality
column7: which regards opinion or mere individualism as law
column8: the real as unreal
column9: and the unreal as real.  That universality is
column10: however
column11: at the same time the side of realization of the ordinance
column12: for to it belongs the independent self-existence (Fursichseyn) of individuality.  The other side is the universal in the sense of stable passive essence; but
column13: for that very reason
column14: the absolutely non-existent
column15: but still not an actual reality
column16: and can itself only become actual by canceling the individuality
column17: that has presumed to claim actuality.  This type of consciousness
column18: which becomes aware of  itself in the law; which finds itself in what is inherently true and good not as mere individual
column19: but only as essentially real; and which knows individuality to be what is perverted and perverting
column20: and hence feels bound to surrender and sacrifice individualism of consciousness - this type of consciousness is Virtue."   ...   "The mood of moral sentimentalism is reduced to confusion and contradiction: but the subjective individualism in which it is rooted is not yet eradicated.  Individualism now takes refuge in another attitude which claims to do greater justice to the inherent universality of rational self-realization....  The World's course is this to owe its goodness to the efforts of the individual.  A struggle ensues
column21: for the situation is contradictory; and the issue of the struggle goes to prove that the individual is not the fons et origo boni
column22: that goodness does not await his efforts
column23: and that in fact the course of the world is at heart good; the soul of the world is righteous.   "The attitude analyzed here is that of abstract moral idealism
column24: the mood of moral strenuousness
column25: the mood that constantly seeks the improvement and perfectibility of mankind.  It is found in many forms

column47: and finally to find the relation of the individual conscious entity to the Absolute Being

This special and peculiar wisdom of enlightenment necessarily seems at the same time to the believing mind to be sheer insipidity and the confession of insipidity; because it consists in knowing nothing of absolute Being

column1: I agree with David Thomson when he says few audiences in the West would be content to view an American epic composed solely of battles and their contexts. Kurosawa was a keen businessman and his reputation in the West was entrenched with "Kagemusha" and "Ran"
column2: he knew what (American) audiences think of as heroic and mystical about "historical" Japan: Kurosawa's art takes a great deal on its impetus from what Americans (or Westerners) imagine about Japan. column3: hence the suicide attempt). I am not saying that the work is rubbish - there is no "ugly" shot in either "Ran" or "Kag" - merely that there are more "authentically Japanese" films out there to choose from.

column1: Before you read the book
column2: look at the sources.  I only found one scientific paper out of hundreds of sources. Everything else has to be classified as opinions.  Sources for this book  include news stories and testimonies in congress.  I will point out by two examples (not from the book
column3: but from information that you are probably familiar with) why these are not good sources. I recall the news stories based on the opinions of experts that said it would take five years to put out the oil well fires started in the first Gulf War.  They were all wrong.  It took six months.  CEO's and others testified before congress about tobacco products being non-addictive.  Were they correct? No! So when we read this book
column4: we can't be sure of anything.  It is a book of opinions and ideas.  Some of them may be good
column5: but they may also be bad.  This is why we have science and the scientific method.  Even science may be corrupted at times or fail until we have a better understanding. Even if Mr. Gore had scientific papers
column6: it is unlikely that he could judge whether they really support his environmental views.  He would need a Ph.D. or at least a lot of experience in the proper field(s) to interpret scientific papers properly.  This book discusses how corporations are unfriendly to the environment. Surely some of them are.  But so is the government.  When the government plant at Fernald
column7: Ohio
column8: (near Cincinnati) was accused of poluting the soil and water with radioactive waste
column9: the government denied
column10: dragged its feet
column11: and fought in court. The government lost it case because there was obvious guilt
column12: but the government did not hestitate to fight against the very people it represents. When you or I appear to be at fault in an auto accident
column13: do we admit it and offer to pay all claims
column14: or do we take a less candid approach as our insurance company suggests?  We might even think we are not at fault. Mr. Gore has denied being at fault countless times in his political career
column15: but he can't believe that a corporation should do anything but admit guilt
column16: accept every environmental claim that is made
column17: and pay large sums of money.  Mr. Gore is an elitist.  First
column18: he believes that he is an environmental expert because he has heard a lot of opinions. He doesn't need an advanced degree in environmental science  or experience in that field.  He just knows better because he is Al Gore. Secondly
column19: he sees how he uses the environment and how you should use the environment quite differently.  When he was Vice President
column20: he flew to Kyoto
column21: Japan
column22: to symbolically (read unnecessary trip) approve the Kyoto Treaty.  He used more than 180
column23: 000 gallons of fuel in a private government plane in one day.  My wife and I can drive our cars and heat our house for our lifetimes and never use this amount of fuel.  During his Presidental campaign
column24: Mr. Gore would fly a private jet to his son's games.  I have no great objection to the former Vice President doing these things as long as he doesn't start telling me how I am abusing the environment
column25: that I should drive an electric car
column26: ...  I do have trouble believing his environmental views are anything but political.  If you like the views in the book
column27: read it and feel good.  If you don't like the views

column1: To be sure
column2: there are some intriguing speculations in this book
column3: such as the one concerning the distinction between the historic Jesus of Nazareth and the Christ
column4: and the  --- not all that novel  --- analysis of the Jewish Tanakh and of the two Christian Testaments purely as literary texts. These speculations
column5: if properly stretched
column6: could fill a quaint fifty minute lecture. But to keep holding forth for the full two-hundred-some pages it takes to fill a book
column7: of necessity takes Harold Bloom out of his depth
column8: to where the same quite trivial points are being repeated over and over. Obsessive repetition would not be out of place in a religious text
column9: but in a literary analysis it signals careless editing and/or a dearth of ideas.  Bloom informs the reader that he worships neither at Yahweh's nor at the Christian God's altar. Instead
column10: we catch him worshipping at William Shakespeare's admittedly superb altar; indeed he acts as if he were the bard's latter day grand ayatollah. He keeps telling the reader and then forever reminding him
column11: that in this capacity he has the biblical characters paired with Shakespearean characters
column12: Jesus with the Danish prince Hamlet and Yahweh with the erratic King Lear. Hamlet and Lear appearing in different plays
column13: do not get to exchange any dialogue
column14: and wouldn't you know
column15: nor do their biblical counterparts
column16: just arias
column17: no duets.   By the author's reckoning
column18: the historic Jesus was the greatest "Jewish genius" before Sigmund Freud of all people. This does not deter Bloom from issuing the additional fatwa that Freud's oedipal take on the Danish prince is all hogwash. For all anyone knows
column19: this may even be so. I
column20: for one
column21: find the oedipal interpretation of Hamlet more amusing than convincing.  Bloom however doesn't even amuse
column22: nor does he bother to present any convincing arguments in his refutation of Freud. But then
column23: fatwas will be fatwas and
column24: in all fairness
column25: Bloom never claims to be a "Jewish genius."

column1: Zulakika's Basque Violence is a confusing and chaotic work which attempts to examine the cultural background to the question of why a terroristic form of violence haunts the Basque people.  The works' shortcomings are abundant and ubiquitous throughout his writing.  No one outside of the field of ethnography will be able to comprehend the overpowering amount of  ethnographic jargon that inundates Zulakika's work.  His work is also delinquent in the fact that very few readers outside of the Basque culture could understand or find the thesis of the work. The reader feels as if he or she is stuck the eccentric mind of a bedlamite
column2: who is rattling off the hagiology of the Basque culture from the Paleolithic era to modern day. The book is structured in what would appear at first glance to be studies of different areas of Basque culture and its relation to the violence that has been occurring in the area; however
column3: the book fails to accomplish this task as well.  Readers will be greatly disappointed with this work because it does not realize any of the intended goals that the author set for himself work

column1: "I really take Nietzsche to town"--this is a quote from Marilynne Robinson. I heard her say this once at a writer's workshop in Saratoga Springs shortly before this collection
column2: The Death of Adam
column3: was printed. Who would SAY such a thing? It's not that one cannot argue with Nietzsche's thought--but "take him to town"? One may recall Rush Limbaugh
column4: for instance
column5: who
column6: whenever he is under fire for getting someone angry
column7: responds
column8: "That's because I'M RIGHT."   Her book never gets much more intelligent than her quote.   The reviewer who said Robinson has an axe to grind here was right! These essays are well written but often full of a grudging and largely uninformed conservative viewpoint. Like many books that espouse such views
column9: this one seems to see itself as some kind of enlightening  alternative to the "accepted" wisdom about contemporary science and morality. Bosh!     This book was written out of sheer discomfort. Robinson doesn't seem to have given writers such as Darwin and Nietzsche the kind of reading they deserve--that is
column10: the type in which the reader does not immediately discount all ideas that seem like they will lead to undesirable consequences (Nietzsche and Darwin led to Hitler
column11: that kind of tiresome cliche). Come now Marilynne
column12: didn't we get enough of that kind of thing listening to the frat boys argue with the professor in Humanities Seminar back in freshman year? For one who sets out to undermine accepted wisdom
column13: Robinson espouses it in ludicrous amounts.    If you don't happen to agree with Robinson already
column14: most of her thinking will jump out as the usual smokescreen behind which essentially conservative thinkers carry out their specious assault on everything that makes them uncomfortable.

column1: I enjoyed other
column2: more recent
column3: books by William Poundstone and I decided to try this. I was very disappointed. I am sure the fact that the book was written twenty years ago contributes to my disappointment: many subjects present only nostalgic value for some people and mostly outdated. Don't look for revelations - the author is mostly speculating on the subject (secrets mostly will stay secrets). In our time much more and better information could be found on the Internet. I gave it two stars just for some historical data that I found sometimes interesting

column1: I was disappointed with the book. Like the others
column2: the book lost what little integrity I was willing to give it to start when Catherine said she lived in 1863 BC. Given that the author repeatedly states that he is a traditionally-trained medical professional
column3: his material is starkly lacking in any kind of verifiable fact or scientific questioning. The book reads like a personal diary of someone who is searching for meaning in his life rather than a case study. I think the thing that bothered me the most is that it is obvious he uses the patient for his own purposes in sessions that he allows to go on for hours on end to await messages from the Masters. Seems unethical to me (a lesson he must still need to learn.) I thought it especially odd that the first other professional he brings into to observe a session is his wife and not an objective colleague.  I read many of the reviews below and I like what one said about past lives recollection being born from the mental garbage of the Earth. That seems more likely. I encourage you to keep searching for the truth. Do not settle for the soul candy offered in this book

column1: All the poems are smooth and clever and slightly (or more than slightly) ironic.  They sometimes make me smile
column2: but they seldom make me feel much.    I was recently at a poetry reading Collins gave
column3: where he was greatly applauded.  He mentioned that sentimentality is a cardinal sin in poetry.  That's true.  But I couldn't emotionally connect to the self-consciously witty voices speaking out of his poems
column4: and by the end of this collection I didn't really want to.  When I first read Collins
column5: I was hoping to find the accessible poet illuminating the everyday world I was promised.  Instead
column6: I found an extremely polished poet whose engaging tone almost makes up for his persistent lack of emotional depth.  Sentimentality may be a poetic sin
column7: but sincerity isn't.    Even funny poems should display a little emotional risk.  But Collins never seems to risk anything.  And because he takes small risks
column8: we get small rewards.    Go ahead and get this book.  Read it.  Smile a bit.  Appreciate the cleverness and talent Collins displays.  These poems are likeable
column9: and I wouldn't be surprised if you liked them.  But if you are looking for poetry that will feed you
column10: go somewhere else

column1: This book is WAY past its pull date.  Full of warnings about not calling back the unrecognized number on your pager (pager?)

column3: and how you should shred paperwork with identifying information on it (duh!).  The over-riding assumption is that anyone with something to hide must be a criminal.  The reader is told to vary your hours
column4: commute route
column5: and habits so 'they' can't catch you
column6: because you must be trying to get away with something.  For the rest of us law-abiding types
column7: the message is "privacy is obsolete.  get over it."  Even worse
column8: the author and the ghost-writer (this is one of those books by someone WITH someone else) must have been paid by the word.  It goes on and on and on
column9: just to convey the merest morsel of a factoid.  But worst of all
column10: the author is such a big shot
column11: you're supposed to be really impressed with the names he drops and the James Bond-style exploits he pulled.  He walked right into office buildings after-hours and stole bags of trash!  He staked out the parking lot of the YMCA residence and guessed that the only non-hoopty in the lot belonged to the embezzeler!  He shoulder-surfed the old man in line in front of him at the bank to learn his identity!  Shaken-not-stirred stuff
column12: you bet!  I have a lot of books on my shelf
column13: and I don't mind reading a lot of pages to get a little information.  But this turkey yielded NO information of use
column14: and so it went right back in the box and back to Amazon.

column1: The game itself is very interesting - the storyline is engaging and the controls are unique.  It's an RPG
column2: which is quite a switch for Mario.  The major problem with this game is interactivity - not enough of it.  Specifically
column3: there are far too many cutscenes that are not skippable.  Many of these cutscenes lead directly into a boss battle.  The most frustrating instance of this is just before the final boss battle - it takes about 10 minutes to get to the "real" fight from the prior save point.  This isn't a problem for the first time through the sequence
column4: but if you lose 4 or 5 times
column5: this just becomes a hassle and makes the game not really worth playing to see the end.  This is a major problem that most game designers have found work-arounds for
column6: but Nintendo revealed its lack of RPG experience in this element.  It's an interesting game
column7: but just make sure to win
column8: or have a friend/sibling/(enemy?) skip through the dialog sequences for you if you get tired of them

column1: First of all
column2: I did not exactly 'read' this biography. Instead I purchased the CD version which I distilled via my car sound system every morning on my way to work (I have enjoyed countless biographies of great american figures this way
column3: and still been able to read many more technology related books).  I had great expectations from this book
column4: having recently enjoyed three biographies of Lincoln. I have to confess that I was sorely disapointed. I found the research of Mr McCullough to lack the kind of details that I have enjoyed in biographies from Walter Isaacson
column5: Richard Carwardine
column6: or Doris Goodwin. I do not seek a beautiful story in a biography
column7: but rather a reliable source of facts that I can use to form my own opinion of a character. In this context
column8: I find Mr McCullough's use of superlatives or long emotionally charged sentences to be a distraction from the subject matter of John Adams and his contribution to America. I also enjoy direct quotes from letters
column9: speaches
column10: autobiographies
column11: as they help me refine my impressions of the context (the period
column12: the relationships to contemporary characters
column13: ...) surounding a promonent figure. Usage of the English language in politics has dramatically evolved since Mr Adams' time
column14: and I missed 'hearing' the voice of John Adams. Instead
column15: this biography felt like reading a translation where the personality of the translator overshadows the personality of the original author. Finally
column16: having read other biographies of the founding fathers
column17: I was disapointed to find so little about the complex relationship between Adams and Franklin.  All in all
column18: my lasting impression is that Mr McCullough did a great job at bringing John Adams and the early American Revolution to the masses through a very appealling product that may however leave readers asking for more historical details and less emotional opinions. Had I known that
column19: I might have passed on this biography and instead explore Mr McCullough's fictional work

column1: Goldwater's disastorous 1964 Presidential campaign is the vehicle for telling the book's real story: the rise of the ultra-conservative movement in American politics in the sixties. It is undoubtedly an important story
column2: and one that Perlstein has researched considerably. However
column3: Perlstein's work is undone not by his findings
column4: or his damaging portrayal of the burgeoning right-wing movement -- I concur with him on these points -- but by very lazy presentation. Perlstein has obvioulsy drunk deep at the David Halberstam well. He can rattle off an anecdote
column5: but he is dreadfully prolix. The book is at least two hundred pages too long. No reader opening a book on sixties politics needs an eight-hundred word summary of Kubrick's Dr. Strangelove. Perlstein has also made a mess in organising his material; he leaps back and forth
column6: from person to person
column7: without ever stitching the requisite parts together. One moment Henry Cabot Lodge looks to be the certain favourite for the 1964 Republican nomination
column8: and we are treated to fifteen pages on the organisation of his campaign; later we are told
column9: almost as an aside
column10: that he has withdrawn from the race
column11: and Perlstein never explains why. Sam Tannehaus's 'Whittaker Chambers' is a much more assured analysis of the growth of anti-communist hysteria in the fifties and sixites
column12: and is considerably shorter and better crafted than Perlstein's book. A more thorough editor and an author more intent on telling the story carefully and well would have made 'Before the Storm' a much better book than it is

column1: The story of Wim Wenders' "Wings of Desire" is told through images and thoughts.  Abandon all expectations of seeing anything resembling a conventional film before watching it.      Two angels glide through the streets of Berlin surveying its inhabitants.  Cassiel (Otto Sander) embraces his role as witness but Damiel (Bruno Ganz) wants to break free of his ethereal existence.  He is willing to cast aside his immortality in order to experience the simple joys of everyday life.  The primary catalyst for his desire to change is his attraction to trapeze artist Marion (Solveig Dommartin).   "Wings of Desire" does not quite work.  It stumbles not because it is too pretentious or too ponderous.  Rather
column2: it stumbles because it is just too abstract.   Relying on imagery and monologues to tell a story makes for an interesting lesson in unconventional filmmaking
column3: but it also leads to frustration and annoyance to anyone conditioned to more traditional narratives.  "Wings of Desire" deserves a lot of credit for its innovative approach toward its material and its beautiful dream-like visuals.  Yet
column4: it is a film that unfortunately will not appeal much to the mainstream viewer.

column1: This is actually 2.5.  These 2 books are fantasy novels set in a human prehistory in which magic exists.  The twist to this idea is that magic is based on a naturally occurring but non-renewable resource called manna (what else).  In some ways
column2: this is an attempt at an allegory of contemporary dependence on petroleum products. Against the backdrop
column3: Niven and Pournelle set a series of stories about a period when manna is really drying up.  The first book
column4: The Burning City
column5: is a bildungsroman about a young man growing up in a relatively magicless community with an unusual social structure and his later adventures in the greater world.  The second book
column6: Burning Tower
column7: is a quest story in which the heroes
column8: related to the heroes of The Burning City
column9: search for powerful wizards manipulating magic in a malignant way.   These are not particularly well written books.  Plots are haphazardly developed
column10: characterization is weak
column11: and good descriptive writing is conspicuous by its absence.  The Burning City
column12: in particular
column13: is marred by some poorly developed allegory.  Neither Niven nor Pournelle are gifted writers though some of their previous work
column14: both individually and in collaboration
column15: is considerably better than either of these books.  Neither of these books come close to matching their best work
column16: The Mote in God's Eye
column17: a very good novel.  Given these deficiencies
column18: the books succeed or fail on the authors' ability to weave traditional mythology and prehistory into their premise. Here
column19: they are only modestly successful.  Their use of mythic elements is relatively superficial.  I can recommend these books only to hard core Niven-Pournelle fans
column20: and then only if they purchase these books at a discount.

I recently received a copy this CD via Amazon and am terribly disappointed by the quality of the baking.  As one reviewer rightfully stated "it sounds like a Karaoke backtrack".  I also get the impression that the production of this project was done on the cheap side given the quality of the backing.  Although Dionne put a lot of faith in her son producing this CD I'm of the opinion that a more experienced producer should have taken the lead.  A full orchestra as backing would also do more justice to Dionne's voice.  I think however that the personal attack by some reviewers on Dionne's vocal ability is a bit unfair.  Take the vocals and back it up with a proper orchestra and you will hear the difference.  Unfortunately the terrible backing is so overpowering that one cannot help but cringe when you listen to the CD.  Should I recommend this CD to other people?  Well...  1) To Dionne all fans: Buy the CD
column2: its certainly one of Dionne's poorer projects
column3: however
column4: you will always wonder if you should have bought it or not.  2) To people who do not mind Dionne's music but do not label themselves as fans: Rather purchase recordings of Dionne that dates back to the 80's
column5: 90's and early 00's.  You will begin to appreciate this TITANIC of a talent much more.  The "My friends and me" CD might just do damage to casual listeners perception of Dionne.  3) To the new generation wanting to purchase their first Dionne album:  See point number two.  I not only purchased a copy for me but another one for a good friend as a Christmas gift.  I'm a bit embarrassed to give him a CD of this quality as a gift and rather decided to buy him something else instead.  I hope that Concord will take cognisance of the reviews and make the necessary changes when they start working on "My friends and me" 2 & 3.  Take Care  Riaan - South Africa

column1: A book about bebop drummers needs to explain 1) what bebop drumming consists of and 2) how the styles of the various drummers profiled diverge. This book does not do either. Instead we are told that drummer after drummer after drummer has "a great feel" and "great time"; we learn nothing.  If it were just that I'd give the book another star for its sketchy and scattered biographical information
column2: but considering how badly written the book is
column3: I can't justify it.  I suggest instead that you buy a copy of "The Grove Dictionary of Jazz" and look up the entry for each famous drummer you want to know about. You'll learn a lot more and have a much better time doing it.  For transcriptions consult Modern Drummer magazine.

 In my experience (and I wish it were not so!), gays tend to share some unpleasant character traits, such as effeminacy or lack of masculinity, cliquishness, and lewdness.  The book's chief merit is that it doesn't deny their existence, but its chief defect is that it attempts, largely unsuccessfully, to try to interpret these characteristics in a more favorable light.  I agree that some of these favorable interpretations are reasonable: for example, I agree that the greater amoralism of gays opens up certain aesthetic or artistic possibilities, at least given a certain understanding of art.  But from the point of view that is most interesting to me, as someone trying to assess the romantic possibilities, I disagree that something very good can be built on such things 
 I really looked forward to this book after reading the review in The New Yorker.  The reviewer's critical skills, evidently, do not extend to evaluating the merits of a logical argument.   There are so many logical problems with the analysis in this book, it is difficult to know where to begin.    I will limit myself to just a handful, among countless possibilities.   1) The authors find a correlation between the stability of a basketball team's roster and its winning percentage, and conclude that roster stability is a factor in producing wins! Classic problem of mistaking effect for cause.  Clearly, winning teams are disinclined to make major roster changes, and losing teams are eager to.  I was so amazed at this I reread it to see if I missed where they pointed this out.  They didn't.   2) The authors show a correlation between more assists and winning percentage and conclude that assists help produce wins.  Again, very silly.  A team with a higher shooting percentage and fewer turnovers will of course get more wins and produce more assists.  But the assists are not producing the wins - the shooting percentage is.  Were these factors discounted?  Not according to the text.    3) Most problematic, the authors define a way of measuring the value of players to a team, and then prove" their method by summing these values
column10: per player
column11: across each team
column12: and show  that they do indeed predict the number of wins each team will get.  What they fail to realize is that their method of apportioning value to a player necessarily sums back to team totals such as points per possession that we know correlate to wins per team.  But this in no way proves that the apportioning is wrong.  We could just as easily base each player's value "team's points while players is on the floor - opposing team's points while player is in the floor".  Sum for all players on team
column13: and you will find the team's points-per-game and the opposition's points per game
column14: and you have just "proven" that your method of measuring a player's value is accurate.    4.  In looking at rebounds
column15: there is not even the slightest caveat that a player's rebounds per game are affected by who he shares rebounding responsibilities with.  If you are in the front court with Shaq
column16: you will get fewer rebounds
column17: not because the other team gets them
column18: but because your teammate does
column19: so comparing rebounding stats between players across teams is highly questionable.    5. Ridiculously
column20: they conclude that adding great players to your roster makes the other players worse not better (this is written as a great revelation
column21: demythifying the common presumption that great players make teammates better).  Adding great players indeed will make other players statistically less productive.  They will take fewer shots
column22: get fewer rebounds
column23: fewer assists if a new ball-handler is added
column24: etc.  And so
column25: according their evaluation method
column26: the other players become worse.  This should clearly tell them there is something wrong with their system
column27: based so heavily on specific metrics of productivity.  Instead
column28: they simply accept the merit of their method as fact
column29: and conclude that adding great players really makes other players worse!!!  The most frustrating thing about this book
column30: however
column31: for an analytically minded reader
column32: is its smugness.  They understand statistics. They have the answers.  They are bringing them down from the mountains and explaining them to us idiot peons.  All while their reasoning is so problematic.   I in no way am a supporter of the intuitive and nonsensical drivel one hears from so many sports coaches
column33: players and commentators.  I would have enjoyed a good
column34: statistical
column35: analytical study of the game of basketball.  Unfortunately
column36: this is not it.

column1: A much condensed version would have helped but still would not have been a good story.  The end was a disappointment and the middle laborious
Once again
column2: Carr's central truth is: To know how the addiction works is to be free of it.   Unfortunately this is simply a false dawn.  The greater the need for a solution
column3: the more willingly we suspend disbelief and trust in a system that promises an end to our problem.  This is not to say the book contains nothing of worth. But Carr's demand for total deference and his insistence on offering a complete cure inevitably prepare us for eventual disappointment. We are all more intelligent than we are capable and awareness of the insanity of addiction never saved anyone from the disease.

column1: To charge a ridiculously high price for an abridged release of any TV series is a crime. In this case it only adds insult to injury. This TV show was never fully appreciated
column2: much less promoted in it's original run
column3: which coincided with the early years of The Simpsons. But that can be credited to Fox Television's still relatively early
column4: unsure of itself years when it wasn't quite sure where to emphasize its marketing. Nevertheless
column5: that's no reason to perpetuate that crime in its DVD release. Chris Elliott was perfectly cast in this role of the live at home with the folks
column6: 30 year old paper boy. It gave him an avenue of extention for the dry wit he demostrated in his years on David Letterman (who can forget
column7: the man under the stands
column8: and his Marlon Brando routines on that show). Watching this show you can see where producers cast him as the lead in "Cabin Boy
column9: again, another unappreciated work. The wit and sarcasm are the same, as is the way he irks those around him, including his own folks, which includes his real life dad Bob Elliott of classic old time radio fame, and Elanor Donahue of Father Knows Best" and "Andy Griffith
column10: where she played a before her time sexy pharmacist named Ellie. I give this series 2 stars merely due to the quality of the episodes themselves, which  was the perfect marriage of writers who worked around Elliotts' delivery and humor. On that it should get a 5, but the collection offered here is a disgrace. This show ranks as one of the top 2 TV shows to get cut short before given a fair chance, along with Police Squad
column11: which at least was given a second life in movie theaters via The Naked Gun" movies. Elliott deserved better than just "Cabin Boy" towards that end. Try again on the DVD release boys. Either do it right
column12: or it shouldn't have been done at all

column1: There are WAY too many credible stories about these things causing problems to risk a $400 360. Putting *any* kind of power-drawing device between a piece of sophisticated electronics and its power supply is just asking for trouble -- I own a lot of expensive electronics and I'd never do it in a million years.  Instead of taking such a chance
column2: go to your local retailer and buy a little fan (4"-6") designed for placing/clipping (depending on how you've got your Xbox set up) on your desk at work
column3: etc. You can get one for $5-$10 and don't have to worry about leeching power from your 360. Just set it up beside the 360 so that air flows beneath and over top.  Since your average superstore has about a dozen fans that would fit the bill
column4: you can shop for one that's quiet and fits your setup. My 360 actually runs quite cool
column5: although I do have a small fan behind my audio rack that blows on my stereo amplifier.  ps Always
column6: always
column7: always put electronics that generate heat in as open a location as possible. NEVER put anything on top
column8: ALWAYS place on a hard surface
column9: and ALWAYS leave at least a few inches clearance all around. Lastly
column10: ALWAYS use a surge suppressor
