column1: This is a book about our society and yet I am left wondering how "everything bad for us" actually affects our society. I believe the author's underlying presumption is that improving the individual improves our society as a whole. This societal analysis
column2: however
column3: is completely missing.  The book can be summed up as follows: 1. Games and software are more complex
column4: therefore our problem-solving ability has increased. 2. TV is more complex
column5: therefore our emotional intelligence has increased. 3. The Internet gives us new ways to connect with others
column6: therefore our communication abilities have increased.  The litmus test for all this is increasing IQ scores.  Part I of the book goes to great lengths to explain how an individual's "mental muscle" is increased through popular media: games
column7: TV
column8: software
column9: and the Internet. Part II asserts that increased IQ scores are the proof that our mental muscle is increasing.  The individual may be benefiting from popular media
column10: but is our society benefiting? Are more technological breakthroughs happening? Are we better able to piece together disparate facts provided by the media and government into a cohesive whole? Is software easier to use so we can more easily accomplish our goals? Are communities and homes being designed better so they improve communication between neighbors and families? Can we better recognize the underlying motives of our politicians? Are we making great strides to decrease global warming
column11: air and water pollution
column12: forest depletion
column13: species extinction
column14: famine
column15: homelessness
column16: cancer and disease
column17: gender and racial inequality
column18: and the distribution of wealth?  If our ability to see connections and solve problems has improved
column19: why do a vast number of Americans still believe there is a connection between 911 and Iraq? Why do we not recognize that the diversity of plant and animal species on the planet directly affects our well-being? Why do we seem incapable of understanding that many of the divisive issues we focus upon (e.g.
column20: school prayer
column21: flag burning
column22: abortion
column23: gay marriage) are simply manifestations of larger societal problems (e.g.
column24: inequality
column25: poverty
column26: domination and control).  How is the popular media affecting these societal and technological issues? Is it making them worse? This is the missing part of the book that I hope will be addressed in another edition

column1: This is not a history of Ancient Persia but rather a set of essays on just a few topics: "The Testimonies" (i.e. the historical sources); "The King and his Subjects"; and "Everyday Life". Basically
column2: apart from the Bisutun relief (text available at http://www.avesta.org/op.htm) and the Persepolis Texts (R. T. Hallock
column3: Chicago 1969)
column4: nearly all the sources are Greek or Latin upon which the author relies despite the contrary assertion given by the publisher on the flyleaf.  It's not the ancient Greek and Roman writers that the author attempts to discredit but rather the modern writers of the nineteenth and twentieth centuries. Better to read "The Persian Empire" by J. M. Cook or "A Political History of the Achaemenid Empire" by Muhammad A. Dandamaev

column1: There are some good things about this film -- it gives audiences an idea of how insidious the Nazi propaganda machine was
column2: for one thing. It also shows the main character
column3: Antoine Moreau
column4: a (fictional) famous French mime
column5: having his eyes opened to the reality of the Nazis' 'final solution' to the 'Jewish problem'. Brought to a Czech town that has been 'given to the Jews' by the Nazis in order to stage a performance that will be seen by the Swiss Red Cross delegation
column6: hopefully persuading them that the Germans are not as monstrous as they have been portrayed
column7: Moreau changes his original idea for the performance
column8: hoping to get a 'silent' message to the Red Cross that will let them know the true fate of Jews (and other 'undesirables') at the hands of the Nazis.    I'll briefly mention a couple of less-than-positive observations
column9: and then get into my main problem with the film.  The production values reminded me a bit of a made-for-TV movie -- and from time to time it seemed that the sound was a little out of sync with the picture. The image quality on the DVD could have been much better as well.  Also
column10: the Shanachie DVD release is version of the film that has been dubbed with English.  This is
column11: in the case of this film
column12: not very well-done.  The cabaret singer
column13: for instance
column14: comes across as completely unbelievable in that her voice doesn't match her face or ethnicity in the least.  Everyone in the film winds up with an English accent
column15: which detracts from any authenticity that might have been retained using subtitles instead of clumsy dubbing.  Another reviewer below brought up the dubbing problem as it apples to one of one of the children
column16: Stella (portrayed by Linda Jablonska).  Her voice does not sound at all like that of a little girl. She develops a bit of a crush on Antoine
column17: which in itself seems like a pretty natural occurrence under the circumstances -- here is a famous artist who has come to the village to stage a show
column18: with her as one of the leads
column19: who is kind and supportive and friendly to her
column20: who listens to her ideas and feelings with attention and respect.  The problem I had was with one scene in particular.  Stella has been caught on the streets after curfew and chased by police.  She bites one of them and manages to elude them by squeezing through a break in a fence.  In the process of getting away
column21: she gets muddy
column22: scrapes herself bloody in a few places
column23: and tears her clothing.  She goes to Moreau's hotel and climbs to the ledge outside his room and taps on the window.  When he opens it
column24: he is shocked at her condition
column25: lets her into the room
column26: and begins to try to clean her cuts and scrapes

It is necessary to correct the current trend of public commentary

column5: designed to validate the existing post-modern myths and prejudices. This book faithfully reflects the post-modern blinkers that its author has helped first create and then perpetuate in his "coverage" of the Wars of Yugoslav Succession. This book reflects his (and their) belief that the Orthodox nations of Southeast Europe - embodied in "the Serbs" - are The Other vis-a-vis "The West" in the Huntingtonian sense. The author's assumptions are prejudiced in a coarse
column6: primordial manner.   Judah's mindset helps us understand why the problem of the Balkans under UN/EU/NATO/UNMIK/KFOR/SFOR. . . is inseparable from the quandary of America under the bipartisan regime inside the Beltway
column7: or that of Europe "united" under the Leviathan of Brussels. This book unintentionally poses many questions

column10: and why has the modern
column11: secular
column12: "post-Christian" West inherited the antipathy of West to the carriers of the Byzantine tradition? How do those two traditions converge
column13: and how do they diverge

column15: and they have been political all along. It is on the way we deal with them today that the future of our civilization will depend

column19: they have one thing in common: for most of history they have not been masters of their own fate

column21: the Serbs in most cases had these conflicts foisted upon them by powerful outsiders and their local minions.  In particular Judah's attempt to relativize the Ustasha genocide of some 500-700

column24: it need not be dominated by the obsessions of the day. column1: Werner Keller was a journalist who was enamored with biblical studies and turned his attention to archeology as a result of the burgeoning area in the late 40s (Dead Sea Scrolls
column2: Nag Hammadi
column3: etc.). The result was this book wherein Keller unashamedly declares - "The Bible is right after all." (p. xviii). He then proceeds to show us.  The book itself is well written and shows more than a little scholarship. He covers 4000 years of biblical history and he tries to integrate archeology with bible quotes and reference works
column4: mostly from the 19th Century.  Yet the book is deeply flawed by Keller's desire to have everything validate the bible's positions. For example
column5: he tries to show that Luke's dating of the census was not entirely incorrect since Quirinius had been in Palestine sometime "between 10 and 7 BC" (p. 344). Yet every scholar who has studied the issue claims that the census in 6 AD was the first census
column6: so Quirinius' presence in Palestine in 8 BC is irrelevant. He spends an exhaustive amount of time detailing the history of the "Star of Bethlehem" and "proving" that the wise men would have arrived to see Jesus in December 7 BC. Then in the next breath he concludes that Jesus must have been born "before the onset of winter" (p. 354). In no case does he seem to realize that the "wise men"
column7: if they existed at all
column8: came 2 years after Jesus' birth which is why Herod had all the children
column9: 2 years or younger
column10: slain. Or consider his remarks about the "one-time splendid synagogue" (p. 364) found in Capernaum. In fact
column11: what is there is a public bulding of some sort
column12: but there is no evidence that it was a synagogue until the 3rd Century.  You know that anyone who refers to Josephus as a "trusty historian" (p. 356) hasn't really done his homework.  It's a shame that Keller's theologically biases make a lot of the material unusable. This book can be dangerous if read by a person who is unable to separate fact from theology. Which is unfortunate because it does have a lot of good information and it is well written

I'd pass on this book

Disclaimer: I am not a fan of Larry Summers.  I didn't care for him when I was an intern at Treasury
column2: and as an alum I really don't care for him as president of Harvard.  But even I think this book is unfair to Summers and goes too far in trying to villify the man.    Bradely has written a book that is very easy to read and draws almost all of the issues enveloping Harvard in easy to digest
column3: black-and-white dramas between Summers (always in the black hat) and various members of the faculty and student body (always portrayed sympatetically).  This book makes no pretence of being objective or looking any further than skin-deep at the controversies that surrounded Summers before the most recent blow-up over his comments on women in science.  Several chapters end with essentially the same line: by doing X
column4: Summers had further consolidated his rule over the university.  If all of this is true (it's not)
column5: Summers would be the absolute dictator of Harvard Yard by now.  In fact
column6: what has been written here is basically an expanded
column7: book-edition copy of the Harvard Crimson from 2000 to the present.  There is little new in the book that readers of Harvard's student newspaper don't already know other than a few re-interviews that Richard Bradley has done with various personalities involved in the recent events at Harvard.    What's lost here is that what is going on at Harvard is a microcosm of what's going on at many other American universities
column8: and that much of it isn't new.  As far back as I can remember (and I come from a family of academics)
column9: students and faculty alike have hated their university presidents
column10: viewing them as uninterested in academics or out of touch with their student bodies.  As at Harvard
column11: with the decibel level of campus politics higher today than at any time since the 1960s
column12: there is a lot of talking (or complaining
column13: depending on one's perspective) going on and less respect for opposing viewpoints.  Harvard is hardly unique in this respect.    Bradely castigates Summers for his handling of several episodes with faculty (most noteably the Cornel West debacle) but misses the broader trend that acadmics as a whole have been getting into narrower and narrower specalties that prevent their work from being of much use to anyone.  This doesn't mean that Summers was justified in how he treated West
column14: who was (and is) a true educator
column15: but it does deny this book some much-needed context.    Similarly
column16: Bradley's comments on Summers' stress on achievement by students misses that the same line was toed by the genteel Neil Rudenstine
column17: who once told the Crimson that 'students don't come to Harvard to have fun' when asked why the university maintains an academic schedule that places fall term finals immediately after winter break.  This was a particularly poor-timed comment after a rash of student suicides on campus and reports that Harvard's student suicide rate was twice the national average.  Overall
column18: only the most die-hard Summers haters will find anything valuable in Harvard Rules.  Everyone else interested in the state of campus would be better of reading the Crimson from time to time

column3: I still think they are worthy of a better book than this. Wild on the road behaviour-which is the main contents of this book largely- is really very common place for a band from that era. I just simply can't understand why it's represented as being so unique. When infact
column4: what is really great about Led Zeppelin is their fantastic music. The writer really fails to capture this or what makes the band as individuals tick. Although he can deliver some salcious tales it becomes pretty obvious he knows very little about them. The photographs are pretty uninspired too. I think the real Led Zeppelin story is full of the heights of success and the lows of human tragedy
column5: and various trials and tribulations inbetween which constitutes their real growth as individuals and musicians. But I have quite honestly never seen any writer particularly
column6: let alone this one- tackle this skillfully. Anything very meaningful tends to be brushed over in favour of petty gossip-mainly to impress a certain type of male fan.  I still think the definative book about them which is more truly representive of their lives and music has yet to be written.

column1: We looked for a trash truck that our 4 year old boy could play with. On the surface
column2: the Bruder looked the part. Not as cartoon-looking as some
column3: the fact that it looked like a real trash truck but had few obvious breakable parts made it seem like an ideal choice.   Actual play testing though shows this product isn't very well-built
column4: at least not enough to withstand normal wear and tear. This truck wasn't subjected to being thrown down the stairs
column5: jumped on
column6: etc. It's been just played with
column7: but it started coming apart quickly.   The hinged door in the back of the truck is a poor design. The plastic hinges on the truck are too thin
column8: and break easily. The plastic hinges on the door start to bend after multiple open/closes
column9: and the plastic weakens and breaks off.   The hinged front compartment and rear sections are difficult to operate
column10: and stick easily. Items put into the cab (like the essential green army man who drives the truck) easily get caught in here and are very difficult to remove.   Worse though is the key point of this toy
column11: the ability to latch the trash can to the lifting/dumping mechanism. This is way to complex for a child
column12: and the intricacy in getting a solid connect is difficult even for an adult.  If it's not hooked up right
column13: the can falls off when you try to lift it; very frustrating.   Some little pieces (rear view mirror
column14: etc) broke off easily and early on
column15: but we kind of expected this. The parts were simply too small and fragile to last long. I don't hold this part against the design; part of the attraction was that it looked like a real truck
column16: and I don't think there's an easy way to add small details without some fragility.  While this is orignally was one of my sons favorite toys
column17: he can't really play with it the way he'd like to. While he still enjoys driving it around the house
column18: he can't pick up the trash and dump it without an adults help
column19: and that's a shame.   For the price
column20: I expected so much more.

column2: bloated
column3: and seemingly pointless. The characters just keep rattling. A lot of writers fill in the story with descriptions of time and place to give an atmosphere to the story. This writer (Wilkie Collins) just fills it with unrelated trivia. Every once in a while I would go back a few pages to see what I must have missed. When I read again there was nothing there to miss. Ether Wilkie is extremely monotonous or other writing from this period is and I am just now lucky enough to find out. I talked to others about this and they said; "Now you know why Sherlock Holmes is so popular"

column1: The film opens with three men arriving at a house. They draw their pistols and rush in. Shots are fired
column2: and Tuco escapes. Then a bounty hunter visits an isolated house
column3: searching for "Jackson". He learns the new name of "Bill Carson" (they were part of a gang of robbers). There is an exchange of opinions
column4: shots are fired. The bounty hunter leaves to report to his boss
column5: and perform another job. Next we see a wanted man captured by three men. Another man shows up to eliminate the competition
column6: like a lion driving away hyenas. The wanted man is turned in for the reward. But his hanging is prevented
column7: and he rides away to be recycled. [Can you believe this?]  Tuco catches up to his former partner and captures him
column8: the tables are turned. [This is like a cartoon.] Just like it looks like it is over for "Blondie" a runaway wagon appears to begin a new story! A dying man tells of a buried treasure of stolen payroll. Now Tuco must care for "Blondie" because he knows the name on the grave that contains the treasure. As they ride away
column9: they see a gray troop of cavalry coming for them. The gray turns out to be dust on their blue uniforms. [Another joke.] Now they are prisoners and sent to a camp. [Was there really combat in the southwest?] This film is like a succession of short stories linked through the same characters.  Tuco manages to escape from the train. Later "Blondie" escapes and they meet again. There is more gunplay in eliminating the competition for their business deal. They arrive at a huge cemetery
column10: much too large for the small town shown in this film. [Obviously staged.] And so there is a showdown between the Good
column11: the Bad
column12: and the Ugly. Scratch one rival. The film ends with a sick joke about hanging. I wonder why some people rate this film highly?  The vocalized song means there is no problem in translation to another language. [Isn't it funny?] The most interesting part is how a 1950s style Western was created by Europeans after they became obsolete in Hollywood. Not that they can't do better.

column1: That should have been the title of this movie as it describes the use that the talents of a high-profile cast & normally respectable director are put to.  Another possible title is "It's All About the Groceries"

column8: a pretty hefty drinking problem
column9: a propensity for picking up strangers in bars & having rough sex with them . . .and some grisly skeletons in her closet.  I was interested to see what Judd would do with this opportunity to play a character with a dark side instead of her usual noble victim.  Unfortunately
column10: not enough.  Ms. Judd is a luminously beautiful actress
column11: even with a severe short haircut meant to make her look tough
column12: I suppose. It is not hard to believe that men would be drawn to her like bugs to a flame.  She has not developed the range of emotion to really carry a complex character like Jessica
column13: though
column14: playing it distressingly one-note.  Is she ecstatic?  Depressed?  In a drug-induced stupor?  The way Judd plays it
column15: it could be any
column16: or all
column17: of the above.  I like Ashley Judd
column18: but she is in danger of turning into the female version of Richard Gere--a performer with real potential who keeps choosing flashy junk-food roles that do not challenge her talent.  "Kiss the Girls" was the high-water mark & each subsequent film has been weaker than the last.  This movie is worth the price of a rental
column19: but I'd take a pass on purchasing it.  For a better treatment of female-cop-with-dark-secrets-and-Issues

column1: Into The Woods is one of my Sondheim favorites.  Having seen the PBS presentation of this
column2: I am thoroughly dismayed at how poorly this DVD is edited.  Rather than allowing one to be engaged by the staging and character interaction
column3: this DVD uses pan and scan to isolate characters and provide sometimes inappropriate close-ups.  This especially detracts from what one wishes to see in a play; the staging.  By forcing the viewer's perspective
column4: this version does a disservice to a very fine play that investigates our relationships with each other through fairy tales and their aftermath.  I am hoping that somebody releases a version that does not presume to edit out the director's vision

column7: burned out bum of a cop who guzzles gallons of booze and staggers from scene to scene like one of the zombies in Dawn of the Dead. This is his worst performance (that I have ever witnessed) and to make matters even more grim

column13: apparitions

column19: plot
column20: direction
column21: and characterization. Also

Perfect when you are snoozing with your loved one on a Sunday- or Saturdaymorning. Here come the tracks in the correct order (the order is VERY important for the mood):  1. column2: the unplugged version... MUCH better than the loud one!) 4. Long December (from 'Across a wire') 5. Holiday in Spain (from 'Hard Candy') 6. Perfect Blue buildings (from 'August and everything after') 7. Black & Blue (from 'Hard Candy') 8. All my friends (from 'Desert Life') 9. I wish I was a girl ( from 'Desert Life') 10. Speedway (from 'Desert Life') 11. Miller's Angels (from 'Mercury Falls')  I bet they are going to steal this idea from me
column3: and otherwise you guys can :-) Enjoy!

column1: Professor Yoo makes many seemingly compelling arguments in favor of his contention that the President has virtually unfettered authority sanctioned by our constitution
column2: but
column3: as reasonable as his arguments may seem
column4: what I find to be the underlying flaw is that he's arguing that unrestrained authority of the chief executive is somehow consistent with the principles of constitutional democracy and the rule of law upon which our system of government is based.  Frankly
column5: this is a completly cognitively dissonant position; advocating an authoritarian right in the name of democracy just doesn't  meet the test of reason. It's functionally identical to the argument that "We have to destroy the village to save it" made popular during the Vietnam War.  Benjamin Franklin famously said; "Those who would give up essential Liberty to purchase a little temporary Safety
column6: deserve neither Liberty nor Safety". Clearly the good professor doesn't seem to grasp this essential concept as elucidated by one of our most respected and revered Founders.

If you're going to read one of the great classics of literature-and you should-don't pick up this edition.  It is a reprint of a version that dates back to the 1870s and was exposed more than 40 years ago for cutting nearly one-quarter of Verne's story and mistranslating much of the remainder.  Its reappearance in this edition is all the more amazing considering Tor's status as a leading science fiction publisher
column2: and the company's willingness to perpetrate this fraud on is many readers is truly stunning.  If you want to truly get to know Verne's novel
column3: pick up the elegant Naval Institute Press edition
column4: in a modern
column5: complete
column6: updated translation
column7: with commentary by the leading American Verne expert today
column8: Walter James Miller.  That book also comes with many of the artistic engravings that illustrated the original French first edition (no illustrations are to be found in the B&N Mercier reprint).  Less attractive but more academic is the Oxford Classics version of Twenty Thousand Leagues.  This review is posted on behalf of the North American Jules Verne Society by Jean-Michel Margot

column1: If you're getting this book for hardcore reference material I would be careful. I literally had the book 5 minutes and discovered a handful of mistakes.  Ex.  -Jim Lee's entry has the best selling X-Men #1 as being released in 2001 instead of 1991.  -The timeline has Sandman ending in 1997 when it was actually 1996.  If you buy this book get it for light reading. Do not use it for quoting comic fact until you check the validity of what you are using. Like I said.. I noticed these two mistakes after skimming the book for 5 minutes. I am afraid of how much more I will find once I start digging in
It's probably been 15 years since I read it
column2: and EVERY person in the years since with whom I have discussed this book has said the same thing.  It was literally a book that kept me up until 3 a.m. - and THAT is how it ends?  I'm hoping Dr. Crichton had a publishing deadline or something.

column1: Max Brooks has written a must-have history for Romero (or just Zombie) fans every where.  Unfortunately
column2: while the story starts off strong
column3: it soon dribbles into a series of disjointed and
column4: occasionally
column5: pointless vignettes.  It would be a difficult tale for anyone to carry
column6: given the format that Brooks has chosen to use: a large number of first person accounts of the near take over of the world by the stumbling zombie hordes.  There's no single narrative string for the audience to follow and no heroes with which the reader can identify.  I found myself eventually becoming bored with the different ways that Max's characters described the zombies - there's only so many ways to say "undead."    To make up for the essential sameness of the story line in every individual short story
column7: Max begins to increasingly rely on overblown rhetoric.  For example
column8: a chain-smoking military veteran
column9: recovering in a psychiatric ward
column10: breaks out of semi-literate street-slang to describe zombie heads popping like "Kristal corks." Far from being effectively descriptive
column11: it becomes a distraction that made me start looking for more examples of excessive hyperbole.    I think the book would have held up better if
column12: in addition to the large number of independent accounts
column13: Max had found a way to weave a single unifying thread
column14: giving his audience some one to root for and a reason to keep reading. A difficult
column15: but not impossible task and Max Brooks appears to have the talent needed to pull such a task off; but the lack of heroes
column16: or even characters most readers can identify with
column17: makes this a book with no compelling reason to finish.  You can stop on one page
column18: flip at random through the book
column19: start reading again and never feel like you've lost your place.  And speaking of heroes - this is really a minor complaint
column20: but once you've figured it out it begins to annoy - Max's characters are all of a type: a PC type.    That is
column21: such heroes as the various stories allow
column22: are divided into sympathetic and non-sympathetic groupings.  The sympathetic
column23: most effective
column24: characters are all minorities
column25: women
column26: or handicapped.  The non-sympathetic
column27: least effective
column28: characters are all white and male.  His bias goes so far that there's not a single heroic cop
column29: survivalist NRA member
column30: or even effective military unit.  The president of the United States (sympathetic-minority) is contrasted against the vice-president (unsympathetic-white) by citing many instances of the great president's wise guidance
column31: while the vice president is simply described as "the wacko."    I'm not saying that it's impossible for the world to be saved by any particular group.  It's Max's book and he can take the tale where ever he wants.  But it's so transparently obvious a bias that
column32: once you figure it out
column33: you find yourself mentally forecasting the characters entirely independently of their stories.  It's a stretch and distracts from what could have been a more balanced (and more interesting) tale as a result.  All that said
column34: I started out by saying that tome is a "must-have" for Romero loving Dead-heads like me and I stand by that statement. For all it's rambling plot and hyper-kinetic speech
column35: it's still the best new installment in the zombie pantheon for many a day.  I predict great success in it's admittedly limited demographic.

column1: After my older brother suddenly died of coronary artery disease at age 40 due to genetically high cholesterol
column2: I needed to learn everything possible on the subject so that I could avoid suffering the same fate.  I read all the books on the shelf
column3: among them Dr. Ornish's.  I disliked this book because it is rather narcissistic and is focused more on Dr. Ornish himself than on educating us about how to avoid heart disease.  Take a look at chapter 1 and you'll see what I mean: "I was trained to treat hypertension..."; "I first became interested in conducting research on heart disease in 1975..."; "I began to wonder..."; "I went to the medical library and began reading extensively"; "It seemed like an exciting opportunity
column4: so in 1977 I decided to take a year off..."; "I hadn't had enough clinical experience to be jaded..."; "I was unwittingly giving many of them hope for the first time since their illness had been diagnosed"; "I went back to medical school and graduated in 1980"; "From 1981 to 1984
column5: I completed my internship and medical residency in Boston."; "In July 1984
column6: I moved to San Francisco..."  This is just the tedious first six pages.  Trust me
column7: it goes on and on like this.  Do you want to learn about how the heart works?  You'll finally get a few sentences on that subject when you get to page 42
column8: squeezed in between more "I did this and I did that."  You'll get a little info on LDL and HDL when you get to page 51.  Sure
column9: there is useful information within the 672 pages of this book
column10: but you'll be forced to become an expert on Dr. Ornish and his life story to find it.  And remember
column11: this book is more than 15 years old.  Perhaps back in 1990 he needed to devote 300 pages to convincing people that he was correct in believing that diet
column12: exercise
column13: and stress affect your risk of heart disease
column14: but that that is common knowledge and not controversial now.  The research is far more advanced in today's world.  If you are interested in Dr. Ornish personally and the history of the study of heart disease in the 1970s and 1980s
column15: you'll probably enjoy this book.  But if you are serious about educating yourself on heart disease and how best to avoid it
column16: I would recommend Dr. Robert Superko's "Before the Heart Attacks : A Revolutionary Approach to Detecting
column17: Preventing
column18: and Even Reversing Heart Disease" (2003) or Dr. Harlan M. Krumholz's "The Expert Guide to Beating Heart Disease: What You Absolutely Must Know" (2005).  These books are more up to date and provide far more useful information.

column1: Well
column2: before buying this I had never even heard of bright eyes.  Just so you know my background
column3: I generally dislike indie and Emo.  I usually listen to hardcore and Screamo.  But for some reason I became interested in this band.  (or person) Someone compared a CD of their's to A Death Cab CD.  Me being a pretty big Death Cab fan
column4: I decided to go out and buy this EP to see if I liked this band at all.  This review is the result of that listen.  The EP opens up with the slow acoustic guitar picks of "a line allows prgress"...  A few seconds into the song I am greeted with with drums and an organ.  This song sounds like a slower Cursive song.  The guy's voice sounds decent.  I guess the vocal effects he uses are for emotional purposes.  Overall this is a pretty decent song.  It reminds me of hotel california.  Next in line comes one of my favorite tracks on here:  "a perfect sonnet".  I don't know if it's the simple guitar stum or the sense that his voice is going to explode any moment.  Seriously
column5: the whole song I was thinking that everything was about to fall apart...but it didn't.  He keeps going and going.  It must be his voice that creates this mood.  This was also the point of the CD where I realized that it was a bit more than music I was listening to.  Bright eyes will make you feel moods that other music can't.  It's got a unique brand of emotion that is new to me.  It's too bad this song ends so quickly.  As I press on to: "on my way to work" I begin to get the feel for the CD.  He's almost whispering on this track.  There's an odd sounding guitar picking and a country sounding synthesizer.  Quite frankly
column6: I hate this song.  It sounds like an offkey country ballad...  Who wants that?  The next two tracks are more or less the same feel.  A new arrangement provides better quality music than the craptastic on my way to work
column7: but doesn't reach the level of A perfect sonnet.  Finally
column8: the EP is ended with the techno atmospheric: Neely o hara...  I don't know what to say.  It's meaningless.  I don't see how you can like this.  It's just pointless.  Overall this is a half and half EP.  The first two tracks are good...  But the rest of the CD falls between failing and decent.  If Bright Eyes good churn out more tracks like a perfect sonnet
column9: this band would get at least a 4 star.  Sadly thats not the case.  So I don't recommend this for anyone other than the really dedicated fans.  Perhaps the other CD's are better

column1: While Dr. Osterholm's suggestions for improvements to the nations biological defense were ingenious and visionary
column2: the rest of the text was to sensational for me to take seriously.  The examples of biological attacks were so dramatic that at points I was laughing.  The terrorists had some how bypassed all safeties in place without any effort which would not be the case for a large scale attack.  Just read "Silent Death" or "Biohazard" and you would understand the difficulty in the types of attacks he was describing. Yes
column3: there have been bioterrorist attacks in the U.S. but none of the scale he is describing.  He doesnt seem to understand the destinction between biological warfare and bioterrorism that he says he is trying to make.  There is a real threat and his underlying message is an important one but the approach was meant to shock instead of to teach. If your interested in biological weapons or warfare I would suggest "Germs" or "Biohazard" instead.  They take them selves more seriously and the detailed accounts of actual biological attacks is more frightening then anything that can be made up

column15: among other things
column16: opposing doctrines of racial equality. Kirk goes on about Calhoun's support for states rights but his support only extended to southern states as he supported the Fugitive Slave Act which forced federal officials and law officials in Northern states to return runaway slave under penalty of $1000 fine. He supported laws that would make it illegal for northerners to even protest slavery. For Calhoun states rights were nothing more than a self serving attempt to keep slavery safe. Kirk shows his own racist stripes when he refers to northern `anti-slavery agitation' and supports Calhoun for choosing racial preservation over liberty
column17: although Calhoun has an extremely warped view of liberty. One wonders if Kirk could even fathom the supreme irony in stating the Calhoun mounted a `strong protest against domination by class or region'.  Another thread is his desire to see the reunification of church and state. The duty of the church is to keep the unclean masses in line. Quoting Samuel Coleridge
column18: the author makes it clear that the truth or falsity of the church is irrelevant; it is an institution that must be preserved as the primary means of social control. Sounding like the inspiration for disgraced Chief Justice Roy Moore
column19: Russell Kirk urges that
column20: "state and church ought never to be separate entities
column21: true religion is not merely an expression of national spirit; it rises far superior to earthly law
column22: being
column23: indeed
column24: the source of all law". Kirk sees a difference between the faulty laws of man and the laws of God but never draws a distinction. I have to wonder if
column25: like the modern Reconstructionist
column26: Kirk wanted to see the laws of Leviticus imposed including executing homosexuals and blasphemers. He never explains how one might recognize a law of God besides using prejudice.  The third thread would be Kirk's anti-intellectual (or perhaps pro-stupid) stance. He refers to human reason as `puny' and `impotent' and claims that we find the mind of God in prejudice and tradition. `Prejudice'
column27: he writes
column28: `is of ready application in the emergency; it previously engages the mind in a steady course of wisdom and virtue
column29: and does not leave the man hesitating in the moment of decision
column30: skeptical
column31: puzzled
column32: and unresolved'. Actually what he is advocating is for the general population to turn over rational thought to the church and those higher up the social chain. Citizens are encouraged to exhibit awe and veneration for God and those in higher stations and authority.  In order to grab the golden fleece of populism Conservatives have lately had to abandon overt stratification although veneration of wealth is certainly still evident. Like Calhoun the support for states rights remains a complete faade. I found Russell Kirk's salesmanship of Conservativism generally repellent but recommend the book because it remains a fairly enlightening view of an ideology that continues to thrive to this day.

column1: This is a deeply flawed book. It purports to be a description of the characteristics and attitudes that make wealthy people wealthy
column2: but it is based mostly on their self-assessments without comparison to a control group. I suspect that this heavily underplays the role of random chance in success
column3: and attributes causation where there is only correlation. Further
column4: the author displays clear biases on a number of topics
column5: which leads him to engage in ad hoc interpretation of his data
column6: sometimes to argue for conclusions that are contrary to the clear implications of the data--such as his arguments for the importance of religion in the lives of millionaires.  On pp. 33-35
column7: the author looks at success factors
column8: and compares to the role of luck on pp. 82-85
column9: which he downplays in favor of discipline. While he touches on the importance of having the right connections (and the genetic contributions to intelligence)
column10: on p. 85 he asks "what does luck have to do with graduating from medical school? What does luck have to do with successfully running a medical practice? Very little
column11: according to these physicians." But what does luck have to do with being born into a family and in a country where one has a chance to reach adulthood
column12: let alone be able to attend a medical school? Quite a bit.  Unlike its predecessor
column13: which looked at prodigious accumulators of wealth (PAWs) vs. under-accumulators of wealth (UAWs)
column14: this book focuses on millionaires (PAWs) and decamillionaires (a tiny subset of PAWs
column15: those with net worth $10M or greater). The lack of comparison to the general public serves to limit the book's value.  A misleading comparison between businessmen and stockbrokers on pp. 76ff makes the point. Stanley states that the former is an occupation more likely to have higher net worth. But this comparison is misleading because he's only looking at the millionaire-plus sample; he is excluding more of the total business owner population from his sample than stockbrokers. The average and median income and net worth for business owners are likely lower than for stockbrokers. If he made the same comparison with actors or musicians to stockbrokers
column16: for example
column17: the problem is more obvious--by excluding all those who aren't worth $1M or more up front
column18: you exclude the vast majority
column19: and pull up the average. With stockbrokers
column20: on the other hand
column21: a higher percentage of them are in the top income earners and wealthy.  On p. 110
column22: after having pages about the importance of ethics and advising "Never lie. Never tell one lie." (p. 55)
column23: he passes right over his example
column24: Mr. Warren
column25: lying about being a college graduate in order to get a job
column26: without comment
column27: and without noticing the hypocrisy.  On pp. 173-174
column28: the author wants to make the point that prayer is important for millionaires dealing with stress
column29: despite the fact that the majority of his surveyed population do not regularly pray. (He repeats this again on p. 370
column30: saying "nearly one-half of the millionaires (47 percent) engaged in prayer. ... for a significant percentage of millionaires
column31: their religious faith is a major force in their lives.")  In trying to emphasize the point (p. 174)
column32: he splits his sample into "religious millionaires" (RM) and "other millionaires" (OM)
column33: observes that 75% of RM engage in prayer while only 8% of OM do
column34: and points out that this is "a ratio of more than nine to one." This is a meaningless comparison
column35: however--RM make up only 37% of his total population of millionaires
column36: so his "more than nine to one" ratio is really nothing more than saying
column37: of those millionaires who are religious
column38: three-fourths hold religious practices which involve regular prayer (and 8% of those who do not consider themselves religious pray anyway). Since the OM population is much larger than the RM population
column39: in absolute numbers that's not a nine-to-one ratio--his numbers show that about 28% of his total sample are RM who pray
column40: while 5% of his total sample are OM who pray--closer to a six-to-one ratio.  But more importantly
column41: the author glosses over the fact that not only are the majority of millionaires not religious
column42: even a quarter of those who are don't engage in regular prayer! Given that the U.S. is one of the most religious countries in the world
column43: the fact that such a low percentage of millionaires are religious is quite interesting and worthy of further exploration as to the cause
column44: but for Stanley
column45: religion and prayer are an important foundation of the "millionaire mind
column46: and he completely misses the opportunity to find an explanation for why millionaires are so much less religious than the general population.  In a later table in the book on p. 366, he shows activities engaged in by a sample of 733 millionaires during the preceding 30 days. The table includes 52% attending religious services, 47% praying, 37% attending religious events, 22% Bible/devotional reading. These numbers don't quite match up with the RM/OM data from pp. 173-174, which seem to show even lower levels of religious activity, but these are still lower than they are for the nonmillionaire population--and weekly church attendance is notoriously over-reported in surveys. Work by Mark Chaves, C. Kirk Hardaway, and P.L. Marler in the 1990s found the actual percentage of attendance about half of what surveys show. This actually could mean that millionaires attend more often, if Stanley's survey results don't have similar over-reporting.  The author's religious bias further leads him to recommend to a student going through a divorce that she, despite not being a church attendee, search for a mate by joining a church group (p. 268) because she believed in marriage and the traditional family concept." He writes that "I believe that one is likely to find better prospects in a church setting than in singles bars. Of course
column47: there are no guarantees
column48: but people with a religious orientation are more prone to respect the principles espoused in the Good Book." But why is he just guessing on this? Hasn't he asked his population of millionaires--the ones who are 63% non-religious--how they met their mates? He did this
column49: very usefully
column50: regarding how millionaires purchase their homes (pp. 315-326)--yet isn't picking a partner even more important?      This book has some interesting data
column51: and is at its best when giving comparative results between populations (e.g.
column52: the house-purchasing characteristics of economically productive millionaires vs. non-economically productive millionaires in chapter 7). But it doesn't stand up well in comparison to The Millionaire Next Door
column53: which is a much better book

column1: If you liked Michael Eric Dyson's other works then you will love this.  It is essentially his standard "blame Amerika" rant with the words New Orleans
column2: and Hurricane Katrina thrown in to render the work germane.  The interesting thing about this book is how quickly it was published after Katrina.  Given the length of time required to get a manuscript onto bookshelves
column3: I calculated that he must have written this in the two weeks following the storm. Given that some of the "facts" he cites about Katrina can be shown empirically to be false
column4: perhaps he should have waited just a little longer before jumping into the fray.    Another  blow to Dyson's neo-Marxist take on Katrina is the  Knight Ridder news story released  in December (2006) that showed the pattern of death and to a certain extent destruction did NOT occure on racial/class lines as Dyson would have us believe also casts doubt on his narrative (for example
column5: as a percentage of population
column6: there was a stronger correlation between age and death than race and death. If those found dead in nursing homes were factored out
column7: as a percentage of population
column8: more white people than black died. Can we then surmise that George Bush hates old white people? The main stream media
column9: with few exceptions
column10: did not pick up on this story because like Dyson
column11: they had already decided the Katrina narrative and they are not about to let the facts ruin a juicy story.)  Those of you who know Dyson's work of course will know that he was probably chomping at the bit from day one to throw his opinion into the mix.    Anyone who followed the coverage of Katrina probably heard various religious figures blaming the evil nature of New Orleans for incurring god's wrath.  Offensive as these views may be
column12: I was surprised that Dyson - a writer who is considered to be a first rate accademic by many - would wast a whole chapter refuting such arguments.  In fact
column13: by even arguing against these positions he is giving them more credence than they deserve.  If any book about Katrina is to be taken seriously
column14: it probably should not contain a whole chapter on the pros and cons of various theological interpretations of the disaster.  True
column15: the author is an ordained minister but perhaps he should leave his views on divine retribution in the pulpit where they belong (it is also ironic that given Dysons neo-Marxist critical approach to race
column16: etc. that he would even counternance the notion of god. let alone engage in the arguments he does here.)  So
column17: if you are a fan of Dyson's
column18: buy this book - you will be neither disappointed nor challenged (because you already know what he is going to say.) If you are interested in the state of contemporary leftist "academic" thought then this is a good read because it is far more accessible than the works of many of Dyson's peers yet encapsulates the narrow race/class/power/gender optic through which they view capitalism in general and of course this most wicked of nations

column1: I was expecting accurate information regarding the history of Christmas songs and carols. Instead
column2: Ace Collins has taken some facts about the carols and woven fairytales around them. In some cases he has taken a few facts and assumed results that are erroneous.   Having personally researched "Silent Night" in Austria
column3: I can say for certain that Collins has presented another fanciful story based on some facts and some misconceptions about the world's best-loved carol.   The tale about "The Twelve Days of Christmas" being a secret catechism for Catholics in the period when they were oppressed in England doesn't make any sense. The "secret" Catholic beliefs it supposedly hides are identical to the Protestant beliefs of that era. Therefore there was no reason to keep them secret from Protestants -- 1 =  one God
column4: 2 = Old and New Testament
column5: 3 = gold
column6: frankincense
column7: and myrrh -- and so on.   Sadly
column8: it's just another feel-good Christmas book when it could have been a valuable resource for people wanting accurate information.

column1: In this book Popper presents two contradictory theses: (a) science can be based on deductive logic only
column2: and there is no need for induction; (b) science cannot have a logical basis.   Because deduction yields sure knowledge if it is based on sure knowledge and induction always produces only hypothetical knowledge
column3: as Bertrand Russell clearly stated
column4: Popper begins by trying to show that the use of deduction instead of induction can provide a solid logical basis for science. He talks about replacing "inductivism" by "deductivism." In reality
column5: he explains the use of deduction in the testing of a theory: consequences are deduced from the theory and are compared with known facts
column6: which is something known by many. Induction
column7: on the other hand
column8: is used in creating hypotheses in both experimental and theoretical investigations and is again used in generalizing the results of tests (a) to all other possible tests in experimental investigation
column9: and (b) also to some phenomena that cannot be used to test the theory created using the hypothesis
column10: or hypotheses
column11: that are produced inductively. When Popper claims that inductivism can be replaced by deductivism
column12: he is unaware of the fact that induction is used at the beginning of both experimental and theoretical investigations to create hypotheses and again at the end of the investigation to generalize the test results.   But in the rest of the book
column13: Popper concentrates on the generalization of test results
column14: which is done through induction and is what he overlooked to begin with
column15: as explained above. Consequently
column16: Popper proves rightly that scientific knowledge cannot be produced using deductive logic
column17: which is the opposite of what he tried to prove earlier.   The truth is that new knowledge is not a product of logic but is learned from the world about singular phenomena and is generalized through induction. Induction does not yield logically sure knowledge
column18: but evolution created the human brain/mind so that it knows that it has to trust induction. Thus
column19: everyone avoids hitting his or her head against hard objects by learning from past experience through induction. Someone who does not trust such inductive knowledge is punished severely. Similarly
column20: when a scientist or an engineer does not use an accepted theory anywhere in his or her work
column21: he or she is likely to be punished by failure and its consequences of many kinds.  Popper's views should serve to waken up those who seek the comfort of producing all knowledge through deduction only
column22: but in fact
column23: they shed doubt mostly on theories
column24: because a theory is not deduced from anywhere
column25: unlike empirical knowledge is
column26: about some singular phenomena. A theory is constructed and tested by using induction or deduction
column27: as necessary
column28: at various stages of the total process on the basis of empirical knowledge. Popper's views are those of a philosopher who is not familiar with the mission and methods of science and thinks that science is about discovering something that can be called the absolute truth. Read also my evaluation of Kuhn's views.  Another erroneous idea of Popper is that theories can be falsified but cannot be verified. It is true that if a new theory is falsified by a few or even a single test
column29: there is usually no more wish to keep testing it. But when an accepted theory is falsified by one phenomenon
column30: it is not discarded as invalid. Its use continues where it gives good results. It is also true that a theory cannot be verified in an absolute sense
column31: but this is true also about empirical knowledge. The generality of any knowledge is a consequence of induction which is forced upon the mind by the results of evolution
column32: as mentioned. The verification of a theory
column33: or any knowledge
column34: means that it can be used where it gives useful results. Unfortunately
column35: the impossibility of the logical or experimental validation of knowledge in a general way is seen as a weakness of only theories by those who ignore what a theory is and how it is constructed
column36: tested
column37: and used.

column1: There's a lot to like in this book
column2: theoretically. The worlds themselves are well-drawn
column3: the language curt and no-nonsense with occasional flights into a kind of hard cyberpunk beauty (that sort of mimics but doesn't really ever come close to the best that William Gibson has given us). The science is seamlessly integrated into the story
column4: and you come away with the impression that a lot of thought went into its structure.  The theory doesn't hold
column5: though. This just isn't a very good book.   The action follows three different characters
column6: along three different threads. At first
column7: and for most of the book
column8: they have no obvious connection with each other. Their stories appear to unravel aimlessly
column9: and although lots of stuff happens
column10: none of it seems to be in the service of an actual story. It has the effect of three brutal picaresques without destinations
column11: physical or moral.  There is a payoff
column12: but it takes a long time to get there
column13: and by the time I did I was so exhausted and dispirited by the intervening unpleasantness that it didn't really have much of an impact.  There are three major problems with this book:  Information withholding: I like books with central mysteries
column14: that make you wait (and work) to understand what's going on. It's a good propulsive technique
column15: plot-wise. But the mysteries need to resolve. The author keeps us confused pretty much the whole way through
column16: dropping occasional hints that aren't so much tantalizing as frustrating. As I said: by the time I figured out what was going on
column17: I'd stopped caring. This might just be my limitations as a reader
column18: but I gather
column19: from other reviews
column20: that a lot of people feel the same way. You work so hard to understand what's going on that it's difficult to enjoy any of it.  Dreams: Harrison uses dreams both in the service of both theme and plot: to elucidate the characters' psychology
column21: and to give us a window into their past. This is unfortunate
column22: because (in my mind) dreams are lazy plot devices that give the author an excuse to stop the narrative and jump back for some convenient exposition
column23: instead of wending it into the story. Generally speaking
column24: as soon as I hit a dream sequence
column25: I lose interest. I lost interest a lot in this book. Which is a shame
column26: because the content of the dreams here is often wonderful
column27: strange and sometimes even touching. It just needs to be presented better.  Unremitting dourness: There is nothing pleasant about reading this book. The main characters are either savage and unlikeable
column28: pitiable and unlikeable
column29: or mystifying and unlikeable. Often all three. And
column30: with the exception of the wife (who I liked almost as much as I pitied)
column31: none of the supporting characters are much use either. The worlds they inhabit are brutal
column32: dire
column33: unpleasant
column34: and dour. There's a lot of sex here
column35: but as portrayed it's mostly just another kind of violence. The whole thing's kind of a downer
column36: pretty much the whole way through
column37: and the strange note of hope at the end comes off false and unconvincing
column38: as if it's been grafted on from another
column39: happier book.  The writing itself has some odd lapses too
column40: given the care that went into the structure of the book
column41: and the obvious attention to detail. Lots of tortured
column42: passive sentences. A few bits of dialogue that sound like campy Chandler.   Harrison is obviously very talented. I wanted very much to like this book
column43: and I suspect I'll pick up another one of his novels sometime in the future. There's a great deal of potential here. It's just that most of it went unrealized

I'll let you know if I do. I guess I've just read too much Flannery O'Conner (brilliant) and consider Faulkner a bit too precious. Slam me if you must. "A Light in August" was good

column1: I've enjoyed Stephen Fry's work as an actor and comedian
column2: and looked forward to my first crack at one of his books. But "The Hippopotamus"
column3: while loaded with clever lines
column4: completely failed as a novel for me because of the author's intense desire to shock the reader and thus "prove" his superiority. Fry apparently believes he has accomplished this with a plot involving bestiality
column5: but he is unable to sustain the kind of intense focus it would take to really explore the dark world of mental delusion he temporarily assigns to one of his characters
column6: an adolescent boy. By the end (SPOILER coming up; stop reading if you don't want to know)
column7: everything has reverted to a happy
column8: sunny world. The boy who suffered the delusions has instantly forgotten them and
column9: even more inexplicably
column10: a complete cipher of a character has agreed to go on a date with the narrator
column11: despite the fact that his idea of attracting a woman is to promise to "lick her like a lolly". Fry really gives away his underlying lack of grit when he equates a liking for McDonald's hamburgers with mental health. (Mickey D's advertising sure works well.)   It's too bad that Fry's goal of being shocking supersedes his interest in creating believable characters and situations
column12: because he definitely has talent as a writer. His style is engaging and intelligent. I may try one of his other books
column13: but I can't recommend this one

column1: I recently finished reading Nathaniel Philbrick's excellent book

column3: the story of the Whaleship Essex" and realized that Sena Naslund took a major chunk of her story from real-life events.  I suggest that readers of "Ahab's Wife" read Philbrick's book next--it is much more interesting and a truly fantastic read.  Naslund most certainly based the seafaring section of her novel upon this true story: the whaleship Essex  is stove by a white whale in the South Pacific. The men take refuge in whaleboats
column4: and the captain is convinced by his mates to head to South America instead of Tahiti
column5: out of fear of cannibalism
column6: yet they eventually resort to cannibalism themselves.  I had to skim parts of Naslund's book
column7: as it got so tedious in parts.  In contrast
column8: Philbrick's book kept me riveted from start to finish

column1: I'm a little hesitant to write a review of this book as a male reader that does not gush with positive statements about it being an affirmation of the hardships women face (same would go if I were reviewing The Fear of Flying or A Room of One's Own
column2: both of which are far superior to this outing
column3: although of different genres)
column4: but I'll go ahead and write one anyways. Nafisi's account of her life and those of her female students during the past few troubling decades in Tehran didn't provide all of the insight that many have used to champion this work. Nor has she really provided any insights into the works that she uses nor many links between the relevance of these specific works with her students. I know I may get lambasted for saying so
column5: but the memoir and literary criticism does not mesh together well and at no point do we get some semblance of true cohesion. Instead
column6: we get pockets of reflections that come out slightly forced or too general. The layers of interpretation for a character such as Humbert is simplified to either he's a villian or a misunderstood villian
column7: neither of which deals with many of the nuances Nabakov has included. You would expect more from someone who teaches these works if she wants to actually flesh out some of these ideas and the relevance and impact upon her students. The strongest parts of the text lie with her description of university life and the political complexities that emerge surrounding being a literature teacher educated in the West who comes back to Iran to teach. I think one of my problems was the way which the book is marketed as a celebration of sorts of the way literature is important within any context
column8: yet the novel devolves into a simple description of the life of one brave English professor who stands up to the conservative regime and its attempts to curb access to certain books in the country. On a more stylistic level
column9: I was slightly annoyed that the students she describes in the text
column10: as much as she loves and cares for each of them and does try to differentiate them
column11: actually become a massive blob without much indivuality. I had many problems picturing them and the way that they are different from one another. Her husband is also described more as a shadow than anythign else
column12: even though he does play an important role
column13: although a subtle one in many scenes. I think I expected a lot from this novel that I couldn't get from picking up a newspaper and I didn't get much beyond that.

Getting a root canal with a pneumatic drill would be more entertaining.  Anyone buying this CD should be subject to intense psychotherapy.

column1: I understood that The Moonstone is a classic so I decided to read this to be culturally literate. Well the story line may be interesting but the writing is atrocious. It is curricular
column2: bloated
column3: and seemingly pointless. The characters just keep rattling. A lot of writers fill in the story with descriptions of time and place to give an atmosphere to the story. This writer (Wilkie Collins) just fills it with unrelated trivia. Every once in a while I would go back a few pages to see what I must have missed. When I read again there was nothing there to miss. Ether Wilkie is extremely monotonous or other writing from this period is and I am just now lucky enough to find out. I talked to others about this and they said; "Now you know why Sherlock Holmes is so popular"

column1: This is the most poorly written book I have read on the war.  I felt like I was reading a struggling wannabe writer.  I would have preferred to read to each person's story by chapter as opposed to being scattered through out the book. One minute Henderson was trying to write factual information
column2: the next trying to be a novelist
column3: she should have selected one style or the other. When I reached chapter 7 it was said that many military wives don't know the death notification process I quit reading the book.  I couldn't stand it anymore.  What I did read did not impress me or make me feel compassion for the wives.  I come from a military family and I am so grateful we are not like the folks in this book.  When you marry a Soldier that is exactly what you get and if you can't take the initiative to do research and educate yourself on the lifestyle then I have no sympathy. I do not care how much whining the wives do their deployed loved ones at war have it one thousand times worse than they do here at home and they need to get that

column1: To quote Matt Ruff in Sewer
column2: Gas & Electric: Joan met Archie Kerrigan in November of '03 while researching a position paper on federal regulation of the genetic engineering industry.  Kerrigan was an Arkansas-born conservative
column3: a tongue-in-cheek
column4: right-wing iconoclast whose favorite sport was teaching stupid pet tricks to the hounds of the Lefty God.  He'd first gained notoriety after a correspondent to the Harvard Crimson accused him of "oppression symbolism" for flying a Confederate battle flag from his dorm room window. Progressive students mobilized quickly to express their outrage and demand the flag's removal only to be caught flatfooted when
column5: at the height of their candlelight vigil
column6: a passing political science major pointed out that Kerrigan's racist Confederate flag was actually a British Union Jack.  A photographer for National Review just happened to be on hand to catch the red-faced squirming that followed; Rolling Stone columnist P. J. O'Rourke joined in the heaping of ridicule a couple of weeks later with a piece titled "Bean Town's Culturally Illiterate Elite: Why Johnny Can't Tell Grits from a Crumpet."  Suspecting--a tad late--that they'd been set up
column7: the flag-bashers reexamined the Crimson letter that had sparked their protest in the first place.  It was signed "A.K."  This bit of entrapment alone had earned Kerrigan a reserve spot in the lowest circle of Lefty Hades.  Hellbound or no
column8: though
column9: Archie was a crack biochemistry major with inside knowledge of the gene-splicing-for-profit business: he'd worked two summers for PhenoTech
column10: a genetic engineering firm currently being sued by the city of Boston for gross criminal negligence.  Joan thought he would be a perfect background source--or devil's advocate--for her paper.  But when she went to look him up
column11: she found the hallways outside his room jammed solid with angry women singing "We Shall Overcome."  "What blasphemy did he commit this time?" Joan asked.  "Andrea Dworkin
column12: the song leader told her.  Kerrigan's filed a complaint to block her from speaking on campus next week
column13: and they say that he's threatening to do the same thing if Alice Walker tries to come in December."  "What kind of complaint?  How can he block someone from speaking at a university?"  "It's the new Sensitivity in Debate Ordinance that the Harvard Executive Student Council enacted in closed session last Thursday
column14: a second singer chimed in.  It bars students from hosting lecturers whose presence may create an overtly hostile environment for any ethnic
column15: gender
column16: physical challenge
column17: or sexual orientation group
column18: or other oppression category."  "Kerrigan
column19: said a third singer, is claiming that an appearance by Dworkin would create a hostile environment for white male heterosexuals."  "And what genius thought up this Sensitivity Ordinance in the first place?"  Joan asked.  "I did
column20: the song leader said.  It's an important step in the evolution of progressive society
column21: but Kerrigan's action is a total subversion of the Ordinance's intent."  "Well
column22: intent notwithstanding
column23: if you got this beast enacted then Kerrigan is technically within his rights. Andrea Dworkin does create a hostile environment for white male heterosexuals; it's part of what makes her so interesting.  Of course a man who's read her essay on penile infibulation as street justice might not see it that way...."  "But the Ordinance is meant to safeguard tolerance by empowering students from oppressed groups.  White male students aren't oppressed."  "But if you make them the only group that can't censor hostile viewpoints
column24: they are oppressed."  "Look
column25: the song leader said, you obviously just don't get it.  If any group can veto speakers they find threatening
column26: even speakers with the correct point of view
column27: then pretty soon there won't be any speakers left at all.  That sort of indiscriminate use of the Ordinance renders it worthless."  "We might even have to repeal it
column28: the second singer added.  By the way
column29: said the third singer, jabbing an incisor-manicured finger at the rectangular bulge in Joan's hip pocket, 'don't even think of smoking in here.  It's antisocial behavior and we won't stand for it.

column3: but mostly found it did not live up to all my expectations. The book is classified as pscyhology and Cashdan makes the case for fairy tales offering psychologists and patients insights into psychological problems. This was something I had a hard time swallowing

column1: Restall's conclusions add nothing to what Tzvetan Todorov has already said in The Conquest of America-which Seven Myths gets wrong in its dismissal of Todorov's crucial point about the role of writing in the Conquest.  Merely being able to put information down on paper isn't the issue.  What Todorov means is much more complex
column2: and is grounded in evidence from anthropology to neuroscience (e.g.
column3: Ong
column4: Goody
column5: Havelock
column6: Panksepp).  First
column7: with written words fixed in front of you
column8: you can re-read
column9: check for inconsistencies
column10: compare to other accounts to assess accuracy and consider alternatives
column11: even elaborate.  You
column12: in fact
column13: practice thinking skills you have little opportunity to develop unless literate.  Restall also sees no reason to prefer an alphabetic system over
column14: say
column15: Aztec pictographs that interpreters used to recall memorized speeches embodying the culture.  But only with an alphabet can you unambiguously set down every single thing a person can think; and only then can an idea be fully worked out and fully critiqued.  Evidence shows that the way you think when you internalize an alphabetic written language is significantly more abstract
column16: analytical
column17: and adaptable than when you rely primarily on speech.  Second
column18: as Restall claims
column19: "disease
column20: native disunity
column21: Spanish steel
column22: and the culture of war
column23: are causes of the Aztec defeat, but, as Todorov rightly argues, they are only the immediate causes.  Underlying them is the ability to productively command signs (whether words or behaviors)-an ability that hinges on writing.  It's because the Spaniards had an extensive body of written knowledge that they had steel.  It's because of Corts' writing-based innovative thinking that he could exploit information about the native" situation to win allies.  It's because of the Aztecs' speech-based tradition-dominated thinking that they didn't see the Spaniards as a dangerous new breed of enemy that needed to be dispatched-long before smallpox arrived with a later expedition-and didn't effectively adapt battle conventions to fight this new
column24: unpredictable enemy.  Aztec society
column25: as Todorov emphasizes
column26: was NOT inferior to Spanish society in any absolute way.  The Aztecs clearly had a complex and highly successful culture.  But
column27: at that moment in history
column28: faced with a new kind of enemy shaped by written language
column29: they did not successfully compete.  Restall uncritically dismisses Todorov's argument instead of getting it straight

column12: discouraged
column13: hearing only the seeds of our well-worn
column14: ludicrous sexual double standard which dictates that women must be either virgins or whores
column15: either blessed or cursed
column16: while men are simply sexual athletes." And: "That we all begin inside a woman and must emerge from her body is something that the male theologians of the world's religions have yet to forgive us for."   She uses the f-word

column18: as when she notes with self-congratulatory satisfaction that after one such use her driver appeared startled because "[S]he apparently had heard that I was a religious writer." Well
column19: regrettably
column20: I had heard that

column22: who seemed to always analyze the nature of his own feelings instead of criticizing someone else who may have brought those feelings about. But then again

column24: a quality Norris needs to work hard to develop.  Norris has plenty of personal issues to deal with

column26: offering social criticism and justifying her life as "a poet.

column1: There was so much potential in this story
column2: but unfortunately
column3: the author did not have the ability to realize that potential. That in and of itself was so very sad. It's hard
column4: at least for this Asian American reader
column5: to sympathize with a self loathing Twinkie who
column6: while supposedly so "American"
column7: cosmopolitan
column8: and hip is so wretchedly naïve
column9: even dumb. It's actually insulting for the author to try to have us believe a woman in her late twenties living in NYC is this clueless when it comes to people using her like her former roommate does in this story.  Also
column10: choice moments to actually make some biting commentary about non Asian people's thoughts about Asian Americans never come to pass or erroneous ideas about Asian Americans
column11: especially Asian American women are never fully challenged such as when a white photographer talks about how he likes Asian women because they are so "mysterious". You cannot help but roll your eyes at the predictable "torn between two cultures" and "not interested in Korean men" themes that run through this story. To be fair
column12: some of the stories of racism do ring painfully true and some of the aspects of Korean American culture are familiar. However
column13: the character's career in the fashion magazine industry is supposed to give the story a certain amount of glamour and excitement
column14: yet the inherently shallow nature of the environment does nothing to give the character much depth nor does the author ever successfully develops any true depth in the main character or any of the characters in the entire story. Even the breakthroughs or nuggets of wisdom the character realizes toward the end of the story never seem genuine or profound. Rather
column15: the realizations seem hurried and forced as the author realizes that the story is supposed to end soon.  This story does nothing to break new ground
column16: challenge readers
column17: or offer much in the way of commentary-which is the biggest shame of all because it could have done all of that. Asian Americans should support work by other Asian Americans. But we should support good work. Not derivative pap.

It's hard to know where to begin when talking about this sensationalistic tabloid-like book.  On the one hand
column2: not everything is a lie
column3: exaggeration
column4: urban legend
column5: or told in a gleefully sensationalistic manner
column6: and there are good pictures
column7: but those aspects are really overwhelmed by how much of the book just isn't true.  It's uncertain just what propelled Kenneth Anger (who has a very fitting surname) to write this book; was it the fact he was bitter that his own Hollywood career never came to anything much
column8: a general dislike of most of the stars from Hollywood's Golden Age
column9: a love of sensational gossip in general
column10: or something else?  He's a writer of the same caliber as an Albert Goldman or Geoffrey Giuliano and their own celebrity biographies--it's been shown that most of what they've written just isn't true and has no basis in factual evidence and has never been proven
column11: so you have to doubt everything they write
column12: even if some passages are true or written in a respectful manner.  He's like the boy who cried wolf.  Although amazingly quite a few people believe all of the stories in this book and they're now regularly discussed like they actually happened and are absolute fact
column13: even though they're the results of speculation
column14: urban legends that have been disproven yet just won't go away because of books like this
column15: and are outright lies and character assassinations.  Just because I'm a fan of many of the celebrities from Old Hollywood doesn't mean I'm incapable of accepting that some of them did have less than perfect lives
column16: personal scandals
column17: and were the complete opposite of their screen personalities.  But by and large
column18: with certain exceptions
column19: the stars of that era were classy
column20: keeping their personal and private lives separate.  Even if they did have
column21: say
column22: problems with alcohol
column23: sleeping around
column24: or drug abuse
column25: they still presented positive public images and role models of class
column26: grace
column27: and style.  It wasn't like today
column28: when people seem to know just about every detail of a celebrity's private life.  Does Anger somehow feel that celebrities of yore were more prone to scandal and devastating problems?  And why does anyone want to know some of these sleazy details
column29: like about someone dying on the toilet?  Are we supposed to suddenly no longer like this person's body of work?  Even some celebrity biographies that do report events of this nature at least balance it out with just as much positive information and a respectful tone
column30: instead of taking delight in tearing down reputations.  It would seem baffling as to why people now take some of these stories as accepted facts
column31: no matter how many times they've been disproven
column32: but again
column33: it seems to be human nature to believe the bad and not the good.
